DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND PROMOTION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1983DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 October 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose these Bills. We will move amendments to the Dairy Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 in the Committee of the Whole. In line with the co-operation that generally has been extended by the Opposition to help the Government's legislative program, I will not hold up the Senate for any great length of time. The Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill 1983 has a two-fold purpose. First, it seeks to correct an anomalous situation whereby the levy is not payable on the dairy product content of certain mixtures. So this legislation basically provides a definition, particularly for butter milk and whole milk powders. Secondly, it provides that under certain circumstances levy may be refunded in respect of dairy products contained in other products that are exported, thus removing doubts about whether the levy could be refunded in those circumstances. I understand also that that basically would formalise a practice which is now in operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Bill 1983 seeks to impose a levy, with certain exceptions, on the production and sale of whole milk and butter fat. The proceeds of the levy are to be used for dairy research and to finance the Australian Dairy Corporation. The proposed increase in the levy has been recommended by the ADC and the Australian dairy farmers. The Corporation recommended that the operative rate be increased to 19 cents per 100 litres for whole milk and $4.75 per 100 kilos of butter fat produced. As well, the purpose of the Bill is to bring the Act into line with our metrification system in that it replaces the term 'gallons', which is now outmoded, with the term 'litres'. The Bill, taking into consideration the recommendations of the ADC, increases the amount payable from 12c to 24c per 100 litres for whole milk and from $3 to $6 per 100 kilos for butter fat.

We will be moving amendments to the Dairy Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1983 in the Committee of the Whole. This Bill amends the Dairy Produce Act 1924 and the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Act 1977. It brings up to date the Corporation's powers over the carriage of dairy produce by sea to places beyond Australia. The Dairy Industry Legislation Amendment Bill provides an increase from $10 to $100 of the penalty for the non-payment of levy and an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from a decision to refuse to remit an amount of the penalty. As I indicated, the Opposition does not oppose these Bills and wishes them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to run briefly through the important parts, as I see them, of the dairy Bills. The Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Bill basically provides, by way of levy, for increases in funds for dairy research and to finance the Australian Dairy Corporation. The amounts have been quoted as 19c per 100 litres of whole milk and $4.75 per 100 kilograms of butter fat produced. This has been arranged and agreed to by the Australian Dairy Corporation and the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. The Bill increases the levy on whole milk from 12c to 24c and on butter fat from $3 to $6.

SPEECH.PARA: The Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Amendment Bill produces new definitions and makes arrangements about products which are produced by the removal of water from a mixture of buttermilk or whole milk, and one or two other substances, which contain at least 25 per cent of buttermilk powder or whole milk powder. They will be subject to levy calculated according to how much buttermilk powder and whole milk powder the product actually contains. This will rectify certain anomalous situations that have arisen. The Bill goes on to allow refunds of levy under certain circumstances.

The Dairy Industry Legislation Amendment Bill relates to two main areas; one to do with the shipping of the product and one to do with the various penalties that are involved. It also inserts a new section 24A concerning the treatment of any debits, deficits and surpluses. It is in this regard that the Opposition will be moving an amendment. We believe it is important that certain restrictions be placed on just how these things should be treated. The Opposition does not oppose these changes because basically they are industry proposals. I think we need to take the opportunity to look at the state of the industry. I wish to read a few small pieces from a letter from the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) dated 18 March 1983. The first important item that strikes me is that in spite of seasonal conditions last year he stated that production actually increased from 5,181 billion litres in 1980-81 to 5,199 billion litres in 1981-82. The letter also states:
Nineteen per cent of Australia's milkfat production was exported during the year and we expect this percentage to increase in the year ahead.
I believe these two points are very important. I will come back to those shortly . We also need to take into account that the letter goes on to say:
. . . the very high stocks in the United States of America and the European Economic community . . . added together, . . . aggregate 1,115,000 tonnes of skim milk powder and 559,000 tonnes of butter.

Additionally, the USA is also carrying 358,000 tonnes of cheese. The position within the USA is further compounded in that milk production is increasing at an annual rate of 2 per cent. Further, it is estimated that, taken together, some 12,000 tonnes of butter, skim milk powder and cheese are being added to stock each week in the USA, and the market value of their surplus has been estimated at some US$2.7 billion.

We have to bear that in mind as we look at the state of the industry in Australia. The letter also states that prices for butter and the export market can be expected to weaken. It states also that the quantity of cheese sold increased 15 per cent, but the value only rose between 8 and 10 per cent. So the more we sell the more we are involved in lower market prices. The various powders do not look terribly encouraging either. The document states that the sales of skim milk powder were extremely slow and that we sold 13,000 tonnes of skim milk powder to Japan for stock feed. It always makes me wonder that, if we can sell powder to Japan for stock feed would it not be better to feed the stock in Australia. I know Senator Primmer has similar views. I have heard him discussing the matter on previous occasions. The document states that whole milk powders are marginal and so it goes on. I think the report from the Chairman, Mr Vawser, highlights the state of the market. We have to remember all the time that, while the operation of the Corporation has been of tremendous assistance, we have to be careful in case it provides too much assistance so that we are increasing production to do the same as happened in the European Economic Community and the United States and slowly build up a surplus and a problem with which somebody else will have to deal.

The dairy underwriting scheme which has now been in force nearly 10 years has been a great support for the industry. The 95 per cent payment for the product that has been bought over the previous three years has become a very satisfactory way of providing an underpinning of the market. Another document which I obtained recently states that the production between 1970-71 and 1983-84 had fallen by 22 per cent but it is now rising again and far from bottoming out it seems to be on the increase even though there are now only about a quarter of the number of dairy farmers that there were in the late 1950s.

The marketing of dairy produce is an area that has always caused a lot of concern. Far too often it has been handled by people usually representative of the co-operative interests that are unskilled in the fields of marketing. They do not have enough product to be able to make a large impact on the world markets. They seem ill-inclined to get together to try to market in a universal way. The Corporation has done a certain amount towards bringing this together but it has not stopped people who do not have this ability from going out into the market-place and trying to sell product where they can and in competition with one another, when in collaboration they could probably do considerably better.

The question of the number of pools has been discussed recently. I too would urge the industry to give this a lot of consideration. At the time the various pools were set up it was a good idea, but now I believe they are insulating various participants against the true market forces. Limiting the pools, probably in line with the suggestion that came from Unigate Australia Pty Ltd, is worthy of consideration. Its proposal was that there should be only two pools , one for fat and another for solids not fat. If we were able to look at the product along those lines we may well find it is the best determinant in the market. It may well encourage some of the manufacturers to produce product that is more suitable to the market requirements and to make changes as they become necessary.

If we were able to do that we would be able to encourage both the processors and the primary producers to be more concerned about what happens to the product and how it will produce the best price. We have to encourage people to do what is best and to produce the right products. We do not want to support people who are producing the commodity which is most marginal, and that is still happening in some cases. The recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission have not been universally accepted throughout the industry. I think it is unfortunate that all sections of the industry have been unable to come together on many of these matters. A paper I received recently contained the following comment:

All interested parties, including Federal and State Governments and Oppositions , dairy farmers and processors, should look beyond the economic jargon, such as efficiency of resource use etc, contained in the report because there are sound reasons why the Commission's recommendations should be given very serious consideration.

That is all very well and I fully understand it, but it does not take into account that the dairy industry, besides being a national industry as far as export surplus is concerned, is also very much a domestic industry. Whilst I have sympathy for the States who are not in the export market and whose efficiency is less than the two best States, shall we say, they do have considerable rights in looking after their own communities and State economies. However, I believe that over a period we have to see that the efficiency drifts to where it is best used. We want to make sure that we are not encouraging the least efficient producers to obtain too much of the resource by subsidising them to do what other people could do much better.

I regret that the dairy industry as a whole was unable to make a united response to the IAC inquiry. I think it is most unfortunate, and all I can really say is that I believe the industry would do far better to produce the best report that it can in unison than to wait and see what the Government is going to impose upon it. I am firmly of the opinion that the best place for government is out of the business, and I believe the dairy industry would be of a similar mind. I know all the differences, and I have spoken to most of the people involved in various areas who disagree, but I still believe they would have been better to have made some decisions themselves than to leave it to the Government to do on their behalf.

I have read the IAC report fairly carefully and I believe it faces the position quite openly. It does not adequately take into account the local issues, but I think it is a basis for discussion. It is realistically presented and I hope that the industry will be able to continue to use it as a document for consideration and a document from which it can make recommendations not only to governments but also to itself.

There simply has to be more emphasis on market orientation. It is imperative that we look to new products and keep watching the EEC and the United States very carefully. I think the administration of the industry has been under pressure and under question. The industry itself has to become more united and conscious of its responsibility. It is largely dependent on the co-operation that it receives from the State and Federal governments. I believe it needs to maximise this situation by ensuring that its own house is in order to its best possible advantage.

A considerable move has been made recently towards training. I can only urge that this proceeds. Some of the farmer training programs are working very well. Training now extends into the realm of people working in the processing factories and advice is even being provided to the directors of co-operatives and the management of both proprietaries and co-operatives. I urge that this continue and spread as far as possible. But all this training is of little avail if the processors are struggling, inefficient, making the wrong product or if the industry is run by less than capable people. Every section of the industry should be looking inwardly at itself, to see whether it is doing the best it can by the suppliers, the country, its own State and the industry as a whole. I support the industry; I alway have. But I urge it to streamline its administration. I also urge it to uncover to the market forces more progressively than it has done. In particular, I urge it to beware of creeping over-production and the problems that would arise from that. I urge it to continue to extend its research into its product range, manufacturing and production in general. I support the passage of the Bills and the amendment circulated by Senator Collard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Government will not accept any amendments which have been proposed. I will go into that in a little more detail later. I do not suppose that I was particularly interested, but I noted once again Senator Archer's typical Liberal Party rhetoric, which is in conflict with the facts and empirical evidence. It was the typical Liberal Party pseudo ideological commitment to getting government out of the business of the dairy industry, as he put it. At the same time the National Party, always dragging along with it or pushing ahead of it the Liberal Party dog, has of course long involved government in dairy industry affairs in such a way that it extracted higher prices from the domestic market than would prevail in a free market situation, to which the Liberal Party ostensibly is committed, in order either to subsidise losses on exports or, alternatively, to capitalise the monopoly profits which accrue to restricted entry in the market value of quotas.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that yet again the Liberal Party rhetoric and pseudo ideology pouring out of the mouth of Senator Archer is absolutely in conflict with the empirical evidence and the facts. That is one of the reasons why this hypocritical, rudderless, leaderless party is now in opposition in this Parliament and in almost every other mainland parliament in Australia. Very shortly, following the next election, I expect it will still be in opposition throughout mainland Australia. It demonstrates, albeit in a minor way, the Liberal Party's need to rethink its mythology or, rather to rethink its actual beliefs and throw out the window the mythology, nonsense, humbug and hypocrisy of the type we have heard pouring from Senator Archer's mouth, and develop a set of policies which actually have some reference and relevance to the real world.

The Bill itself, of course, simply seeks to increase the levies which may be applied on milk and other dairy products for promotional purposes. One would hope that the promotional purposes to which they are applied in the future are more productive for the industry than the way in which some of them have been applied in the past. They appear to have been applied to advantage particular former employees of the Australian Dairy Corporation, rather than to advantage the dairy industry and the dairy producers. But that is probably a separate matter too.

We will not accept the amendments, Mr-I am sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President -to be moved by Senator Collard because they make no sense in that the original clause which they seek to amend deals with trading activities, whereas one of the amendments to be put up by Senator Collard deals with investments. It really makes no sense. I add that the Country Party-or the National Party, whatever it calls itself these days-is displaying the chutzpah for which it is traditionally noted in having the audacity to propose such an amendment clearly aimed at the impending losses accruing to PT Australia Indonesia Milk Industries Inc. when the National Party's own Minister a couple of years ago gratuitously gave a direction to the Dairy Corporation that it not proceed with a proposed sale or an offer of purchase from Kebun Bunga for $US10m. The Indonesian Government may or may not have rejected that application for sale. The point, however, is that the then Country Party Minister, Mr Nixon, gratuitously relieved the Indonesian Government of the obligation or duty to make any such decision by intervening himself and preventing the Corporation allowing that sale to proceed.

As a result of that piece of meddling by that National Party Minister, the Dairy Corporation, and ultimately the dairy farmers, now stand to lose a very considerable amount of money, possibly more than $10m. I note again the National Party tail pushing ahead of it, as usual, the Liberal Party dog. Its audacity, its cheek, in proposing an amendment like this to try-

TALK.START.PARA: —You can find better adjectives than that.
—Chutzpah is the one I normally use. We probably could not find a better adjective than that to describe the Country Party or, for that matter, the Tasmanian Premier.
—Cheer him up. Tell him a funny story. Smile, Peter.

—Senator Withers might care to give us his opinions of the Australian Democrats, as he was doing yesterday, and vice versa. That amendment displays typical Country Party cheek in purporting to do something to minimise the losses which are likely to accrue to the Australian Dairy Corporation and ultimately to dairy farmers through the problems associated with the sale of PT Indomilk, problems which have been created substantially by the actions of a former National Party Minister. The second amendment from the Australian Democrats, relating to shipping contracts, in the Government's view would, if applied, be cumbersome and would unnecessarily add to administrative problems, yet it states in proposed sub-section 3 that:

SPEECH.PARA: Any failure to comply with the requirements of this sub-section in relation to a decision-
that is, a decision on shipping-
does not affect the validity of the Corporation's decision.

In other words, it provides a sort of loophole that enables the Corporation to bypass appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is apparently the ostensible primary purpose of the amendment. The Government will not accept either of those amendments. However, I understand that the Bill will not be opposed by the Opposition or by the Australian Democrats. I do not intend to delay its passage any longer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND PROMOTION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1983DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1983DAIRY INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 4, after proposed section 19, insert the following section:
Review of decisions
'19AA. (1) An application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of conditions approved by the Corporation under sub-section 19 (1).

(2) Where the Corporation notifies each licensee, under sub-section 19 (2), of the conditions approved under section 19 (1), that notice shall include a statement to the effect that, subject to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, an application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of decisions of the Corporation relating to such conditions by or on behalf of any person whose interests are affected by the decisions.
(3) Any failure to comply with the requirements of sub-section (2) in relation to a decision does not affect the validity of the Corporation's decision.'.

This amendment is one which the Australian Democrats have moved on a number of occasions. It arises out of the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, the ninth report dated 12 October 1983, in relation to contracts for shipping of dairy products. The item under proposed section 19 to which the amendment refers is a proposed new section giving the Australian Dairy Corporation extensive powers to approve conditions relating to contracts for the cartage of dairy products by sea. The Corporation is required simply to inform the licensee of the conditions that it requires. There is no other limitation put on the Corporation's power, nor is there any provision for review of these contracts. The situation when the Corporation is operating reasonably is that there would be no difficulty. However, unduly onerous conditions could be imposed by the Corporation. On the other hand, extremely lenient conditions could be imposed. The people involved would want to appeal the onerous ones, and the Government might well want to appeal the lenient conditions. The Australian Democrats believe that it would seem to be appropriate that there be an ability to review that type of decision on the part of the Corporation so that people who may feel themselves aggrieved would have the ability to argue their case before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

This is a reasonable amendment. It is the standard provision which appears in a number of Acts. It would simply allow the appeal, after notice has been given by the Corporation, to the AAT. The Government has supported this type of provision in the past when in opposition. I suggest that it might well support this amendment in a spirit of continuing its long held view in opposition that the ability of people to seek a review of adverse decisions of corporations or other statutory bodies upon them is a principle that is worth upholding. Perhaps the Minister will respond and say why it is that the Government will not allow an appeal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I tried to respond when speaking on the second reading. Firstly, we see it as being an unjustifiable impediment or a cumbersome addition to the procedures that are in place and, secondly, there is provision for it to become meaningless anyway-at least on our reading of it-by reason of sub clause (3) in Senator Macklin's amendment which says, that failure to comply does not affect the validity of the Corporation's decision. In other words, we believe it is something which is probably not necessary and even if it is necessary, it would be ineffective anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, clause 6, proposed sub-section 24A (4), line 4, before ''The Minister'', insert ''Subject to sub-section (8),''.
(2) Page 4, clause 6, after proposed sub-section 24A (7), add the following sub -section:
'' '(8) The Minister, with respect to the Australian dairy industry's investment in overseas companies-
(a) shall not give a direction to the Corporation under sub-section (4); and

(b) shall, in consultation with the Corporation, the Australian Dairy Industry Conference and the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, examine all options available for the meeting of losses incurred by means of investments of this kind, with recourse to use of moneys held in export pools being considered only as a last resort.'.''.

I must say that, on a morning when we are trying to get legislation through and everybody is in good heart and mind, it was an unusual tirade from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh). I suppose that if we had a standing order that allowed him to go back to bed, get out again on the right side and start all over again we might get on a little better. Even if he drank some more dairy products the mood of the chamber might be a little better. We have always been concerned about his lack of vision but it is unforgivable that he earlier confused the gender of the occupant of the President's chair. We would forgive anything else but I would like the Minister to assure Senator Haines, on behalf of the National Party at least, that she is most decidedly and delightfully feminine.

Be that as it may, notwithstanding the tirade, I am still pressing the amendments. The amendments have come about after discussions with the industry. They are to do with the losses sustained by PT Australia Indonesia Milk Industries Inc. or, as it has become known, PT Indomilk. The amendments are derived from concern that losses sustained by this company should not be treated as just trading losses and be made up out of the export pools but rather that they be treated as investment losses-this is the thinking of the dairy industry itself-and if necessary be handled out of the diary industry stabilisation fund. In other words, the losses would be borne by the industry as a whole. The amendments basically ask the Minister not just to handle these losses out of the export pool but rather to handle them only after consultation with the Australian Dairy Industry Conference and the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation . It is their wish that this should happen. Ironically, I understand that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), when speaking in the other place, indicated that this is what he would probably be doing. He did not accept the amendments there even though he accepted the thrust of them. I do not see why the Committee, recognising that the amendments express the wish of the industry and recognising the fact that the Minister has indicated that he would probably be acting along these lines, cannot accept the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Australian Democrats agree with the Government's opinion on these particular amendments that were moved in the other place and have been moved here again by Senator Collard. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in the other place on 5 October said:

SPEECH.PARA: Directions given under proposed new section 24A (4) relate only to surpluses and deficits on export sales of dairy products whereas the amendment proposed by the Opposition concerns the dairy industry's investment in overseas companies.

The Australian Democrats admit that the specific problem which concerns the Opposition, indeed it concerns many if not all honourable senators in this place , could be interpreted as a trade matter on one reading of the amendment moved by Senator Collard. However, I am uncertain as to whether or not it is covered, given the rather vague wording, particularly of proposed new sub-section 8 (b). The Government, in relation to a previous matter has already given us a clear commitment that this Parliament will have an opportunity to discuss emergency funding if it becomes necesssary in relation to unwise overseas investments by the Australian Dairy Corporation. The Australian Democrats sought such an assurance and the Government gave it. We are willing to rely upon that assurance at present. With respect to the Australian dairy industry's investment in overseas companies, I believe that had the Opposition moved an amendment along the line that the Minister shall not give a direction to the Corporation under sub-section (4) without previously consulting with the Corporation, the situation might be different. In other words rather than simply saying under paragraph (a), shall not give a direction to the Corporation, and then go on to suggest that if they have to, they can-having ruled this out under paragraph (a) -I believe it would be extremely difficult in legislative terms to do anything under paragraph (b). If it had been said that a direction cannot be given without previously consulting with the Corporation and with the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation that proposition certainly would have been acceptable to the Australian Democrats. I think it would have had some meaning. At the moment the Australian Democrats cannot support Senator Collard's amendments because we think they would be unworkable.

There is also a matter of principle involved in the Opposition's amendments with which we have some difficulty. This issue was raised by Senator Archer. Indeed, I think these amendments run against some of the tenor of the points that Senator Archer was making. If the average person in the street goes out, buys into a small business and six months later a supermarket is opened down the road, then there is no government pool of funds which will cover the losses of the person involved in that small business. What is being suggested is that the Australian Dairy Corporation, while it should be able to keep its profits, should not have a situation whereby the Minister cannot direct it to bear the costs of its ill advised ventures. The Australian Democrats believe that such corporations would function much better if indeed they did bear the burden of their own financial decisions. I think they would be much wiser managers of both government and producer money if they could not simply shuffle off the effects of unwise decisions. Indeed, I believe that the producers would be much more interested in playing an active role in the Corporation, in geting the Corporation to work strongly and in putting increased pressure on the Corporation to make it accountable if, in fact, the producers' funds were involved in the commercial operations of the Corporation and those funds were at risk in the same way as are funds in other commercial ventures. I indicate that the Democrats cannot accept the amendments on those two grounds. One is that we think it would be unworkable. The second ground is that we do not agree with the principle of propping up to the extent of allowing corporations to make unwise financial decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking on this legislation before the adjournment debate last night I was dealing with Senator Peter Rae's Bill. I had pointed out the constitutional uncertainty that follows the Senate's rejection of Supply when a double dissolution trigger is in place. I was about to say that I have even more considerable doubt as to whether a Governor-General would dissolve the House of Representatives whilst the Prime Minister maintained the confidence of that House in circumstances where the Senate rejects Supply but a double dissolution trigger is not in place. That to me is a position of great uncertainty. In any event, I do not believe that the Senate should be able to send the House of Representatives to the people without going itself. Therefore, the position needs to be clarified. Either the Senate should cease to have power to reject Supply or the Constitution should provide what is to happen if it does so reject Supply. Senator Rae's Bill gives the people the opportunity to confirm that they desire the Senate to retain its power and that, upon this major exercise of reponsibility, both Houses should go to the polls. The attempt is also to define, if only in the negative, an appropriation of revenue or money for the ordinary annual services of government. As an attempt at clarification of a vexed problem, I believe it also is to be applauded.

SPEECH.PARA: Next I wish to deal briefly with Senator Mason's Bill which is to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws. I do not reject this as arrant nonsense as suggested by some other senators because any move to involve the community more directly in the legislative process will receive from me a sympathetic hearing. But, after considerable thought, I have determined not to give it my support. I believe that the energy utilised in obtaining a quarter of a million signatures could be better used by making the existing system work more effectively. I ask honourable senators to imagine those involved using that energy in motivating and becoming more active within the political parties, in stimulating debate, and in educating and lobbying politicians as to the merits of their particular points and arguments. Again, I am concerned about the cost at the referendum stage. I believe that the money could be better spent in upgrading and further improving the current system. For example, such funds could allow more widespread public hearings by Senate committees in relation to government legislation before the Senate. I am not convinced as to the merits of changing the formula by which constitutional change might be brought about as contained in Senator Mason's Bill. I think recent experiences have suggested that the Constitution is sufficiently flexible to adapt to a changing world and a changing Australia. I would prefer to see the energy and funds that would be saved by not adopting this Bill utilised in making parliamentary democracy, as we know it, work better.

I next wish to deal with the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill 1983. This particularly important Bill deals with advisory opinions. I remind the Senate that in July of this year at the Australian Legal Convention in Brisbane the Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, spoke against the proposal to seek advisory opinions of the High Court. When speaking of the Canadian position, he said:
. . . in my opinion it is neither necessary-or desirable to adopt a similar procedure in Australia.
He continued:
I think I am right in saying that that view is shared by the other members of my Court.

It is obviously not for the Court to say what work it shall be given. However, disquiet by one as senior as the Chief Justice should not be dismissed without explanation. That is particularly so when he is not alone. I draw the attention of the Senate to an opinion by the Constitutional Law Committee of the Law Council of Australia in August 1977, which concluded:

For these reasons, the Committee is of the view that the Constitution should not be amended to enable the High Court to give advisory opinions on any matter. We reach this conclusion, not from any instinctive desire to avoid constitutional change, but because in the fair exercise of our judgment based on our experience in constitutional cases we considered the suggested amendment to be wholly undesirable (in relation to pre-legislation) and unnecessary (in relation to post-enactment).
The Chief Justice, in part, also argues that it is unnecessary in relation to post-enactment, and I quote from his speech to the Australian Legal Convention:

My Court has always taken a very liberal view in deciding whether it should give a declaratory judgment to resolve a constitutional question, and it is difficult to suppose that any question which is ripe for decision could not promptly be submitted to the High Court under the existing procedure.

I believe an examination of the history of the practice of the High Court in relation to declaratory judgments tends to confirm what the Chief Justice said. We know that for a declaratory judgment there should be rival parties presenting controversy to the Court for adjudication. We know of the requirements of standing and justiciability that must be satisfied. The suit must raise a matter as required by the Constitution. In practice, the extraordinarily liberal interpretation of these prerequisites has led one commentator to say:
The prematurity and breadth of the challenge, and the abstract manner in which the legal issues were presented, make the suit (for a declaration) resemble proceedings for an advisory opinion.

So one might say that, if we already have the declaratory judgments being interpreted in such broad terms, we do not need advisory opinions, which is the argument the Chief Justice puts. Alternatively, one might argue that if we have declaratory judgments which require the High Court to stretch standing and justiciability, it is better to formalise the system through an advisory opinion procedure.

It is not surprising that most of the objections in relation to post-enactment cases are the same objections that are put in relation to advisory opinions and declaratory judgments. Particularly because of the criticism of one as senior as the Chief Justice, I believe it is necessary to address the objections to advisory opinions that are commonly put in relation to the post-enactment situation. The first that one commonly hears is that advisory opinions are an infringement of the docrine of separation of powers. I would dismiss that immediately. This appears to me to be clearly still a judicial function of the Court. Secondly, some say that they would lead to possible politicisation of the Court. I think in relation to post-enactment that also is clearly invalid. The Court, by delivering an advisory opinion, would not become part of the Executive or the legislature. The third argument that one sometimes hears is the need for judicial decisions to determine concrete issues. That was certainly a concern of the Chief Justice when he said:
. . . the Court would be required to consider questions in the abstract, and possibly before the practical implications of the legislation had come to be fully understood.
This is what some say is a desirability for a judgment from experience as against a judgment from speculation.

The position is that some constitutional cases will have to be decided on the facts, such as section 92 cases, but others not necessarily so. In many cases in respect of declaratory judgment, the High Court has not necessarily required a concrete fact situation and has had no trouble in reaching a decision. To take the matter one step further, I remind the Senate that it is not uncommon for the High Court to go further and make obiter dicta on questions of constitutionality , which dicta are not really necessary, given the factual situation at hand. One case that comes to mind is the Rocla Pipes case, which was concerned with the possible width of corporation power. I see that his objection is not so much an absolute direction but rather an indication of a need for care by the party seeking the opinion. Not all Acts will be suitable to be submitted to the Court without facts, and even if hypothetical facts are submitted there may be difficulties. No doubt the Court will respond by declining to answer questions ' if it concludes that they do not exhibit sufficient precision to permit cogent answers', as was the case in a recent Canadian case referred to by the Chief Justice in the speech I have just mentioned.

The fourth argument that one sometimes hears is the possible binding effect of advisory opinions. I think it must be clearly understood that the opinion will be only as good as the material submitted. The Court is free to come to a different decision in a concrete factual situation, and that is a position that must be recognised and taken into account when an Attorney-General or some other party seeks an advisory opinion. The fifth argument is that advisory opinions would mean the imposition of a greater burden on the Court. That, of course, is the case in relation to any additional or expanded jurisdiction. It solely requires a political judgment; it is not an objection in itself. There is one last objection I wish to mention. It is argued by some that, by their nature, advisory opinions do not involve the benefit of legal representation and argument by contesting private parties. I know that some purists might place great emphasis on the traditional adversary system in ensuring that all argument is put before the Court. I believe this concern underrates the capability of the Court and I do not share that concern.

Therefore, I believe the objections can be answered. There will be advantages, in appropriate cases, if this procedure in relation to post-enactment matters is brought into effect. I believe that one advantage was eloquently put by Mr Cranshaw in a good article on the subject which appears in the Australian Law Journal, when he said:
We have a right to live under constitutional laws. In the appropriate case earliest possible adjudication of constitutionality may be desirable.

That opportunity could occur before the Act is in fact proclaimed. Therefore, largely as legitimising the flexible practices that the Court has permitted in relation to declaratory judgments, taking into account the success of the option in those jurisdictions, particularly in India and Canada and its provinces, where it has been evident that the method has been an effective device in minimising the danger of unconstitutional legislation, and bearing in mind the advice given by the 1928 royal commission on the Constitution, the 1977 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and the report of the same year of the Judiciary Committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention all of which saw merit in this proposal, I am prepared to support it.

But I am most concerned as to the pre-enactment power, that is, the power to refer Bills, not laws, to the Court for opinion. It appears to me that that is an abdication of the Government's responsibility and that of its law officers. It is potentially drawing the Court into a legislative role, allowing abuses of the Government forwarding draft after draft to the Court to get it right, and removes from parliament a responsibility which it has. Mr Cranshaw, in his article, referred to 'the desirability of constitutionality being determined with reference to the finished statutory product which has passed through the beneficial ordeal of public discussion, legislative debate and deliberate enactment'. I adopt those words in this case. Therefore, I am clearly of the opinion that before the enactment of legislation has taken place a Bill which involves abstract questions should not be forwarded to the Court for advisory opinion. I note that the power to refer Bills was not included in the report of the Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which I mentioned. It was not included in the 1928 royal commission. I regard the referral of pre-enactment legislation as highly undesirable. Although I would like to support the Bill in relation to post-enactment I could not support it in its present form, while pre -enactment remains included.

The final Bill I wish to touch upon in the minute or so which I have remaining relates to the interchange of powers. I am pleased to support the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill. I believe that in a dynamic Constitution this Bill gives the State and Federal parliaments a little more flexibility and responsiveness, to adopt the language of the then Premier Hamer of Victoria in speaking on this matter, flexibility and responsiveness that can be utilised for the general public benefit. Therefore, I am pleased to support the Bill. I am not concerned by some of the worries that have been expressed that it is a radical departure. It appears to me that it is not a radical departure at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is a pity, after we have been debating these Constitution alteration Bills for so long, that one should come back to some sort of political reality. In my opinion, we have all been in somewhat of a cloud-cuckoo-land for some days regarding these Bills. As I understand it, on 25 February next there will be a vote on these referendum proposals. On that day, at a cost of some $10m, $15m or $20m, 10 million electors or thereabouts will go to the polls of whom, of course, one million or so will be unemployed. I trust that as those one million unemployed people walk into the polling booth they will say to themselves: 'What is in this for me? After all, we have had a Hawke Government for 12 months and at the end of its time all it can do is put up this mass of trivia at a cost of $10m, $15m or $20m and here are a million of us still unemployed'. I trust that the Government members and senators in this Parliament will be going around their unions, their labour leagues and their Australian Labor Party branches attempting to whip up enthusiasm, and will be able to convince their workers to get out and really work for these proposals. After all, it is far better to indulge in trivia than to fix up the problems of the nation!

SPEECH.PARA: In the last 12 months or thereabouts we have had a number of interestingly led recoveries. Mr Deputy President, I notice that you are looking anxiously, but I will connect my remarks to the referendum. As honourable senators will know, first of all we had a consensus-led recovery. Then we had a Summit-led recovery. We are now in the middle of a royal commissions-led recovery. We are really indulging in a record deficit-led recovery. Early prisoner release-led recovery is evidently trying to help New South Wales out of its problems! Mr Dawkins is discovering that we have a disclosure of pecuniary interests-led recovery going on. One could keep going on. Of course, a lot of the time since the Parliament began sitting we have been having, in this place, a sex discrimination-led recovery; a luxury swimming pool-led recovery; a withholding tax-led recovery and a Tasmanian dam-led recovery. At last, God help us, we are going to have a referendum-led recovery.

What are the Bills all about? What a mass of trivia, except for two. Of all the proposals only two are of some interest to the electors. The first is what one might call, in shorthand terms, the Rae proposal. At least it is an attempt to give the electors of this country a fair go against the politicians. The other proposal is what might again, in shorthand terms, be called the Hamer proposal. That again is an attempt to keep politicians honest. That is always a very good thing that politicians particularly ought to be trying to do. But as one looks across the rest of the trivia which is before us one sees that it is all about making things easier for politicians.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government.
—No, all of us.
—We thought that would particularly appeal to you.

—No. See, I am the last of the workers. Unlike Senator Button I come from a genuine Labor working class family. I managed to escape that and pick up the Liberal Christian work ethic. I therefore understand why work is somewhat anathema to people on the opposite side. I understand that Senator Button wishes to make a ministerial statement about some other led recovery which we are about to have. Therefore I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.

MINISTERIAL STATEMENT

The previous Government announced the establishment of the Review of Customs Administration and Procedures on 27 April 1982 following the resignation of the then Ministers for Health and Business and Consumer Affairs over the importation of a colour television set through Sydney Airport in October 1981. Mr F. J. Mahony, C.B., O.B.E., President of the Repatriation Review Tribunal was appointed to undertake the Review.
The terms of reference for the Review required it to examine the administration and procedures for the control and clearance of imported goods under the Customs Act in New South Wales.

The Review was asked to have particular regard to three areas. First, the clearance of incoming passengers and their unaccompanied baggage and also the clearance of incoming cargo at Sydney Airport; second, the relations between management, staff and Staff Associations; and third, the need to ensure the efficient and impartial application of Customs procedures. Mr Mahony was also asked to report on any changes that may be necessary or desirable for more efficient and effective administration, including industrial relations, and to ensure observance of the instruction by the then Prime Minister in 1976 that all Australians should receive equal treatment in respect of the enforcement of Customs legislation.

Written submissions were invited by public notice in the newspapers and 30 submissions were received from private citizens, industry organisations, individual companies, Federal and State Government departments, community groups and staff organisations. The Review held a series of public hearings.
Mr Mahony submitted his Report to me on 13 April this year. I asked him to provide me with additional advice on two matters which I will refer to later. I received that further advice on 19 July.

The Report is critical of aspects of Customs management in a number of areas such as industrial relations, management training and communication with staff. Whilst no major operational deficiencies were revealed, some procedural shortcomings were identified.
It points to ways in which the Customs administration might be improved and recommends ways in which some procedures might be made more effective.

The Government has considered Mr Mahony's report and has accepted the very large majority of his recommendations. Whilst the Review dealt only with the Customs administration in New South Wales, many of the recommendations will be implemented nationwide.
I turn now to certain of the key recommendations.
V.I.P. Procedures

As I have said, Mr Mahony was asked to report on the impartial application of Customs procedures and on any changes which may be necessary or desirable to ensure that all Australians returning from overseas should receive equal treatment under Customs legislation.

Mr Mahony has concluded that the impartial application of Customs procedures did not occur in the incident in which Mr MacKellar was involved; nor was he satisfied that the procedures have always been applied impartially to passengers who have been facilitated, or in other words, received V.I.P. treatment.
The Report, whilst acknowledging that Customs facilitation arrangements for V.I .P.s are generally suitable, recommends certain specific procedures which should be applied.

These would require the passenger to present himself or herself to a primary line officer; to retire then to a V.I.P. room if this has been arranged; to identify his or her baggage for Customs processing; and to leave the Customs area only with the permission of a designated Customs officer.

The Government has decided that any facilitation of returning Australians will be in accordance with the procedures recommended by Mr Mahony. In doing so it re -affirms the position of the previous Government that all Australians returning from overseas receive equal treatment in respect of the enforcement of Customs and Quarantine requirements.
Imports of Pornographic Material

Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations prohibits the import of pornography without the approval of the Attorney-General's Department. Since 1973, the policy of successive Governments has been based on the principle that it is the basic right of adults to make their own decisions as to what they read, hear and see. Child pornography is the principal exception to this principle. Customs operational guidelines reflect this policy although the Regulation has not been amended to give effect to the policy.

Mr Mahony has recommended that the conflict between Regulation 4A and the Customs direction (which reflects the policies of successive Governments) be resolved without delay. The Government accepts this recommendation and the Attorney-General will arrange for the necessary amendment to the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations.
Search of Suspect Persons

Section 196 of the Customs Act authorises Customs officers to search people who they have reasonable cause to suspect are unlawfully carrying smuggled or prohibited goods secreted about them. A prime target in such searches is concealed illicit drugs.

The Government has considered carefully the recommendation on this matter which is in seven parts. It has rejected the first three parts. The first is that a Customs officer who has reasonable cause to conduct a personal search not be required to obtain the permission of a senior officer before conducting the search. The Government considers that it is in the best interests both of the person to be searched and the searching officer that the decision to search be tested with a senior officer before a search is conducted.

The second is that the plain language explanation on the card 'Your Rights', which is shown to a person prior to that person being searched, be deleted, leaving only the legal language of section 196 on the card. The Government considers on balance that the plain language explanation should remain in the interests of the person to be searched. We have directed, however, that the explanation be reviewed to ensure that it is both fully and clearly understandable and reflects the law.

The Customs Act provides a person with the right to have a search decision reviewed by a Justice or the Collector. Mr Mahony recommends that the person should also have the right to choose between a Justice or the Collector. This is contrary to long standing and recently confirmed advice of the Attorney-General' s Department and therefore the Government has not accepted the third part of the recommendation.
The Government has decided that Departmental instructions on searches be amended to reflect the four remaining elements of the recommendation:

deletion from existing instructions of the need for a senior officer to be available to assist a Justice or the Collector, thereby ensuring that there is no inference that the decision of the Justice or Collector has been the subject of influence;
provide that the suspect be invited by the Justice or the Collector to put reasons why no search should be conducted;
ensure that officers who conduct searches have explained to them at regular intervals the basis on which they may form a reasonable cause to suspect; and
ensure that every officer who conducts a search adequately and promply records in his notebook the grounds on which he has undertaken the search.

Mr Mahony has also recommended that an unproclaimed amendment to section 196, introduced to clarify the authority to conduct internal searches, be reviewed. The Government has directed that this review be undertaken as a matter of priority and that it take into account the views of the Law Reform Commission on privacy matters.
Industrial Relations

The report deals in detail with the question of industrial relations. Mr Mahony noted that management and staff associations expressed conflicting views on issues and that a lack of willingness of the parties to compromise had led to considerable industrial unrest in the NSW Collectorate. In arriving at this observation, Mr Mahony also mentioned that evidence indicated some improvement in the last two years.

Mr Mahony concluded: 'I do not suggest that there is any single remedy which will immediately resolve the Customs difficulties with staff associations, but it is clear that staff associations and Customs management will need to make a greater effort to settle differences if industrial peace is to be achieved'.

Since Mr Mahony reported, the Department has been involved in a range of further consultations with the unions on the restructuring of the Australian Customs Service. With the agreement of the Public Service Board, certain modifications to the scheme have been put forward recently, aimed at making the new Service more attractive to the staff. These changes also reflect some criticism of the previous arrangements by Mr Mahony.
The Secretary of my Department and the Collector of Customs, New South Wales, have assured me that they will continue to make every effort to improve the quality of industrial relations.
Other Recommendations

One matter I wish to comment on is Mr Mahony's observation that he could not be satisfied that the relevant procedures for processing of documents were being applied efficiently and uniformly to all imported goods under the control of Customs. I wish to make three points on this matter.
First, in making the data available to the Review, the Department pointed out that statistical measurement of the efficiency of processing documents for imported goods required further refinement.
Secondly, Mr Mahony acknowledged that many of the documentation errors, if detected, would not affect the amount of duty payable.

Thirdly, the Department is not satisfied with the current method of collecting statistics on errors, nor is it satisfied with the apparent level of undetected errors. Revised procedures are being developed and tested and a consultant is to be engaged to introduce more reliable effectiveness measurement methodology.
Additional Advice Sought from Mr Mahony

Following receipt of Mr Mahony's report I sought further advice from him on two matters. The first matter concerned evidence given by Mr G. M. Hough at a public session of the Review on 20 December 1982 that he had made a written report to Mr Michael Drury about the incident concerning Mr MacKellar at Sydney Airport on 5 October 1981 and later evidence by Mr Hough in a statement in the form of a minute to the Assistant Collector, Air, dated 19 January 1983 that to the best of his knowledge he did not submit a written report to Mr Michael Drury on 6 October 1981.

On this matter Mr Mahony has advised me that although it is not free from doubt , on the evidence the better opinion is that Mr Hough did not submit a written report; and that he is unable to resolve to any greater degree the conflict arising from Mr Hough's evidence on 20 December 1982 and his minute dated 19 January 1983.

The second matter concerned whether the apparent conflict between an account given by Mr Mayhew of what transpired at interviews with senior Customs officers and the reports made by those officers which were tabled in the House of Representatives justified further enquiry. Mr Mahony advised me that from enquiries he had made, it seemed that Mr Mayhew had lodged a claim for compensation and that for this reason he should not enquire further into that matter.

Mr Mayhew's claim for compensation was subsequently granted by the Commissioner for Employees Compensation, who determined that Mr Mayhew contracted post traumatic stress disorder arising out of his employment with the Department. The compensation is subject to periodic review.

I do not propose to canvass any of the details surrounding the granting of the claim. Clearly it arises from the impact on Mr Mayhew of the colour TV affair of which the interviews were one consequence.
The senior officers concerned have made statutory declarations attesting that the reports by them referred to by Mr Mahony and tabled in the Parliament last year are true records.
In all the circumstances, I have concluded that no worthwhile purpose would be served by the Government pursuing this particular matter any further.
Future action
I do not propose to deal with each of Mr Mahony's 43 recommendations. However, for the information of Honourable Senators I propose to table the Government's response to each of the recommendations.

I said earlier that the Government accepted the very large majority of the recommendations. The only exceptions, in addition to the matters relating to the search of suspected persons, which I have dealt with, are Recommendations 1, 5, 23 and 33.
The reasons for non-acceptance or qualified acceptance of these recommendations are set out in the response. None of these matters, in the Government's view, are major issues.
I have instructed the Department to report to me progressively on the implementation of the recommendations contained in the Report.
In Opposition we were extremely critical of the actions of the former ministers for Health and for Business and Consumer Affairs, and rightly so, over the matter of the colour TV affair.

We have before us now a Report produced by an independent person which looks to the future. Mr Mahony has conducted a thorough and wide ranging review within his terms of reference of Customs administration and procedures in New South Wales. He has made a number of recommendations covering many aspects of the Customs administration, most of which the Government has accepted. A number of those recommendations will impact nationally, not just in New South Wales. Mr Mahony is to be commended for the way he has tackled the task given him and I wish to express the Government's thanks for his efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now have another one. We now have a Customs administration-led recovery to get Australia back to work.
—You started that one.

—Yes, but the Government finished it. We were recovering. As one looks through the rest of this legislation one realises all the Bills are for the convenience of those of us who sit here. The Constitution Alteration ( Simultaneous Elections) Bill is the Bill that interests me. I was against it, then I was for it, and now I do not really give a tinker's so and so about it. But I said when Senator Evans withdrew his fixed-term Bill that really, to this moment, I cannot understand how one could be ardently in favour of fixed terms one moment and ardently in favour of simultaneous elections the next moment. Nor , by the same process of reasoning, can I understand how one could be bitterly opposed to both because I think in many ways they are totally opposed to each other. But some are for both and some are opposed to both. This Parliament is a fascinating place. Whilst one can understand the argument, in principle, that these terrible Prime Ministers ought not to be able to go out and rape the electorate whenever they feel like it by having elections when they feel like it , what do simultaneous elections do but, in fact, give a Prime Minister the capacity to have an election once a week if he likes, taking out the House of Representatives and taking out half the Senate as well? That does not worry me particularly because I have enormous faith in the common sense of the Australian electorate. Any Prime Minister who tries to do that too often will end up where he deserves. I am not really fussed about this Bill, but it really is a means of making things easier for the government of the day. It will not do much good for any of the one million unemployed outside that the Australian Labor Party is supposed to ache about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1983 is great for us. It has been propounded, of course, as something that will be of great benefit to the electorate. Not much is said of course, about its great benefit to us. We are all going to do a little bit better. Good Lord, if we get four-year terms in the other place and eight-year terms here it will be almost as good as being either a tenured academic or a tenured public servant-not quite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a shonky lawyer.

—Shonky lawyers do not last very long. Shonky lawyers tend to end up where they do end up, do not worry about that. It is the lazy, loafing, tenured academics who are never caught up with who are the real problem. So let us not have over-much talk about shonky lawyers. I suppose it takes one to recognise one.

SPEECH.PARA: Then one comes to the next piece of legislation, the Constitution Alteration ( Inter-change of Powers) Bill. There is a lot in that, of course! I imagine John Citizen is out there saying: 'Well really, why are all these politicians getting together to swap the powers under the Constitution without consulting me through a referendum? What is in it for me?'

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be a saving of $15m. I think this is how he will think on 25 February.

—We will be making life cozy for ourselves. I suppose it suits the present Hawke Labor Government to allow Mr Wran and now Mr Cain to impose a sales tax on people's consumer goods to fund their deficits so that they can give more money to striking school teachers, so I suppose the inter-change of powers must be a good thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that none of my electors will stay awake at night worrying about whether the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill passes or not. The High Court of Australia may, but that does not fuss me over much either. Lawyers, of course, get enormously excited, but then lawyers do have a capacity for getting excited about trivia. If we did not, we would not have all these Bills before us. The Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill really is exciting! The Constitution Alteration ( Electors' Initiative) Bill is really not worth talking about. Electors' initiative-why not put it down as the Australian Democrats initiative to expose it for the odd-ball proposition that it really is? We have this rag-bag, mish- mash of trivia which will be enormously expensive-$10m, $15m or $20m. Yesterday, Senator Gietzelt was in this place talking about working something in an enormous attempt to save $1m a year from doctors who treat veterans. He said the Government would save $1.8m a year, I think-some vast sum of money-because doctors were getting an extra 60c a time for treating veterans, but next day spending $10m, $15m or $20m on a referendum is all right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet they are spending $3m on a royal commission into agent orange.

—Oh, that does not matter! The Government says: 'Anything that involves trivia, let's spend money on'. I suppose what we are having is really a trivia-led recovery in this country. Really, that is all we have had in legislation this year. It is no use the Prime Minsiter (Mr Hawke) going out, putting on his nasal ocker accent and yelling 'My fellow Australians' in shades of former Senator Wright. I suppose that he is a bit like Nero-or was it Caligula?-and working on the principle of giving everybody bread and circuses. The problem is that people get bored with the circus in the end and they start wanting some bread. What I am really saying is that this is really all about the circus. Where is the bread? The Labor Government has been in office since 5 March. A million unemployed will be voting on 25 February, voting for the circus to continue, but there will be no bread for them. It is very easy for us. I hope those fellows opposite have the greatest time of their lives over the next couple of months, going around all their unions, all their Labor leagues, all their branches, and saying: 'Fellows, you've gotta get out and work and work and work because we have to get this trivia carried. Don't worry, fellows, about being unemployed-that's too hard. Let's just get on with this sort of stuff because, after all, government really is too hard'.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are my views on what is alleged to be a package of constitutional amendments over which all honourable senators have agonised here day after day. I have a feeling that those 10 million electors out there are a damn sight smarter than all of us sitting in this place, that they will recognise this legislation for what it is and in the polling booths on that day they will vote according to how they feel about the issues. I wish Government senators joy in their attempt to whip up enthusiasm for the referendum. I intend neither to campaign for it nor to campaign against it. I will give the electors the right to make up their own minds. I suspect they will recognise the referendum for what it really is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I have to follow Senator Withers in this debate. He is always a hard act to follow. I have said before in this place that constitutional reformers ought to have a look at some of the things that Woodrow Wilson had to say. I have quoted one particular remark from Woodrow Wilson which I intend to quote again:

SPEECH.PARA: Liberty has never come from the Government . . . the history of liberty is the history of the limitation of governmental power, not the increase of it.

I presume that now that the Australian Labor Party is in government the back benchers of the ALP are beginning to understand the significance of that-that liberty never comes from the government. The history of liberty in our democratic institutions has always been the limitation of the power of governments as Woodrow Wilson said, not the increase of power. Of course, the major proposals being put forward in this constitutional package are endeavours to increase the powers of the Government. I know that ALP back benchers do not see their Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, as being devious. I know they do not think he might misuse any of the powers that he has. I know they feel quite sure that if he is given the power of calling a simultaneous election-in other words, forcing the Senate to go out whenever he feels like having an election for the House of Representatives-he will not misuse that power in any way, but they may have some doubts about some future Liberal Prime Minister misusing the power. Whatever their views on the subject let me say quite bluntly, Mr Deputy President, that I am suspicious that he might misuse the power at some stage in the future, and accordingly I shall not be supporting the proposal that he get that power. Unlike Senator Withers, I shall be doing my best to make sure that the people of Australia do not give him that power.

There is, Mr Deputy President, thanks to you, one proposal which in fact would limit the governmental power. That is your proposal to provide that a dissolution of both Houses of the Parliament shall not take place by reason that the Senate has twice rejected, failed to pass or unacceptably amended a proposed law if more than three months has elapsed after the Senate so treated that proposed law. In all of this package that is the only proposal which I see in any way assisting the Parliament against the increasing power of the Executive. Let me draw the attention of honourable senators to another constitutional authority to which they should give great attention, and that is a speech by Professor G. S. Reid, delivered in 1979, which won the George Watson essay prize , entitled: 'The Changing Political Framework'. Professor Reid's findings ultimately were:
. . . that the elected Parliament is a weak and weakening institution;
He went on to say:
and that the Executive Government is the principal beneficiary of the Parliament 's decline--

(Quorum formed) I was drawing the attention of the Senate to a quotation by Professor Reid when Senator Colston called a quorum in order to bring his colleagues into the chamber. I hope they stay here and listen to the various points that I intend to make in relation to this constitutional package. As I was saying, Madam Acting Deputy President, Professor Reid explained these findings in his speech. He said:
. . . that the elected Parliament is a weak and weakening institution; and that the Executive Government is the principal beneficiary of the Parliament's decline;

That, of course, is so very true. For decades the Executive Government of this country has been gaining strength and the Parliament has been getting weaker and weaker. That is clearly evident now in the House of Representatives where if one member of that chamber crosses the floor it becomes national headlines-a member of the House of Representatives actually had the temerity to vote against his colleagues-even if only on a point of order or some sort of insignificant vote. The party system has destroyed the House of Representatives as a House of Parliament. It is now simply a House of the Executive and the alternative Executive government of the day. So I intend to support very strongly Senator Hamer's proposal which will at least give this chamber some power to stand up to the Executive Government and to reject Bills. If the Executive Government then wants to take the Senate to the people, that is as it may very well be, but at least it will have to do so within a very short period-three months-instead of being able to put the Bill into a stockpile and take the Senate to the people some twelve months or so later over its action in regard to some piece of legislation. Unfortunately, I have heard that the ALP is not prepared to allow that matter to go before the people of Australia. I say strongly to the backbench members of the ALP that that is a very clear indication of the desire of their Executive once again to manipulate the Parliament to the benefit of the Executive Government. Whilst they may not think that their Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Executive Government will in any way misuse that power, they may think it will be used at some stage in the future to the detriment of their party.

Let me go on to the other matter which is of great importance and that is the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill. When I first heard about this idea of having the High Court of Australia giving advisory opinions I thought: 'Yes, that sounds like a good idea', but as soon as one starts to reflect as to what it is all about, we see that there are a number of things wrong with it. The first is that once again we would take power away from the Parliament; we now start to ask the High Court to adopt some sort of role which is midway between a judicial body and a legislative body because it will be able to express views as to what the law would be if certain things were to happen. That is not the traditional role of the courts in Australia or those operating under the British system. But further, Madam Acting Deputy President, the point is that governments will be able to use this power to shorten or forestall debate in the Parliament. A government will be able to come into the Parliament and say: 'The High Court has already considered this and has said this, this and this. Therefore what you are saying in the Parliament is irrelevant'. The truth of the matter is that in Canada, where this power exists, experience has shown that legislation has been brought in as a result of advisory opinions, has been acted on by the people of the country for many years and then subsequently has been challenged and found to be invalid by the court of that land.

The other thing that has happened in countries such as Canada is that the judges have involved themselves in exercises in semantics. In other words, when they are asked for an advisory opinion, instead of saying bluntly what a judgment might very well be, as they have to when they are confronted with a case such as the Tasmanian dam case-which is well known to most of us-they have had to come out with a judgment and say what the law is. They are inclined to roam on about what it might mean and what words could mean and generally end up not providing anything of any value to the Parliament or indeed to the Government. Because of this I understand that in Canada the power has not been used now for some decades. Of course, the Government will be the one that will be using this power and so it will be able to frame questions which might be of some advantage to it if it gets to that stage. Finally, the truth of the matter is that the High Court judges have indicated that they do not want the power because they recognise the difficulty of trying to say what the law might very well be when the circumstances are vague and they do not have an actual set of facts before them. I shall not support the proposal in that Bill when it comes before the Parliament or before the people.

There are other matters to which I should refer fairly briefly. I see some problems with the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill. A party or a coalition of parties which gets into office in any of the States or the Commonwealth could perhaps change the Constitution to its own benefit without ever having to go before the people of Australia. On my reading of the Bill, when a change of government occurs in a State or in the Federal sphere the change introduced as a result of that interchange of powers could be revoked anyway so that is probably not such a bad proposal.

The next Bill is the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill. To give senators a term of eight years causes me great concern. I would be totally opposed to it, but I do not see any way out if we are to give members of the House of Representatives a term of four years. Unfortunately, it looks as if we will have to give senators eight years on that basis. I must say that I am opposed to senators having an eight-year term, but there is no doubt that governments in this country have had difficulty in bringing in difficult legislation during a term of only three years. Again, this Bill is designed to assist the Parliament or the Parliamentarians; it is designed to assist the executive government. It is not designed to assist executive governments to make difficult decisions and to enforce them without having to worry about facing the people at the time when it brings them in.

I now refer to the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill. It always fascinates me that people who claim to be conservationists and want to keep old buildings do not want to keep the old sections of the Constitution; they want to tidy them up and throw them out. They say: 'Let's get rid of the old sections of the Constitution. We do not want the people to know what was put in there at the turn of the century. We must tidy it up'. I cannot really oppose that legislation, but fancy the Government bringing in such a proposal and putting it before the people of Australia, making them go to all that trouble in order to tidy up the Constitution, whatever that might mean. However, I cannot really oppose it, I suppose.

I thoroughly support what Senator Withers had to say about the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill introduced by Senator Mason. The Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill, introduced by Senator Macklin, deals with breaking the nexus. It fascinates me that people keep saying that the nexus is not important. But if we break the nexus two consequences will result. It is inevitable that the House of Representatives will grow. Every time some sort of count is held its members will say: 'Oh, we need an extra three or four seats in the House of Representatives', or 'We need another half dozen members in the House of Representatives'. In due course we will end up with 180 members in the House of Representatives-that is for sure-while 64 senators keep struggling to try to do the work of this chamber. That, I believe, is an inevitable consequence of breaking the nexus.

Another thing about the nexus is that people tend to forget that it may very well be absolutely vital if a conjoint vote of both Houses is necessary following a double dissolution.
