I recognise that if the Senate blocks Supply and there is a double dissolution on some vital matter and if the Government or, perhaps, the Opposition is returned with an enormous majority, the vote will not count. But what happens if one of the parties is returned with a majority of one or two members in the House of Representatives and the Opposition is returned in the Senate with a majority of one or two senators? An absolutely vital vote will be taken conjointly, but people keep saying that the nexus is not important. If the people of this country are so finely split that they vote along the lines that I have indicated, of course the nexus is important. It is the nexus which is proposed to be broken in this Bill. On reflection, I have decided to oppose it. I shall support the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill, put forward by Senator Peter Rae. I think that I have now covered all of the proposals which are before the chamber in this constitutional package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on these Constitution alteration Bills, because I believe the position has been covered quite adequately by most of the speakers. I wish to declare my position and to make one or two observations. Earlier this year I had the opportunity to spend time doing some reading. I found that it was very interesting to read the considerations of the founding fathers of the country. I would certainly recommend such reading to anybody else, particularly to the Government members who believe that what they are doing is in accordance with the wishes of the unbiased people who were looking at the Constitution then.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution of this country was put together by-it is a word that I shudder a little to use-consensus. It was a genuine-probably the most genuine- consensus document. It was not put together by people who were party politically motivated in the process. They were trying to get a document which would embrace all the people of Australia, all the States and all the considerations. I have a quote from one of the books which I read. I think it is well worth while. It was put together at some time during the 1890s. It states:

. . . in the fullness of time we could expect that representatives of the more populous States could be expected to produce proposals which they would claim would be beneficial to all, but which clearly must be to the detriment of the less populous States.

How little things have changed! I have borne that statement in mind as I have looked over the various proposals which we are asked to consider. Our founding fathers tried to put together a Constitution which would be fair to all individuals and the States and one which would respect every individual's position. At this stage I ask: Do the proposals we have before us cover those areas now? Do they maintain the Constitution in that way? Clearly the answer is no. These proposals fail in a whole range of different issues.

I regard the whole package as absolute nonsense and I think it is a surprising show of the Government's priorities. I will spare the Senate the repetition of going through most of the reasons because I think they have been quite adequately covered, but I will declare my stand on the Constitution Alteration ( Simultaneous Elections) Bill. I will oppose that, because we only have to look back to find that in the vast majority of cases elections have been simultaneous . The provision already exists for simultaneous elections. We do not need to trump up another reason which will make elections more beneficial for the Government and less advantageous for the electors. The project clearly is bogus. I could go along with the proposal in the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill. I believe that a four-year term for members of the House of Representatives is reasonable. But there is no way that I can go along with the suggestion that an eight-year term for senators is reasonable. I think that any member of this chamber who tries to sell himself in the community and get support for an eight-year term will have a job in front of him. Accordingly, I have no choice but to vote against that Bill. I think the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill proposed by Senator Macklin, has been covered very adequately by some of my colleagues. I agree with everything they have said and I support their move to throw it out.

I believe there would probably be no better way to try to destroy the Parliament than by the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill, which I will oppose. If the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill is a matter of such importance that we need to take it to the people of Australia, I am absolutely appalled at how little we have in front of us. I believe that history should be a compulsory subject for everybody to avoid consideration of sheer absolute trivia. I believe that those great designers of the brand new future would be well advised to look back over their shoulders because I think that in most cupboards there are people far more clever and far more considerate than we are.

The Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill produces a whole range of potential risks to a federal system. We have only to consider what would happen if all the States and Canberra lined up. Whether by collusion or standover, the result could be much the same. I see that there could be all sorts of potential problems with that proposal. I cannot see that the benefits would outweigh those problems, therefore I will oppose that Bill.

The Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill I leave largely to the lawyers but, as we heard in this chamber yesterday and today, there is absolutely no weight of evidence that could support the proposition that the Bill is desirable. It may work, it may not. But there is certainly not enough evidence to indicate that it is worthwhile and I oppose this Bill also. It is a matter of where we stand on these matters. I find that I have to look at myself and the rest of us here reasonably objectively. Are we the people to make this sort of judgment? Clearly we are not, because there are not 64 more biased people in this regard than us. We are totally prejudiced by our own ends. We are so of necessity. We live with ourselves fairly closely and we all see our own points of view fairly readily. But I do not accept that the Government should produce these sorts of propositions just for the comfort and convenience of members of parliament. The electorate is far more conservative and it deserves far more respect. These proposals cannot be justified in view of the time and cost involved. I wish to make it adequately clear that I will be voting to support the electors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my remarks on the Constitution alteration Bills I say that I am one who has never objected to the population of Australia being asked what it thinks about certain matters. But as an engineer I am also one who realises that one engineering principle is that you do not fix something until it is broken. I believe that the system that we have within Australia at the moment is working fairly well, so I ask: Why change it? If it is not broken do not fix it. But with these Bills we see the Government trying to fix many things that are not broken. I believe that when the votes are taken we will see before the people of Australia virtually a record number of referendums presented. Many of the suggestions that the Government wishes to put before the people are those that will either damage the Senate, particularly as regards some of the smaller States, or do what Senator Withers said a few moments ago, that is, do nothing to help the economic situation but just make life easier for politicians. That, in itself, I believe, is almost sufficient reason to oppose the holding of a referendum on the proposed changes to the Constitution. The people of Australia do not want life made easier for their politicians in any way. A letter I received stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We valued the Senate from 1972 to 1975 . . . Where is the wisdom in destroying its effectiveness?
In December 1975 the electorate overwhelmingly endorsed the Senate in the exercise of its ultimate power. That election resulted in the greatest-ever majority in the Commonwealth Parliament.
Is all that to be forgotten, . . .? Are we so careless that we abandon ourselves and our future to the mercy of our enemies?

I think that some of the proposals for referendums that we are discussing as time went on would, in fact, do that. I ask also why we are rushing these Bills. I have said before that rushed legislation is often bad legislation. I believe that the Government will regret the introduction of these Bills. Already, the Government has had to alter one Bill and one has been withdrawn. If we look back in history we remember that Mr Whitlam tried this idea of having referendums to keep himself in power and change the political situation of this country. I believe the defeat of his referendum Bills helped start his downhill slide. Mr Hawke has now been persuaded to do the same thing. I believe that he will regret it and that he is likely to end up the same way as Mr Whitlam.

The Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill has been before us previously. I was against it on those occasions because it damages the Senate protection of the smaller States. Last time it was being discussed I heard one Labor Party senator say to another, 'This is the first step in the abolition of the Senate'. Another said, 'About time too'. I think we know the Labor Party attitude to these Bills. We have to remember that the simultaneous elections Bill will not necessarily reduce the number of elections. It could well increase them. It may be that that is a good thing. I am one of those strange people who feel that people, the people of Tasmania at any rate, like elections. I believe they like to be involved in the political process and to have the opportunity to pass judgment on the members of this place. The late Senator Greenwood in March 1974 in relation to this matter said:

. . . there is a tediousness, a tiresomeness and a sense of futility occasionally expressed when people must vote. I know the arguments which are raised. One year there is a House of Representatives election, another year there is a Senate election, and in between there is an election for possibly both Houses of a State Parliament. But if one examines that, why should there not be those elections? If one reflects upon why those elections are held, why ought not the justification to be readily expressed and readily accepted and why ought we not to say that this is the means by which we govern ourselves?
I would say that an end should be put to the idea that there are too many elections.

The question is whether we really need a referendum for the purpose of arranging simultaneous elections between the House of Representatives and the Senate. The answer is clearly no. The Prime Minister could easily decide, if he wanted to, to arrange a Senate election at the same time as a House of Representatives election instead of spending the mega-bucks that honourable senators know it will cost to have this referendum, particularly when it is remembered-this is something which perhaps not many people recognise-that the founding fathers referred to the desirability of holding separate elections. If honourable senators refer to the constitutional debates of the late 1800s they will find that that is true. On 13 March 1974 Senator Greenwood, referring to Mr Whitlam, said:

The Prime Minister, as I have indicated, has used the argument that there are too many elections as the sole justification for his proposal. He believes that we should bring into line the elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate. He postulates as a sound principle that every 3 years there should be a House of Representatives election and that at the same time-at the same election -there should be an election for that half of the Senate for which an election is required at that time. I simply say that if that be the principle and if that be the objective-certainly it has been the general position over the greater part of our history-it is very easy for the Prime Minister to achieve that objective without having to resort to a referendum.

In the Sydney Morning Herald at about the same time, in 1977, there was a long article relating to the New South Wales Legislative Assembly. I should like to quote a little from what was said then because it still applies today. The article said:

All who place some store in maintaining individual freedom within the framework of organised society cannot doubt the value of a second Chamber. Frustrating and exasperating thought it often is, its value lies primarily in its being an effective brake to the legislative ambitions of the popularly elected Chamber, in New South Wales the Legislative Assembly.

Its other equally important role is to review, to consider and often to suggest improvements to legislation sometimes sent to the Council hastily by the Assembly in answer to some spectacular election pledge . . . or sent to it as a result of the advocacy of some dominant member of the ministry whose pet theme it is.

I wonder whose pet theme these referendums are. That kind of thing could and does happen in this Federal Parliament. I hope that honourable senators will remember it when they are campaigning against these referendums. Anything that reduces the effectiveness of the Senate is something of which I cannot be a part .
The No case in 1974 said:

This referendum will make the Senate the rubber-stamp of a socialist, centralist Labor Government. The Government is being deceitful-the question you will vote on does not explain the real proposed law.
I do not think that anything has changed since then. It also said:
Canberra asks you to approve a law to alter the constitution 'so as to ensure that Senate elections are held at the same time as House of Representatives elections'.

But the Senate is not an arm of the House of Representatives. Both are established under the Constitution as equal, independent House of Parliament with differing roles. The Senate is the only institution in Australia able to be a barrier to the arbitrary misuse of power by a Prime Minister or his cabinet.
That applies no matter which party is in office. Towards the end of the pamphlet , it said:

The present system is that Senators are elected for a six-year term. It is a ' staggered' election system with half of the Senate coming up for election every three years. The statutory six-year term is one of the strengths from which a Senator derives his independence.
Without Senator independence the casualty would be democracy.

That gives my attitude toward simultaneous elections. I believe that all those things still apply. I would refer those interested in this matter to speeches made earlier that have dealt with other areas of simultaneous elections and the dangers of them. For a small State they are of no advantage. They are of no advantage to the people of this country. They do nothing except expose the people to the trivia that this Government is bringing before us.

All that the second Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill does is to make life easier for Government members and for senators. I have to advise Senator Withers that I had made my copious notes about that before I heard him speak this morning. The Bill certainly does not do anything to help any member of the public. I repeat: The public does not want things made easier for politicians. I admit that the four-year term is used in many places, but I have not yet heard of any eight-year terms. There may be some; I have not heard of any. In the United States of America the President is elected for four years and the senators are elected for four years. I was talking to an American yesterday, who said 'You certainly would not get away with the idea of giving members of parliament in the USA an eight-year term'. I am not sure about the House of Representatives term in the United States. I think that it is two years ; there are elections every couple of years, I think.

I would have to be against an eight-year term. It would make life easy for some of us, although not many of us in this place have had even one six-year term. I think that the President of the Senate is the only person who has had a six-year term, due to the double dissolution elections we have had over the last few years. I am against the length of term. If some provision could be made for the House of Representatives to have a four-year term, and somehow for senators too, maybe I would go along with it; but even then I am not sure that it would do anything but make life easier for the Executive Government. If the Government gets enshrined in power in this ivory towered Canberra area for four years, I would hate to think what would happen.

I shall not deal with the Bills in order. I talk now about the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill. My opinions are very similar to those stated by Mr Knox, from Queensland, in his speeches at the Australian Constitutional Convention in Perth in 1978, and to those of Mr Porter , reported at page 35 of the report. They made some statements, Mr Deputy President, and I seek leave to incorporate those in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The extracts read as follows-

Mr KNOX (Queensland): There may well be many people in this country who think that the seeking of advisory opinions from the High Court would be similar to that procedure which exists in relation to the Privy Council. Of course, those of us who have had some experience know that the situation is quite different. The important question is, what is the status of these opinions. Indeed, as far as the opinions of the High Court would be concerned their status could be very powerful indeed. I would imagine that once these were approved then the work of the High Court would increase enormously, because there would be all sorts of avenues to take advantage of to seek these advisory opinions.

Is this the way we want to see this country run, by having a High Court give its referee decisions before having the opportunity to debate them in the forums provided by this country in the various States of the Commonwealth? Is this the way which we believe the Parliaments ought to operate, to have the High Court stand between the Parliaments and the people? That is the way in which this will tend to go should it be approved.

While the seeking of advisory opinions may seem rather academic to lawyers, to the parliamentarians there should be a different attitude. The legislatures of this country should be allowed to try to make the changes that they think are desirable, even flying in the face of opinions they might have from various sources that they might not be successful. Indeed, it would be a very bad and sad day for the various legislatures if the opinions from the High Court were thrust between them and those who wanted to see changes made in the legislation.

Mr PORTER (Queensland): I find myself reluctant at the best of times to accept determinations from an advisory jurisdiction. It is difficult enough for an ordinary person like myself to accept some political judgments in any case, but to have determinations of tremendous import based on an assumption of facts, applying not only to State enactments but also to proposed State enactments, makes me feel this is a proposition which in short order would label Australia as a very odd sort of country indeed.
I do not think there is much place in our Federal system, in terms of our political and judicial traditions, for this kind of proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Also, Mr Deputy President, I should like to incorporate in Hansard what Mr Doumany of Queensland said, as reported at pages 13 and 14 of the report of the Australian Constitutional Convention, on Wednesday, 27 April this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The extract read as follows-

Mr DOUMANY (Queensland): The proposal which is before the Convention, despite its complexity of drafting, in essence involves a simple proposition, that is, should the High Court of Australia be vested with power to render advisory opinions? Notwithstanding the views which are expressed in the Fourth Report of Standing Committee D and notwithstanding any views which the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs might have expressed, I am opposed to the proposition. Should this proposition succeed and should the necessary constitutional amendments be made, then this Convention will be making a fundamental attack upon the image and the necessity for non-partisanship and independence in the High Court of Australia.

As everyone at this Convention would be aware, we are moving towards the position where the High Court of Australia will become the final court of appeal of all matters arising in the Australian judicial system. If the High Court is to be respected, then it must be seen to be an impartial and non-partisan body. Unfortunately, if this proposal advances, there is a real danger that this will not be the case. Considerable disquiet has already been expressed over some decisions of the High Court where, through judicial interpretation, the balance of legislative, executive and indeed judicial powers struck by the founding fathers at federation, has been disturbed generally in favour of greater powers for the Commonwealth and lesser powers for the States.

More and more the personal and political philosophies of potential appointees to the High Court are a matter of public debate and discussion. As a supporter of the principle that the Judiciary should be politically neutral, I find this tendency abhorrent and I would dread to think that we would ever get ourselves in this country in the situation as exists in the United States of America in relation to the appointments to the Supreme Court where the personal lives of potential Supreme Court appointees are examined minutely in the public gaze prior to an appointment being made. If for no other reason alone, I am opposed to the politicising of the High Court which will spring from giving advisory opinions. However, there are many other substantial reasons why this proposal should be opposed. Let me outline just a few of these.

First, advisory opinions are of necessity expressed in general terms and not related to specific situations. Our whole judicial tradition is directed towards examining the legality of specific situations. The Judiciary is now, in effect, being asked to act as legislators-a move against the separation of powers inherent in our system.

Secondly, because our judicial system considers matters on a relatively narrow frame, questions of fact do influence the decisions which are made. How then is a court supposed to give authoritative pronouncements on circumstances which will be nothing more than the speculations of the persons going before the court ?

Thirdly, sufficient mechanisms already exist for challenges to the constitutional validity of specific Acts to be made. These legal challenges, however, are only made after the necessary political decisions have been made. It can be argued that this proposal is nothing more than an attempt to use the law to overcome an inability to succeed in political arguments.

Fourthly, from a cynical point of view, the proposal can be regarded as nothing more than an attempt to place greater powers in the hands of the Commonwealth Government by encouraging the High Court to write wide-ranging general advisory opinions. This view is not necessarily all that cynical if one has regard to the proposals in section 77A (1) (d). The suggestion that the Executive Government would have an ability to obtain a High Court ruling on the legality of any proposed treaty prior to even signing the treaty, let alone ratifying it, and let alone legislating on it, fills me with complete horror.

Fifthly, the adoption of this principle would also require the High Court to develop new rules of stare decisis and precedent, or are we to adopt a new rule to see if the High Court gives a general advisory opinion in favour of a particular action, then for ever and a day no challenge can be mounted against Commonwealth activity? This, of course, would be ludicrous for any practical person but, nevertheless, this would seem to be inherent in the proposal.

Sixthly, the proposal also ignores the rights of interested litigants to appear to argue a particular point of view. Who is to say who will be affected by a particular advisory opinion by the High Court? Yet from the proposal, the only persons likely to appear when advisory matters are argued will be Governments, both Commonwealth and State. One can readily anticipate the High Court will be encouraged to make pronouncements upon matters which will be of vital concern to many interested parties, but that these parties will only become aware of their rights being affected after the decision is made. Where, therefore, is there any justice in that proposal?

Seventhly, I note already that the proposal suggests that States should have a right of approaching the High Court for advisory opinions. It would strike me that even if you accept the principle of advisory opinions, the last thing the States would do would be to seek to approach the High Court directly for an opinion for, in doing so, they would be casting grave aspersions on the legal abilities of their Supreme Court, particularly of their Full Courts. From this point of view, the proposal can be looked at as a further attempt to downgrade the judicial standing of State Supreme Courts.

Finally, I make the point as to just exactly what the Commonwealth is trying to achieve with this proposal. The Commonwealth already has available to it the best legal advisers in Australia that money can buy. Apparently, these advisers are no longer considered to be able to render appropriate advice to the Commonwealth about actions which it proposes to undertake. Apparently the judges of the High Court are now also to be converted into Commonwealth legal advisers as well.

The High Court should remain independent and impartial, carrying out its duties of interpreting the Commonwealth Constitution and the laws of the land in a way that will ensure that all parties not only do, but believe they do, obtain justice when they appear before the court.

This whole proposal, if adopted, will ensure that the High Court of Australia will descend into the area of political contest. It will ensure that the members of the High Court will become participants in the political process. If you desire to ensure that this does not occur, then I would urge this Convention to reject this whole proposal completely. If, however, this motion is to be accepted than let us honestly reform the whole basis on which the High Court currently operates, particularly the way in which vacancies are filled, for at the moment there are more than a few grounds for believing that current selection methods do favour the Commonwealth over the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Briefly dealing with the other Bills, I come to the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill. The American to whom I was talking yesterday used, I think, these words: 'If that were passed and it enabled a sales tax to be established in the States'-which I believe it would--
—Hardly.
—Would that not be one of the possibilities?
—Not flowing automatically.
—Would it be a possibility?
—It would then be possible for the States to do it. It would be possible to do all sorts of things.
—Thank you. That is all I asked. Did I not say 'one of the possibilities would be'?
—No, you said that that would flow from it, but that would require separate legislation.

—No, I did not. If Senator Evans checks Hansard tomorrow, he will find that I said that it could be a possibility. The American to whom I was talking said that, if that were the case, it would be a horrible idea. He said that the sales tax area is one in which States in the United States find it easiest to raise revenue; to increase their sales taxes on general sales and to raise revenue. I would have to be against that purely on that ground. When Senator Withers was talking about the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill, he said that he could not get very excited about it; I cannot get very excited about it either.
—Who can?

—Who can, indeed; no one, I think. It is not a necessary thing. What I am trying to show is that hardly any of these referendums are required. We come next to the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. I would have to be against that. I would be for the idea of the Bill proposed by Senator Peter Rae, the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill, but unfortunately I have heard that it will not get through. We come next to the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill. Mention has been made of small States and of breaking the nexus. I feel that any senator from a small State who ties himself to the idea of breaking the nexus is avoiding his duty. Let me read to the Senate what Senator Sir John Carrick said in June 1975. It relates to another referendum but it certainly applies to this breaking of the nexus particularly so far as senators from small States are concerned. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any senator coming from one of the small States who ties himself basically to this device is, indeed, in dereliction of his duty to the States . . . the simple situation is that the Australian Constitution was formed on the basis that the less populous States-Tasmania, Western Australia, South Australia in particular, and Queensland-would only come into a Commonwealth if there were a Senate and if the Constitution of that Senate were as provided in the Australian Constitution.
Any senator who gets up and seeks to destroy the quality of the Senate in this way ought to be defeated in his own State.

He did not say that in relation to the breaking of the nexus but certainly any senator from a small State who supported that breaking of the nexus would be lowering the effectiveness of that State's influence in the Commonwealth. As Senator Lewis said, if there were a breaking of the nexus we would certainly see a huge increase over a few years in the number of members in the House of Representatives, which is something I am sure, again, that members of the public would love to see! They would love to see more members of parliament! The Senate would still be stuck with 64 members. I am not saying that the Senate should be increased either. I do not believe at the moment that the size of either House of Parliament should be increased but certainly a breaking of the nexus would allow the people from Melbourne and Sydney to have an overwhelming influence, and one that I am certain the people of Tasmania would not want them to have. I agree with the philosophy behind the Constitution. Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill. Holding a double dissolution within a reasonable time is a very sensible provision, and I agree with it.

Finally, I do agree with Senator Withers's attitude to these referendums. I am certain that the people of Australia, and the people of Tasmania particularly, will reject the ideas that are likely to be passed by the Senate and the other House. Let it be clear that if I am against these referendums then I will be campaigning against them. Most of those that are likely to suceed would disadvantage Tasmania and I will be voting and working against them. I am suspicious of them particularly when I see the politicians from all sides getting together. Usually the only time they do that is when they are voting for an increase in parliamentary salaries. We all know the way the public accepts those, and I think the public will treat these proposals in the same way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise at this late stage of the debate not so much to discuss the Bills in detail, as they have been dealt with very competently by the Australian Democrats' spokesman, Senator Macklin, but to reply and to make some points in regard to my private member's Bill; that is, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill, which is now being debated cognately at this second reading stage. That Bill provides that where 250,000 or more people sign a petition to either House of this Parliament, that matter will be put to a referendum at a set time each year. Of course, this is a well established procedure. It has been for many years in other parts of the world, in more advanced and modern democracies than ours.

SPEECH.PARA: An important instance of the use of electors' initiative which I instance at this stage is the system of civil defence in Switzerland. I have made the point in the Senate many times over the years that we have a notorious situation whereby two governments have done nothing to protect Australian people against nuclear attack, and there are still no signs of anything being done, even though we concede and agree that the risks are becoming greater. As far as the Parliament is concerned, it will have its refuge, I have no doubt. It is a matter of record that such a refuge will be built. But as far as the people of Australia are concerned, they can stay outside and die. Switzerland has the best system of civil defence in the world, a system on which one-quarter of its defence budget is spent. It has provided the best protection in the world against nuclear attack for its people, and that is generally conceded. That protection, Mr Deputy President, was introduced not by the Swiss Parliament but by a citizens' initiative in 1962. It is a classic case of a modern, advanced society acting in its own interests, independently and above and beyond the parliament which had neglected those interests, as this Parliament neglects the basic interests of this country so shamefully.

It is for that reason that I sponsor this Bill and go on with it, because I give notice now that if this Bill is defeated then as soon as possible it will be back on the Notice Paper and it will stay on the Notice Paper for as long as there is an Australian Democrat in this Parliament. Meanwhile, I commend honourable senators to take this matter a little more seriously than has been the case in debate so far. Honourable senators so far have shown a degree of ill -information about the issues in this Bill, which appals me, especially in regard to the discussion on Proposition 13 in California-I will deal with that more later-which indicates to me that they have not even done their reading or studied the background before making their remarks on that issue.

I have read through previous debates on my Bill in Hansard and, following yesterday's debate, I feel I should answer some criticisms before I proceed further. Senator Durack, on behalf of the Opposition, said that the Opposition would oppose my Bill because it would lead to fundamental change and is contrary to our system of parliament. I absolutely agree with Senator Durack. I am happy he sees the Bill in that light, as that is its basic strength. As I have said before in this place, the present system which restricts the right to initiate law to the Parliament is an anachronism and Senator Durack's views of course rank him and his Party as anachronisms. While I am at it, I might as well include Senator Withers in that because of the irresponsible and careless remarks he has made in this place on this important issue.

The relevance of parliamentary dominance to any modern society may have been valid in the nineteenth century but it is no longer enough for a free people in the twentieth century to have the right to elect only one party or another to government; indeed, to have no real control over the legislative process beyond that. We need fundamental changes to our Constitution and to our system of parliament and we are not providing the people with that by proposing this arrogant, effete, inconsequential series of referenda which will be put to the people in February. I agree with Senator Townley that there is nothing at all in them of any significance or importance to the Australian people and, mark my words, they will see these matters in that light.

Only one thing might be put to them which will fundamentally affect their future and the future of this country as a great democracy, and that is the issue of electors' initiative. That is the only fundamental thing in this series of Bills that might have some response, which might evoke some enthusiasm from the unfortunate people of this country who have been dominated for too long by two sets of political cliques that are doing their very best to make sure that they keep that dominance. We see here a fundamental arrogance. In this Bill we are not asking that the system of electors' initiative be proposed; we are merely asking that the Australian people be given the chance to choose for themselves whether or not they want that power. I want to put it on the record clear and straight that the decision of the Senate today when it votes on this matter will be that decision. It will not be a judgment on citizens' initiative; it will not be an expression of the views of honourable senators; it will be a censorship by the members of this Parliament of the right of the Australian people to decide an important new power for themselves. We need to be very clear in our minds about that. I suppose I have spoken at hundreds of public meetings to thousands of people, on this issue over the last five years and not one of them-and some were very informed groups-did not want this power introduced and the chance to vote on it. The only opposition to it is in this Parliament and I think that is a serious matter about which honourable senators may well examine their consciences. They are usurping the right of the people to decide on something which may be of value to them and if honourable senators vote against this Bill then they will be removing that option which I believe ought to be that of the people.

Senator Missen criticised my Bill basically on the grounds that it constitutes a move from parliamentary democracy to participatory democracy, and that once a proposal is drafted it cannot be changed by the Parliament. I cannot sympathise with this prevailing fear of participatory democracy which is so apparent in this Parliament, which is old-fashioned and so out of step with what is happening in many other parts of the world. Participatory democracy would add enormously to our existing system while removing nothing. It would allow the community to decide those controversial issues which politicians now notoriously duck out on. We all know that we duck out on them. I am referring to the big issues in the community, like the legalisation of marihuana, abortion reform and all those things from which we shrink from deciding on as a parliament. We do not even like debating these issues. Let us be honest about this. It should be a matter for the community at large.

There is no suggestion that the responsibilities of Parliament should be usurped. In other countries where this provision exists, the majority of law is carried out and decided upon by members of parliament, just as it is here. But this gives a valuable safeguard to the community, especially when big issues of controversy to the community are at stake. Cost cannot be considered a problem in putting this question to a referendum. It is quite probable that in February next year at least eight questions will be put to a referendum of the Australian people. The cost of adding one more question to that list would be comparatively minuscule.

My Bill does not provide for the alteration of the wording of any proposal after signatures have been gathered but, in practice, I believe this would not be a problem. This is a point, I think, that Senator Missen took up. In order to avoid the necessity of amendment or repeal of an unworkable law through another referendum, as provided for in my Bill, those groups proposing legislation through referendum would be, I think, responsible enough before they began to gather signatures in such enormous numbers to see that the form and wording of their proposal was workable. Indeed, it is reasonable that the Bill could be amended-I have mentioned this before and I will mention it again-to provide a drafting facility for those groups. That is, of course, done in other parts of the world where the initiative operates. To my knowledge, that kind of problem has not existed in those areas. Certainly it has not existed in Switzerland, which has been the main anvil on which this method of democracy has been hammered out. It works extremely well in Switzerland. It is no accident, of course, that Switzerland is one of the world's most efficient societies, with the highest gross national product and the lowest unemployment in the world.

The other main spectre which raised its sepulchral head in criticism of my Bill is the dreaded and much lamented proposition 13 passed in California in 1978. That vote has been paraded before this chamber in an ill-informed way time and time again as proof positive of the avaricious nature of the human race in general and the disregard of voters for sensible government in particular. Honourable senators, when noting proposition 13, always neglect to mention that similar propositions have been proposed 11 times by various American States and have been rejected on eight of those occasions. Perhaps the honourable senators who raised this matter were not aware of that fact. That is quite possible.

Proposition 13 was concerned with a cut in land taxes in California at a time when the Californian Government had allowed a huge surplus of land tax to build up because it had not adjusted the rates in view of the growth of property values through inflation. Proposition 13 was a very justifiable initiative and it was carried for that reason. I was in California last year and I discussed with people its effects on California. I was informed that the effects were advantageous rather than otherwise. It is also worth noting that in 1980 another proposition which would have halved income tax-I agree that that would have been damaging-was refused by the Californian people. It was overwhelmingly defeated. Of course the Californian people were responsible enough to do that. The carrying of proposition 13 was amply justified. Later actions in other States and in California show that the people in America who use this initiative have a very responsible attitude towards it. That is a canard that has to be laid to rest.

Opposition to this Bill basically comes down to the elitist argument that the people of Australia do not know enough to decide matters for themselves. This is , of course, the hoary old argument which was presented against women's suffrage and universal suffrage. Any argument, of course, against participatory democracy must be an argument in favour of oligarchy. This is nakedly revealed as that. As I have said, to my knowledge, no honourable senator has brought forward any other argument which can hold water or be at all convincing.

The Bill has many merits, I believe. It allows matters of considerable public interest to be decided by the electorate. In so doing, of course, it creates more interest in these matters. It meets the point which Senator Townley made earlier, that people need to be involved more in politics. If honourable senators want people to be interested in more than the next long weekend, the next pay day or whether there will be tax cuts in the next Budget, if honourable senators want them to be a little more interested in politics, participatory democracy would give them a greater sense of responsibility and involvement. It would encourage more far-sighted attitudes. It would create a better educated, more politically aware society than has existed in the past. I point again to the people of Washington State, the people of California State and the people of Switzerland. All of these belong to advanced societies where the annual referenda are keenly awaited. They are keenly discussed and, on the whole, a responsible body of legislation has resulted over the years.

Lastly, I remind honourable senators once again that participatory democracy such as is provided for in this Bill does apply elsewhere in the world. There is nothing new in it. There is nothing of which to be frightened. There is nothing that is not being done successfully anywhere else in the world. It applies in Switzerland. It was granted to the Swiss people in 1892 and has operated successfully ever since. It has been adopted by 24 States of the United States of America since 1890.

I trust the Australian people. I do not believe in the philosophy of the great unwashed which members of the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have expressed so freely in this debate. I believe that the Australian people now are more educated and more politically aware than people were a generation ago. Tremendous interest in current affairs programs, politics and news, shows this to be the case. The people of Australia are ready for a greater participation in the government of the country. They want it and they want it to be effective. They feel a sense of frustration with politics because they do not have that participation. I think honourable senators will find that a lot of the criticism of politicians and a lot of the criticism of the political system goes back to this very point: We have a more aware society than we have had previously; it wants more of the action; and this Parliament, I presume from statements so far, is not prepared to allow it even to decide for itself whether it is to have that part of the action.

I suggest that that is a very serious step for honourable senators to be taking . It involves a degree of censorship of what the Australian people might do, which transcends anything else I can think of that the Senate has done in the time I have been here.

If honourable senators trust the electorate as I do they will not treat the people of the electorate as irresponsible children who do not know what is good for them; they will allow them to vote on participatory democracy in a referendum. That is possible if this Bill is passed through the Senate and House of Representatives with the approval of the Government and I would hope with the approval of the Liberal Party and the National Party. It could then take its place in the referendum to be held in February next year. Honourable senators could then campaign against it. That would be an honourable way of doing it. Let honourable senators come out in public instead of hiding behind the vote of this chamber, which obscures their view. Let the honourable senators go out then and say that they do not want it so that the people can hear arguments against it. Then let the people decide. If there is a vote against the second reading of this Bill the people of this country will know perfectly well the view of honourable senators in this place. That view is that they do not want the people of this country to have any enhancement of their democracy. They do not want the proposal considered and they are not prepared to put it to the vote. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the time constraints today I will be very brief in making my position clear, as far as that is possible, on the measures before us. I will deal with them in order. The first measure is the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1983. Such a proposal was rejected in 1974 and 1977. For all the reasons that were contained in the No case at that time, which I participated in drafting, I oppose this Bill. That saves repeating myself. It was rejected in 1974 and 1977. I believe it will be rejected again. As far as the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill is concerned, we do have a three-year parliamentary term at present. What we ought to be creating is a climate in which parliaments run for the whole of their three-year term. In the last 10 years none has run for a whole three-year term. Someone said during this debate that many people elected to this Parliament have never completed their terms. I have been elected for six years on three occasions and have served eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: Another basis for the proposal is that it would enable a government satisfactorily to follow its plan, which it presumably put to the people prior to an election. There are a couple of things wrong with that argument. One is that such plans are rarely honoured and would rarely be honoured irrespective of the term of parliament. The second problem is that many of the plans of a government when it comes to power are of a social character as well as an economic character. Some legislation which comes before this Parliament touches upon very deep matters affecting the very fabric of society. If a government chooses to opt for a program which endangers the basic fabric of our society it is important that the people are given the chance regularly to audit what the government is doing by voting it in or out of office. I believe that at a time when, generally speaking, governments attempt to engage in social engineering practices it is not appropriate to extend the point of time at which the electors, the public, the people most likely to be affected, should have their say. For that reason and for a number of other reasons I will be opposing this proposition during debate on this matter in the public arena.

The third piece of legislation before the Senate is the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill 1983. I will be voting for this Bill at the second reading stage. However, I need to have some clarification on some aspects of this proposal. I do not think it is appropriate at this stage to ask questions of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). However, as I said, I will be voting for the Bill at least at the second reading stage. Perhaps I could give the Attorney a little bit of notice and indicate that my questions relate to the effect on other States if one State chooses to transfer a power to the Commonwealth.

The Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill 1983 has been adequately canvassed in the debate. I am very strongly opposed to this proposal. This matter was considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in 1977. It has been the subject of comment by a number of people, including the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia whose comments, I believe, have been noted by other speakers in this debate. I would like to remind the Senate that in his address entitled 'the State of the Australian Judicature' on 8 July 1983 he said in respect of this proposal:
. . . in my opinion it is neither necessary nor desirable to adopt a similar procedure in Australia.
He was referring to the Canadian situation. He went on to say:
I think I am right in saying that view is shared by the other members of my Court.
He made the following significant point:

Under the proposal made by the Constitutional Convention, the Court would be required to consider questions in the abstract, and possibly before the practical implications of the legislation had come to be fully understood.

I am concerned about the situation in which we could find ourselves having regard to decisions of the High Court relating to international treaties. An executive government could utilise the High Court's time to extend the boundaries of the Constitution by seeking advisory opinions from that body in regard to proposed legislation which sought to implement certain international treaties. Obviously that, to my mind, would be an impingement on the rights of the Parliament and would make fuzzy the division of powers between the Executive , the Parliament and the judiciary. I will be voting against that Bill.

I will be supporting the fifth Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill 1983, at the second reading stage. However, I will be seeking some clarification of some of its clauses at the Committee stage. I am opposed to the sixth Bill, the Constitution Alteration ( Electors' Initiative) Bill 1982 (1983). I believe that acceptance of this proposal would be an abdication of our responsibilities as parliamentarians to protect the rights of minorities in Australia. This legislation would also open the door to the dictatorship and perhaps even the intimidation of Australians by large well organised one-issue groups. Anti-tax groups, the so-called anti-state aid groups and so on would be the first organisations to take advantage of this proposal. Such groups would attempt to utilise such legislation and by well- organised methods they would intimidate and confuse the rest of society. I suggest that we would be abdicating our responsibilities as parliamentarians to protect the rights of minorities if we allowed this to occur. I will oppose that proposition.

The seventh proposal before the Senate is the Constitution Alteration ( Appropriation Bills) Bill 1983. This piece of legislation has some merit. I will be supporting it at the second reading stage. However, I am not altogether convinced that it is an appropriate proposition. A number of features in it need clarification. Whilst I will support it at the second reading stage I will be seeking some clarification on individual aspects during the Committee stage. I am not happy with parts of the Bill and I hope to get that clarification.

The Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill 1983 breaks the nexus. Of course, I am opposed to that. That goes without saying. I refer to the No case and the points made in the No case when this matter was overwhelmingly defeated when it was put before the people of Australia. I oppose that proposal at the second reading stage.

Regarding the final measure, which I support at the second reading stage, at the Committee stage I will be asking that some matters be clarified. I am not sure that the measure ought to be supported. It depends somewhat on what type of legislation certain governments have in mind, whether their legislation is of a long term nature. Whilst the issue around which the legislation is framed may not be a very vital issue at the time the legislation comes forward, it could well be that that would be in six or eight months time and that could be the appropriate time to have the matter tested in such an atmosphere before the people. I will support the measure at the second reading stage. I have spoken very briefly. I am sure that the Attorney-General and other honourable senators are very grateful. There has been a long debate on this matter. The debate will continue up until 25 February. I will have plenty of opportunity to make my viewpoints known.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT (LEGAL AID COSTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.
Debate resumed from 6 October 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity at the first reading stage of the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill to raise again a matter that I have been pursuing for some considerable time. The matter has become known as the Tehran Embassy embezzlement affair or words to that effect. The first domino in the Department of Foreign Affairs has fallen. Honourable senators may recall that last session the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, angrily called on me publicly to cease what he described as my 'unrelenting campaign' to expose financial and other corruption among a small group of senior officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs led by the Secretary, Mr Henderson, whose main claim to fame seems to be that he is the son-in-law of the late Sir Robert Menzies.

SPEECH.PARA: In doing so, Mr Hayden had a bet both ways. While explaining that he had no personal knowledge of the Tehran Embassy embezzlement, the medical retirement frauds, the nepotism and the tax evasion-to name just four-he stated that he was convinced that my allegations were 'without foundation'. To his discredit, and doubtless at the behest of Mr Henderson, he put into Hansard some inaccurate and damaging comments on, in particular, one of the 10 or so retired and serving officers from Foreign Affairs who have contributed, to Parliament's knowledge, to the vast array of examples of corruption and misconduct, which subject was first raised by me in a question without notice on 25 February 1982.

On 2 June, I responded to Mr Hayden's rather ill-tempered tirade, setting out my position on the various questions of embezzlement, massive phoney retirement frauds, nepotism, et cetera, which I had exposed over the last 16 months or so. I spoke strongly and in detail about the bogus investigations into the Tehran Embassy shenanigans of Mr Ivor Bowden by the Department of Finance and the Australian Federal Police, explaining that there was no doubt at all that the police had bullied witnesses and tried, unsuccessfully, I am please to relate, to frighten at least three of them from ever coming forward again. I made it clear that I knew without a shadow of doubt that in order to clear Mr Bowden and , therefore, themselves from the charges I had made Mr Henderson and his senior cronies had brought massive influence to bear on these investigations.

Yet another police investigation was undertaken into other financial activities of Mr Bowden and the Australian Ambassador to West Germany. The police again came up with that ridiculous formula 'no evidence was found', when it was well known that the investigating officers did not approach, did not even go near, any of the several honest Foreign Affairs officers who had been courageous enough to come forward with information. In response to Mr Hayden's criticism of my behaviour, I made it clear that I knew I was right on this issue and that I would be pursuing it relentlessly-to use Mr Hayden's phrase in the Budget session-unless Mr Hayden got his act together. I made it clear that if there was nothing to hide my questions on notice should be answered fully and properly.

It would be easy to throw up one's hands in despair and accept that Mr Hayden had been 'yes, ministered' by Mr Henderson and the other professional liars working with him, as was the hapless former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, last year. Honourable senators may recall Mr Street's disastrous ministerial statement of 26 August 1982 in which the high point was his assertion that Mr Bowden could not have been involved in the fraudulent misappropriation of $8,000-odd at the Australian Commission in Hong Kong, as he had not arrived by the time it happened, but in fact he had.

To give Mr Street his due, however, under heavy pressure from Mr Henne and Mr Witheford, two ex-staffers from the Tehran Embassy, he did try to get the Commonwealth Ombudsman involved in investigating a furniture removal fraud involving Mr Bowden. However, several weeks later Mr Henderson managed to winkle the relevant file out of the Ombudsman and send it to the police, who subsequently said-honourable senators will not be surprised at this-that there was no evidence of a criminal offence. Mr Street probably tried, but he was quite simply not up to the job of containing Mr Henderson and his group of talented, articulate and dishonest cronies. It is a disgrace that every single one of these men continues to be supported, and handsomely so, by the taxpayer. As I said last session, unless Mr Hayden is prepared to use his axe, I am convinced that only a royal commission will get to the bottom of these matters.

I have always given fully of my loyalty and friendship to Mr Hayden and share the view of most that he is one of the most capable and intelligent members of the Parliament. That said, I would have expected Mr Hayden to realise very quickly indeed that there was not only a cloud of smoke in the Department of Foreign Affairs but also a lot of fire. I think honourable senators will agree with me, albeit reluctantly, that it is very hard to accept that at this stage Mr Hayden genuinely believes that Mr Henderson, Mr Bowden, Sir Nicholas Parkinson and the recently promoted Mr R. J. Smith-to name the biggest fish-are innocent of the charges I have put forward in both questions on notice and in speech form. I do not really think that Mr Hayden could doubt that a number of frauds, one of them to the tune of a quarter of a million dollars, has been effected and covered up by all possible means. Furthermore, how can Mr Hayden ignore the excesses of police and security officers against Foreign Affairs staff? Mr Hayden cannot play the ostrich with his head in the sand much longer.

I would like to brief honourable senators quickly on recent developments in this scandal, which are not without interest. Firstly, during the recess an effort was made to answer my scores of questions on notice but, not unexpectedly , the most difficult questions were not answered. However, one answer which is recorded at page 222 of Hansard of 24 August 1983 revealed that the former Ambassador to Germany, about whom I have made embezzlement allegations, had lost out on the appointment as Ambassador to the Netherlands, for which he was under consideration, and that he was not to be given any further ambassadorial appointments. Thus it is that the first domino in the Department of Foreign Affairs has fallen owing to a question which I put 10 months ago. The man in question was told that the decision had been Mr Hayden's. When this man-I derive no joy from the destruction of his career-was told by Mr Henderson to retire or face demotion by two levels, because obviously he does not have the right old school tie, the ex-Ambassador warned Mr Henderson that his punishment would inevitably egg on Senator Primmer to pursuing his allegations against Mr Henderson, Mr Bowden and the others with redoubled vigour. How right he was. A second development has been that Mr Bowden, who obviously bears a charmed life as well as an old school tie, was promoted two levels when he returned from Tehran. He is no longer in charge of a division or even a branch, but he continues to draw $50,000 per year emoluments. There have been rumours that an attempt has been made to give him another ambassadorial appointment. I am determined that he shall not get his hand into the cookie jar again.

The third development of interest is that the teenager, Adam Smith, has been transferred out of his father's division to another job in Foreign Affairs. Mr Hayden's laughable attempt to obscure the obvious fact that Adam Smith's appointment was an example of nepotism, of the Smiths getting in for their cut of the loot, does him no credit. I ask honourable senators to consider all this and then ask themselves whether there is not indeed something rotten in the state of affairs at Foreign Affairs.

During the recess a number of new sources of information on this issue have come forward. Some of their contributions are reflected in the updated set of questions I put on the Senate Notice Paper on 7 September. It is probable that I shall need to ask several more questions shortly when advice is received from informants in remote locations. I make no apology for the innuendo contained in my questions. After all, many of them have been on and off the Notice Paper and unanswered for about a year. I have also taken action to have the Ombudsman, Professor Richardson, examine the second police report. I propose to convene a meeting involving Foreign Affairs officers, interested honourable senators and the Ombudsman in the near future.

I have continued my contacts with the staff associations, principally the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and the Foreign Affairs Association, both of which have given valuable support, advice and protection to those honest officers upon whom Mr Henderson seeks to vent his wrath and false criticism as a means of killing my allegations. Mr Hayden's refusal to discuss these matters with me or with any informants in his Department has meant that I have no choice but to respond to him publicly in this way. I am told that he has even suggested that staff with allegations to make should see Mr Henderson. That is a recipe for instant career destruction, character assassination and a defamation writ if ever I saw one. I call on him again to suspend Mr Henderson, Mr R. J. Smith and Mr Bowden without delay so that a genuine and full investigation can be carried out by authorities in whom the Senate, the unions and the majority of Foreign Affairs staff can place their trust.

Mr Hayden must act quickly and resolutely to head off further damage to his own good name and that of the Australian Labor Party. I for one will not accept that these problems have been solved by treating the former Ambassador to Germany as a scapegoat. Whilst I welcome Mr Hayden's sterling successes as Foreign Affairs Minister, I remind him that charity begins at home. The shortcomings and excesses of his Department cry out for remedial surgery. Looking to the future, I have raised with a number of people, including Mr Hayden, the crying need in Australia for legislation along the lines of the United States of America Civil Service Reform Act 1978, the so-called whistleblowers' charter. In this connection I commend to honourable senators a recent article by Mr Paul Munro, National Secretary of the ACOA, which draws on the American experience in this area. I seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Blowing the whistle
Fraud, waste and mismanagement

About 45 per cent of the US Federal employees claimed to have observed instances of illegal or wasteful activity within the past twelve months according to a recent survey. The final report of a special study on ''whistle- blowing'' by US Merit Systems Protection Board found that according to employees surveyed, waste of Federal funds caused by badly managed Federal programs was the most serious problem in terms of cost.

The report revealed that 70 per cent of employees who claimed to have personal knowledge of some type of fraud, waste or mismanagement did not report the misconduct. Employees viewed existing channels of reporting as generally unresponsive. A belief that nothing would be done to correct illegal or wasteful activity was a reason given by most for not reporting the activity. Only about one in five gave fear of reprisal as a reason for not reporting.

The survey disclosed that more than half of those who were identified as the source of a report believed that nothing happened to them as a consequence of having made the report. About 10 per cent of identified reporters said they were given credit by management, but over a third believed that reporting the incident resulted in some form of ''negative experience''. A substantial percentage of employees was sceptical of the effectiveness of protections against reprisal.

Employee knowledge of reporting channels was low. Those who indicated the greatest degree of familiarity with the specialised US agencies having responsibilities for dealing with these matters tended to have the greatest degree of confidence in that organisation.
Same here?

There is strong reason to believe that the findings of the report would be duplicated in Australian Government employment. The disclosures in 1982 of internal procedures for dealing with alleged fraud, waste and mismanagement in the meat industry, dairies, tax and health benefit administration suggest that Australian public administration has been a fertile producer of home grown varieties of what the Americans describe as fraud, waste and mismanagement. The Public Accounts Committee and the Reid Inquiry, which had some responsibility for examining and improving internal checks against mismanagement, either had no taste for the task or found it beyond them.

A striking feature of the MSPB survey report is the technique of correlating degree of knowledge of a surveillance agency's activity with the degree of confidence in it. According to the report those who know best the specialised agencies dealing with illegal or wasteful activity (the Office of Inspector General and the Office of the Special Counsel of the Merits System Protection Board) have the greatest level of confidence in the effectiveness of those agencies in investigation and protection from reprisals. Another survey related to personnel management practices and grievances showed the opposite result with remarkably high levels of no confidence in the responsible agencies corresponding with direct experience of the agencies' operation.
Low scoring GAB

It would be very interesting to have a similar survey made covering the activities of such Australian agencies as the Public Service Board, the Grievance Appeals Bureau, the Auditor-General's Office, the Public Accounts Committee and the Ombudsman. I expect that some pretty low scores on the confidence level would be recorded.
Whistle blowers' charter

ACOA's submission to the Reid Inquiry drew attention to the causes of the publicly decried mismanagement which came to light in a number of areas of public administration last year. ACOA suggested that objectives for programs and regulatory enforcement be set in a public manner and be matched with the resources available to satisfy those objectives. In addition ACOA's submission called for the development of the whistle blower and other protections introduced to the US Federal Administration by the Carter Civil Service Reform Act.

The Reid Inquiry showed little interest in those proposals. ACOA will be pursuing the policies represented in those submissions with the ALP Government. The reasons why it is necessary to do so are strongly suggested by the graph on this page from the US study, which shows an alarming ignorance about appropriate procedures for reporting illegal or wasteful activities. If duplicated in Australia that ignorance is dangerous to individual ACOA members, and bad for both public administration and the public interest.
Grievance cases

The Grievance Appeal Bureau has general responsibility for a limited category of grievances raised under the Public Service Act. There have recently been a number of changes affecting the bureau, and ACOA is pressing for considerably more to be made. However, some details of the 1982 grievance casework are contained in the following extract from a report by the director of te GAB made to the June Joint Council meeting:
''In 1982, 457 grievance matters were received from staff in departments and statutory bodies with staff employed under the Public Service Act.

''Those departments and authorities from which most grievance matters were received were Defence and Defence Support (82), Social Security (52), Transport and Aviation (44), Taxation (44), Employment and Youth Affairs, Employment and Industrial Relations and Industrial Relations (21), Housing and Construction and Transport and Construction (19), Health (16), Industry an Commerce and Business and Consumer Affairs (14), Administrative Services (11), Veterans' Affairs (10), and Foreign Affairs (10 including 5 ADAB).

''The figures for Defence and Defence Support, Social Security and Taxation represent a substantial increase on last year while the figures for Foreign Affairs and Administrative Services represent a substantial decrease.
''The source of appeals were:
Per-
centage Region

Australian Capital Territory 126 28 Victoria 111 24 New South Wales 78 17 South Australia 54 12 Queensland 35 8 Western Australia 19 4 Tasmania 13 3 Overseas 11 2 Northern Territory 10 2
Total 457

40 against failure to gain appointment to the service or against annulment of appointment;

Of those cases which have been determined, 94 (22%) were allowed or partially allowed, 296 (68%) were disallowed, 10 (2%) were withdrawn by the appellant and in 34 cases (8%) no decision was taken. These percentages are quite consistent with the experience of the previous year.''
Paul Munro National Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —Recent events in the Department of Foreign Affairs-not to mention the meat industry-convince me that legislation along these lines must be pushed forward without delay. I shall be doing all I can to see that effective whistleblowers legislation-Henderson-proof whistleblowers legislation, if you like-is introduced as a matter of priority. To that end I have written to the responsible Minister, the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), asking that he consider the inclusion of whistleblower provisions in any new legislation concerning the Public Service. I seek leave to have a copy of my letter to Mr Dawkins incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE
National Mutual Building
104 Liebig Street,
Warrnambool, Vic. 3280
Telephone: 62 5039
September 30, 1983
Hon. J. Dawkins,
Minister for Finance,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,
I note with some interest, media reports relative to a reform of the Public Service and the intent that you will be taking over the chairmanship of a task force to this end.

I therefore wish to bring to your attention, the 'Civil Service Reform Act 1978 ', implemented by President Carter in the U.S.. Specifically within that Act I cite the provisions for the protection of Public Servants who, to use the phrase 'blow the whistle' on the Department or persons within it.

In my view the classical case in Australia in recent years where a public servant was demeaned and ultimately destroyed, was the case of Mr Tony Meyhew, the Customs Officer who told the truth as it related to the television set brought into Australia by a former Minister. Because Mr Mayhew was honest and struck to his guns, his superiors destroyed him.

There have of course been other cases and I believe that the insertion of a similar legislation in the Australian Public Service would do nothing but good and would encourage persons within that service to be forthcoming if and when they find malpractices therein.
I recommend the thought to you.
Yours faithfully, C. G. Primmer. Senator for Victoria. Per: Kay Ayres.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may have seen that the Department of Foreign Affairs was rebuked earlier this month by Mr Justice Davies, President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, for hiding files relating to the Tehran Embassy embezzlement and cover-up. It is clear from the Tribunal's hearing that additional documents about Tehran are still missing, probably destroyed. I intend to ensure that this new development in the Tehran affair is fully, honestly and earnestly investigated.

—I have listened with interest to Senator Primmer's contribution. I was somewhat alarmed at some of the things Senator Primmer said because these things were quite serious. I realise that he has raised this question before with respect to certain matters that occurred in Tehran involving a Mr Bowden. I think the terms that he used in the Senate were unfortunate. He referred to 'Mr Henderson and the other professional liars working with him'. Words like that are not called for. He referred later to ' articulate and dishonest cronies in the Department'. I do not mind the aspersions he cast on Mr Hayden. I know that on one hand he praised him and on the other hand condemned him. I do not have any quarrel with that. It seems to me that his idea of bringing together Professor Richardson, the Ombudsman, officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and interested members of this Senate and the Parliament is a good one. That means that he can escape from coward's castle and get some of these questions answered and give the people who have been accused an opportunity to defend themselves. I think that would be a good idea. I suggest that Senator Primmer arrange that meeting next week. I am one of those who will be pleased to go along and attend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak to the first reading of the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill for 15 minutes.
—I did not hear the request, Mr Deputy President.
—This is a first reading debate. Senator Kilgariff has already spoken to this matter. He seeks leave to speak a second time on the first reading. Maybe Senator Kilgariff should give an explanation.

—As honourable senators know, each Thursday a money Bill is made available to the Senate so that honourable senators can speak on any matter . This is an arrangement between the Whips which takes place every week. In this case the Bill before the Senate was before the Senate last week. The arrangement between the Whips is that-this is an understanding with the Government Whip- there are honourable senators who wish to speak again this week.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I understand an agreement was reached. I am sorry, I was not previously aware of that, so leave is granted.

—I thank the Minister. I took it that the Minister did not know and I was merely endeavouring to advise him on the matter. I feel that I must speak very briefly today to correct a situation that has arisen from Question Time on 11 October when a question was asked of Senator Grimes regarding the Calaid hearing aid. I expect that it was a misunderstanding when Senator Grimes, in referring to the Northern Territory Minister for Health, the Hon. Nick Dondas, said in rather strong terms:

SPEECH.PARA: It . . . demonstrates that Mr Dondas is willing to use the disabled in the Northern Territory for his own political ends and to create unnecessary anxiety amongst the families of the disabled.
He further said:
. . . it is despicable behaviour.
I hope that this matter is a misunderstanding for the question was asked:
It is a fact that the new Calaid frequency modulation hearing aid will not be available to patients in the Northern Territory as claimed by the Northern Terriotry Minister for Health . . .

Senator Grimes said yes, the Hon. Nick Dondas did know that the hearing aids would be available. So once again I believe it is a misunderstanding and I seek to advise on the situation because I think it is important to correct the errors in Senator Grimes's reply to Senator Robertson's question regarding the Calaid hearing aid. It is advised that Mr Dondas, the Minister for Health and Minister for Housing, became aware of the new hearing aids through Press statements released by the Hon. Neal Blewett, the Federal Minister for Health on 29 July 1983, which stated:
. . . a small number of children in all States would be fitted with the new aid before the end of the year.

There was no direct reference in that statement to the Northern Territory. The Hon.
