Nick Dondas asked the Northern Territory Department of Health how many aids would be supplied to Northern Territory children, and the National Acoustic Laboratories advised that only 50 aids were allocated altogether and there was no allocation for Territory children, although two of the aids may be brought to the Territory for demonstration purposes only.

Then on 8 September, Mr Dondas wrote to Dr Blewett advising that many Aboriginal children would benefit from the hearing aid. He requested advice on the matter from the Minister but received no reply. Because of the concern that the children of the Territory and especially those of the Outback should have this facility there was a follow-up of a telex which was sent on 14 September, but there was no reply to this. The Dondas Press statement that no aids were allocated to the Territory remains correct, even as of today, and it was based on the fact that no information had been given to the Northern Territory Minister for Health. Therefore, there is no basis whatsoever for Senator Grimes' s statement that Mr Dondas knew that hearing aids would be distributed to the Northern Territory on a per capita basis. In fact the Territory rejects the distribution of the aids on a per capita basis because it fails to take into account the special hearing problems of the Northern Territory Aboriginal population. Of course this is understandable when one sees the multitude of problems that exist amongst the Aboriginal children, whether it is nose, ears, chest or what have you. Fortunately in most of these fields now there are many inroads being made into the health problems. But in this case, of course, it is inconceivable to compare the Territory with the States because there is quite obviously the necessity for many more hearing aids than on a per capita basis. Mr Dondas's Press release stated that there was 'no specific allocation' made to the Territory. This was based on information supplied by the Darwin National Acoustics Laboratory staff to the Northern Territory Health Department. Obviously Nick Dondas acted in good faith. Far from using the disabled for his own political ends he was quite obviously seeking the best possible deal for them.

It is unfortunate that this has happened because the Hon. Nick Dondas is known in the Territory for his humane approach to the people of the Territory and particularly to the responsibilities of his portfolios, which include these Aboriginal children. Under the circumstances he does not have the opportunity to defend himself. I think that the facts that have been given by the Federal Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, are incorrect and I believe his statement is quite outrageous. To support the explanation that I have given I have here a statement regarding the Calaid hearing aids from the Secretary for Health of the Northern Territory Health Department.
I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
RE: CALAID HEARING AID
I believe it important to correct some of the errors in Senator Grimes' reply to Senator Robertson's question concerning CALAID hearing aids in the Northern Territory.

I am advised that Mr. Dondas, the Minister for Health and Housing first became aware of the new hearing aid from a press statement issued by the Honourable Neal Blewett dated 29 July 1983, which specifically states: ''that a small number of children in all States would be fitted with the new aid before the end of the year''. The press release does not refer to the Northern Territory.

The Minister's Ministerial Officer requested the N.T. Department of Health to advise whether there were any children in the Northern Territory to whom this announcement would apply. The National Accoustic Laboratory in the N.T. advised that only 50 of the new aids would be allocated and that no Territory children would receive any and that if two came to the Territory they would be used for demonstration purposes only.

On further questioning, subsequent advice was that there were no aids in the Territory so far, that there was no specific allocation for the Territory and that because of the limited production, Territory children could be expected to benefit much later.

On 8th September, Mr. Dondas wrote to Dr. Blewett advising him that there would be many Aboriginal children with hearing defects who could benefit from the new type of hearing aid and requesting advice. A follow-up telex was sent on 14th September, but no response has been received to either request. Mr. Dondas' press release stating that there has been no specific allocation for the Territory remains correct even as of today.

The only other information available is a report in ''The N.T. News'' dated Wednesday 14th September, quoting the National Accoustic Laboratory, Darwin office, as stating that ''the Northern Territory would get three (aids)-but it is not certain when''.

So in summary, Dr. Blewett's announcement in July failed to mention the Northern Territory, there has been no response to two specific requests for information for information concerning allocation to the Territory, and there is no basis whatsoever for Senator Grimes' statement that Mr. Dondas has always known that the aids will be distributed to the Northern Territory on a per capita basis. If this is to be the case, the Territory totally rejects such a distribution as it fails completely to take into account the special hearing problems suffered by the Northern Territory's Aboriginal population.
Keith Fleming
Secretary for Health 12 October 1983

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a most interesting statement and it clearly indicates that there has quite obviously been a breakdown in communication. I hope that after this the matter will be resolved, that not only will the Territory receive the Calaid hearing aids for the children but the difficulties involved and the fact that a large number of children require these aids in the Territory will be taken into consideration. I commend the Federal Government for having introduced these Calaid hearing aids. I note that in Dr Blewett's statement-which I have before me now-he has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Selected children in Sydney have already been fitted with the new system. First reports are of children's delight at being able to hear their parents and teachers. The new aids appear to be particularly valuable in assisting children to hear in a noisy environment.

And so it goes on. I think that this is a tremendous step forward for the children of the States. I hope too that after this misunderstanding the Territory is recognised in its own right, that these Calaid hearing aids will be made available to the Northern Territory and I also hope that it is recognised that what the Hon. Nick Dondas, as the Minister for Health in the Northern Territory, said publicly is quite true. He did it to bring about a situation in which the requirement for Calaid hearing aids in the Northern Territory is realised. Once again I hope that this has been only a misunderstanding and that the harsh words that were said by Senator Grimes regarding this particular Minister in the Northern Territory Government are not proved. I hope he will withdraw them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, as I have already spoken in the debate, I seek leave to speak for a period not exceeding 15 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Newspaper readers in Queensland this week were astounded when they saw a Queensland Government advertisement which attacked the Federal Government's Medicare program. The readers' astonishment was not solely due to the Queensland Government's attack on the Federal Government as that type of behaviour is not unusual for the Queensland Government. In an attempt to cover up its shortcomings it often attacks the Federal Government. With the previous Federal Government, some of the Queensland Government's criticism was well founded. However, since March of this year that criticism has been without foundation. The readers' astonishment was caused more by the sheer effrontery of the State Government using taxpayers' funds to attack a Federal Government program with less than two weeks before a State election. The advertisement which was run was clearly political. It carried no State Government information; all it did was carry misinformation about the Labor Government's Medicare program and photographs of the Premier of Queensland and the Queensland temporary Minister for Health. It indicated that Queenslanders would be paying for the southern States and that Queensland will not receive its fair share of funds from the Medicare levy. I seek leave, Mr Deputy President, to incorporate in Hansard the text of the advertisement which appeared on page 7 of Brisbane's Telegraph on 10 October.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The advertisement read as follows-
WHO WILL BE OUT OF POCKET OVER MEDICARE?
You will-
You will be paying for the Southern States!
Under Medicare, Queensland will get only $29 per head for its hospital system. Other States will get an average of almost $50 per head.
You are not getting your fair share!
Queensland will be $52 million short in a full year. Yet Queenslanders will pay the same levies as people in other States.
You will be out of pocket!
Remember-if husband and wife are working, both will pay the Medicare tax.
MEDICARE WILL COST YOU MORE!
Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Angelo Bertoni Premier of Queensland. Minister for Health, Qld.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The advertisement appeared in newspapers throughout the State. Most were of a size of about 18 centimetres wide by 34 centimetres in depth. I have no doubt that I have missed some of the newspapers in which the advertisement appeared, but I list 20 newspapers of which I am aware in which this advertisement did appear. Firstly, in the Brisbane metropolitan area, it appeared in the Courier-Mail, the Telegraph and the Daily Sun. Outside the Brisbane metropolitan area I noticed the advertisement in these newspapers: The Bundaberg News Mail, the Dalby Herald, the Gatton Star, the Gold Coast Bulletin, the Gympie Times, the Ipswich Advertiser, the Maryborough-Hervey Bay Chronicle, the Toowoomba Chronicle, the Queensland Times, which is an Ipswich newspaper, the Warwick Daily News, the Cairns Post, the Townsville Daily Bulletin, the Mackay Mercury, the Rockhampton Morning Bulletin, the North West Star, which is published in Mount Isa, the Hervey Bay Sun and the Gladstone Observer.

SPEECH.PARA: That these advertisements were paid for by the Queensland Government and thus by the Queensland taxpayer is beyond doubt. An advertisement which appeared in the Courier-Mail on 10 October carried an authorisation by Mr S. Schubert, the State Co-ordinator-General. In the following day's Courier-Mail Mr Schubert explained that his name should not have appeared on the advertisement; he had merely authorised the funds for the placing of the advertisement. I would like to quote the article from the Courier-Mail because it indicates that it was a Queensland Government advertisement. In part, the article stated:
In The Courier-Mail yesterday, an advertisment appeared bearing a Queensland Government crest and stating that Medicare would cost Queenslanders more than people in other States.
It was stated at the foot of the advertisement that it had been authorised by Mr S. Schubert, Co-ordinator-General, Premier's Department.

Mr Schubert claimed yesterday that the advertisement in question had not been an election advertisement. He said he had simply authorised the payment, on behalf of the Queensland Government, of the account relating to the advertisement.

I intend to remark shortly about the actual message in the advertisement but would first call upon the National Party in Queensland to make good the cost of this anti-Medicare newspaper campaign. Being a minority government does not give the National Party in Queensland the right to plunder the public purse. If it wanted to campaign in this way it should have been prepared to shoulder the cost of the advertisement itself. With the resources that I have at my disposal I have not been able to determine the cost of the National Party's advertising exercise. However, I did hear from a reliable source that the minority Government had set aside $40,000 for its anti-Medicare campaign. It may not have spent that amount on the newspaper advertisements to which I have referred. However, the advertisements in the Courier-Mail and the Telegraph would have cost more than $1,000 each. The cost of the Daily Sun advertisement would have been at least $700. When one considers the number of newspapers in which the advertisement was featured one gains some impression of the enormous cost involved, a cost which should not be a charge upon the taxpayers of Queensland. It is clearly a charge which must be borne by the National Party in Queensland. Therefore, I call on the Premier of Queensland or the Party's State President to give a public undertaking that the National Party will bear the costs of this political advertising campaign. If such an undertaking is not forthcoming, the National Party's actions will be condemned by all decent-minded Queenslanders.

In relation to the claims in the Queensland Government's political advertisement, I must mention that support for Queensland hospitals will increase from $93m, as provided by the previous Federal Government, to $173m in the first full year of Medicare. It is absurd to claim that under Medicare Queensland will subsidise other States. The Medicare levy in Queensland will raise some $146m in a full year. Queenslanders will receive in return $260m in extra funds and benefits for their health care system. The misleading information in the advertisement is bad enough and I do not intend to say anything further about it, but I do reiterate that it is totally unacceptable for the minority Queensland Government to use taxpayers' funds to run purely political advertisements. The National Party should immediately assure the people of Queensland that it will pay for these advertisements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this first reading debate to take the opportunity of making some points which have been brought to me by a dedicated group of enthusiasts, many of them scientists in Australia, who feel an acute sense of frustration. These are the people who are proponents of energy alternatives for this country, in particular wind energy. While this subject is one that has not been taken seriously by many in Australia-there is certainly evidence that the Government has not taken it seriously-there is all the evidence that in the world it is advancing steadily as a major alternative source of electric power. It is one which initial surveys of wind direction, speeds and duration have shown to be especially suitable to many parts of Australia, particularly, of course-and this is a key point-the west coast of Tasmania where recently this Government, with the approval and assistance of the Australian Democrats, decided not to go ahead with a hydro-electricity dam and the Gordon below Franklin dam.

SPEECH.PARA: The point about wind generators is that they have flexibility. Basicially, they are not enormous and can be installed or demounted, and sold if necessary, according to the demand for electric power in the location concerned. The other interesting aspect is that most of the machines now being used in Australia are imported. The technology is fairly low-scale and is well within our capabilities . With a little Government encouragement there is a possibility of creating major new industries in this area. The place that would appropriately suggest itself for such use would be Tasmania. Submissions have been made by this group to the Government asking it to consider this proposition seriously as a part of our general energy mix in the future. Nobody, including me in this place is going to say that this will solve all our energy problems, that we will get all our electrical power from wind, but it is possible that a large proportion of it could be so provided, especially in isolated areas where fuel costs are high and reticulation of power costs a great deal in terms of not only money but also power loss. The further one moves electricity along a transmission line the more one loses along the way; it does not get there intact, if I may put it that way.

In other parts of the world major wind generators have been operating successfully for a number of years. I think particularly of one at Tvind in Jutland. It is a 3 megawatt machine which was built, interestingly enough, by a group of enthsiastic amateurs with the full concurrence of the Government and has been operating efficiently for a number of years. One of the interesting things about the Tvind windmill, Mr Deputy President, is that the relationship between its supplying of electricity and the demand made upon it is represented by a very elegant statistical curve. In other words, the evidence regarding this major machine, as with many in the world, is that when you get cold, windy weather, the windmill operates at higher capacities and also, of course, the demand for electricity tends to go up. I have seen the graphs for the Tvind project and it is quite uncanny to note that the curves almost match each other perfectly. Thus, particularly where an ancillary source of power is required for hydroelectricity, where water can be held on the head or released according to demand, wind power can be used as a supplement very successfully. It reduces overall the demand for power from hydroelectric sources only when perhaps the water resources are falling low, as we indeed found to our cost during the drought of recent years. The snowy scheme had difficulty in supplying sufficient hydroelectricity because of water fall-off.

People will say that you cannot guarantee that the wind will be blowing in the one place for more than a certain time. That is, of course, true. The way in which this eccentricity of the supply, if I can put it that way, is being controlled in other countries is simply by having a large number of wind farms with small wind generators which supply electricity to the grid such that, at any one time, for any one grid, the wind is usually blowing and supplying electricity. So that, over a period, in a geographical span of sufficient size, you will get a very steady, even supplementing of the supply from wind farms.

The matter is being raised by me at this stage because of the Democrats' dedication to the idea that all of us must face eventually, that sooner or later we will have before us the problem of loss or depletion of non-renewable sources of supply for the purpose of electricity generation. We depend very heavily on coal in this country for that and, in remote areas, we depend on oil fired generators. The resources for this will inevitably become more expensive in the years to come and might eventually run out altogether. So the sooner we get into this technology the better.

I am putting it to the Government at this stage because I am concerned, as in my question to Senator Ryan as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology yesterday, that the Government has run down completely its wind energy research through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I think that is a tragic circumstance. I am prepared to accept what the Minister told me yesterday, that this was the ending of a particular program which was to assess resources and the general potential. But it would be tragic if that were now not to be followed up by a more concrete and practical program within CSIRO or any other area where that might occur which would allow this industry to go ahead full steam, because private enterprise is interested.

A firm in Perth is thinking of making wind generators and a number of small organisations are already in the business of importing and selling them. Of course, I believe they should be made here. So far there is a limited but significant use of wind power in Australia. The Rottnest Island 55-kilowatt machine has been in operation for some time now and is working quite successfully. An experimental machine is being built at Esperance in Western Australia to determine whether wind generators are a viable proposition in remote windy areas. If it follows the evidence of other areas, I think we will find that that is so as other costs go up.

A small Tasmanian company is installing one or possibly two 55-kilowatt machines on King Island. This is a most interesting example because I understand that the actual fuel cost alone of the generating machine on King Island is 11c a kilowatt hour. This is because fuel has to be shipped to the island. This company, I gather, is negotiating with the Hydro-Electric Commission. It is looking at a total cost of power from the wind generators of 9c a kilowatt hour. So not only would the project conserve fuel, it would also cut significantly the cost of providing power, even in fuel costs alone. I gather that it is proposed that a demonstration wind farm of six to 10 machines is planned to be established in Tasmania where extensive measurements of wind strength and direction have already been taken. World assessments regard the area as one of the most satisfactory places on the globe for wind power. Government funding of the wind farm, which, I understand, is being considered by the Government, ought to go ahead in the general interests of the community. I urge the Government strongly in that direction.

It is interesting that although many sizes of machines are available, ranging from four kilowatt to three megawatt capacity, it appears that the best economy is provided by machines in the 55 kilowatt range. That is why that figure has occurred in a number of examples that I have given to honourable senators. Fifty -five kilowatt machines are more competitive in Australia and, indeed, elsewhere as it would seem they cost about a third to half the cost of a machine in the megawatt range. So the economy of scale which occurs in many other industries does not apparently necessarily apply in this one. That is a most interesting point. This is important because there is greater flexibility if a small generator is used. There is also significantly less environmental hazard.

Last year I went to the trouble of looking at the United States Department of Energy generator on the island of Oahu which, of course, is that part of Hawaii on which Honolulu is located. It has been operating successfully for a number of years. I was able to see and hear it in operation. I thought it was aesthetically a pleasing enough object. Unless one got very close to it, the sound pollution was very limited. There was a swish from the blades as they reached the bottom of the arc, but their speed was not so high as to create a buzz or any sound which would even remotely approach the annoying capacity of so much of what we put up with in cities now-traffic and things of that kind. It is a comparatively peaceful sound so I think that the argument that these things would be pollutant from that point of view is limited.

An average household in southern Australia, which is not all electric and which has reasonable other facilities, would use approximately one kilowatt hour. So it is possible for these machines, which would average approximately 20 to 30 kilowatts over a period of a year, to serve 20 or 30 houses at a one-off cost of about $75,000. However, this cost would be greatly reduced as the number of machines increased. It would again be reduced if the machines could be made in Australia. It has been put to me that we could well reach the stage in favourable areas where complete supply of electricity to a household could be achieved for a cost of about $1,000. After that, there are no fuel costs.

The cost of maintenance of the machine is very small. They also are versatile enough to have reverse electricity metres so that an area which has wind generators can use power when the wind is not blowing. When the is blowing strongly it is possible to pump power back into the grid. In parts of the United States this is already being done. Indeed, the metres run backwards so that the electricity bill of persons in those areas is reduced by the extent to which that wind generator supplies power to the grid. That seems to me to be a very intelligent attitude.

I would like to look briefly at this from a strategic point of view. I think that in the world of the future in any war time situation, which can happen at any time, there is great value in any nation having some sort of decentralisation of its sources of electric power. This is something the Japanese feel quite strongly about. There is obviously a feeling of 'Good, let us have one great big nuclear power station to serve a huge area'. What happens if that one great big nuclear power station becomes a target in a war, which of course it would. It would inevitably be an early target. Quite apart from pollution aspects, there would be no electric power whatsoever for a whole city. If there were auxiliary sources in remote areas they could keep going.

There are many parts of Australia, particularly along our southern coastal areas, which are quite windy enough to enable wind generators to be a viable proposition. One suggestion for overseas and here is that these need not necessarily take up valuable land. They can be situated off-shore in suitable areas on pylons so that they operate along the coast line just out to sea and get the strongest winds. That, of course, is the area where the wind blows most steadily and strongly.

Wind energy is in extensive use in many countries. The European Wind Energy Association, which is a collection of official energy related bodies, has 13 member countries, all of which use wind energy for the generation of power. Their turbines range from four kilowatts to three megawatts and they have shown a most satisfactory mix. Denmark has publicly funded research and development aimed at both large and small scale wind turbines. I believe that in Australia we should follow the Danish model and have some public funding of research and development in this area to get the small industries away. In Denmark several small public companies produce and sell wind turbines and there is a 30 per cent public subsidy to the purchaser of small wind turbines. That has led to the installation of some 730 of these machines, and this figure is increasing. New orders are going in at a rate of about three of four a week. On the island of Oahu I found that quite a lot of the station properties, farms and small businesses are using wind generators in the kilowatt range. They are supplying most of the power for those industries. I therefore urge the Government to look at this sympathetically and to listen to those people who are dedicated to the cause of wind energy. Most of them are scientists who have done their homework and know what they are talking about. I urge the Government to see what assistance can be given.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent to the following Bills reported:
Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1983
Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1983
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill provides for amendment of the Repatriation Act and associated Acts to give legislative authority for the Government's Budget decisions and to make certain amendments to repatriation and defence service homes legislation. There has been some criticism recently that the Government is saving money at the expense of those who can afford it least, that is, the pensioners. The Government's view is that those who need and deserve assistance should get it. Among those who deserve it are veterans who fought for this country and who are disabled or otherwise disadvantaged. The Government is committed to maintaining the repatriation system. Overall expenditure on the Veterans' Affairs portfolio this financial year is estimated to be $2.818 billion which is an increase of $ 355m or 14.4 per cent over last year.

It is governments that decide to send people to war. It is governments that must take the responsibility for those people when they return. This is something I understand and support strongly. Many people do not understand just what the full social costs of war are, let alone the financial costs. It is far more than just setting up and sending off an armed force. There are the consequent costs-costs of death, injury, grief, loss of contribution of the soldier to society and the long term effects upon the veteran and his family. Apart from these horrendous social costs, the financial cost of war is staggering. The following figures represent 1981-82 dollar values. During the six years 1939-45 Australia spent $30 billion to win the war and maintain its freedom. In the years since 1945 we have spent half as much again. It has cost the Australian people $46 billion to meet their obligation for the rehabilitation and care of Australia's fighting men and women and their dependants. People must realise that vast sums will be required for many more years to ensure that Australia's commitment is met.

The Government's Budget initiatives are not all reflected in the Bill before the Senate. In addition, there are initiatives to be provided by amendment to the regulations and others that will not require legislation. This latter category includes major hospital works, the purchase of more specialised equipment for the hospitals and a start to the provision of all-round care for aged veterans. The majority of veterans who receive benefits from the Department of Veterans' Affairs served in the Second World War although some are older and at least one veteran of the South African War is still alive. Second World War veterans are aging, their average age is 64 years, and my Department has the role of ensuring that they are maintained with dignity and comfort. The Government has approved an initial funding of $1m as a first step in providing extended care services to aged veterans. Assistance will be provided by geriatric assessment units to veterans and war widows to live at home where it is considered to be in their best interests to do so. These units are being established in the Repatriation General Hospital in each State capital. The present system of care for the aged is confused and inadequate. The Government is determined that this situation will not continue. We are considering a range of proposals which seek to co-ordinate aged care, enable care to be provided in a variety of ways suitable to the aged population and lessen the aged person's dependence upon institutional care.

Nearly $7m more will be spent this year than was spent last year on capital works in repatriation hospitals, an increase of some 140 per cent over the average of the previous three years. In addition, the Government has decided to refer major development works for Greenslopes and Concord Repatriation General Hospitals to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, recommending capital works programs estimated at $13.5m for Greenslopes and $11.5m for Concord. Although there remains much to be done, there has been real progress in rectifying the serious deterioration under the previous Government in the replacement of old hospital equipment. My Government has made available over $4m this year for specialised hospital equipment-a 55 per cent increase on the average expenditure over the last three years.

I will now explain in detail the provisions contained in the Bill. This Bill provides that the income limits for fringe benefit eligibility are to be indexed ; eligibility for service pension is to be extended to a man providing constant care and attention to a severely handicapped female service pensioner; a remote area allowance is to be introduced for service pensioners; and guardian's allowance is to be extended to a veteran separated from his wife because of ill- health, where he has care of the children. In addition, pensions payable for amputations or loss of vision are to be increased as are attendant allowances and pensions payable to orphaned children. This Bill also includes amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918. They deal with some administrative matters for the conduct of the defence service homes insurance scheme. The indexation of fringe benefit levels will provide a major benefit to service pensioners. This step will mean that many pensioners will not lose eligibility for these benefits when they receive a small increase in income. Fringe benefits provide significant additional benefits to pensioners in the form of free medical treatment, telephone rental concessions and many other concessions, provided by Commonwealth, State and local Government authorities as well as private organisations. Indexation of these levels will provide assistance for those most in need. The indexation provisions will apply from 1 November this year.

Service pensions for veterans who served in a theatre of war are similar to age and invalid pensions paid by the Department of Social Security but are available five years earlier than the social security pensions. They have not been available normally to the husbands of female veterans. This Bill proposes that eligibility for service pension be extended to a husband of a severely handicapped female service pensioner where the husband provides constant care and attention for his wife in their home. This measure will assist those men who would not normally qualify for benefits because, but for caring for their wives, they would be part of the work force. This provision will come into effect on 8 December 1983.

The Bill also proposes that guardian's allowance, which at the moment is payable only to single service pensioners who have the custody, care and control of a child, be extended from 8 December this year to veterans who are unable to live with their spouses because of illness or infirmity and who have the custody , care and control of a child or children. In effect, the Government has recognised that these veterans are in the same position as single supporting parents.

The Goverment has also recognised that additional costs are incurred by people living in areas remote from Australia's major centres. Taxpayers in these areas receive concessions but pensioners have received no assistance in coping with the higher costs of goods and services. This Bill proposes to pay a remote area allowance, from 10 May 1984, to those service pensioners who live in those areas recognised under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as remote areas in Zone A. The proposal is that eligible pensioners living in these areas will receive an additional $7 a week if single and $6 a week to each of a married couple with $3 .50 a week for each child.

The Bill proposes that income from friendly societies and trade unions will no longer be exempt income under the income test for service pensions. This relates to periodical payments since annuities from these organisations are not exempt. Payments from other sources are, however, to be exempted along the same lines as exemptions are proposed for social security pensioners. These include the value of emergency relief, such as that provided following bushfires or floods and insurance or compensation payments following loss of, or damage to, buildings, plant or personal effects. Moneys from the investment of these payments will be exempt for a reasonable period to allow the lost or damaged goods to be replaced . Other exemptions covered are assistance by way of accommodation or meals provided to homeless persons, an open employment incentive bonus, domiciliary nursing care benefits and Commonwealth housing assistance.

Provision is made in the Bill for increases in pensions paid to veterans suffering amputations and loss of vision, in attendant allowance and in pensions paid to orphans. The increases are to have effect from 10 November 1983. The increases are in line with movements in the consumer price index since the previous increases. The increases for amputation and loss of vision mean that the total amount payable for loss of vision in one eye will be $38.77 a week, ranging up to $96.60 a week for the loss of both legs, one above and one below the knee. Higher amounts for more serious amputations are automatically adjusted twice each year in line with movements in the consumer price index.

The rate of attendants allowance is to be increased from $23.30 to 25.90 a week in the case of a veteran who is blind or suffering a cerebro-spinal injury. In the case of a veteran who has had both arms amputated or who is blind and has lost hearing or speech, the allowance is to be increased from $48.60 to $51.80 a week. A single orphan's pension will be increased from $16.60 to $18.45 a week while the increase for a double orphan will be from $33.20 to $36.90 a week.

The Bill also proposes that the Deputy Chairman of the Repatriation Commission be appointed by the Governor-General. At present the person is appointed by the Governor-General as a Commissioner and then elected by the Commission to the position of Deputy Chairman. The proposal will overcome some administrative difficulties in the operation of the Commission and it will also enable the office of Deputy Chairman to be a public office for the purpose of the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1973.

The Defence Service Homes Corporation has been offering insurance cover in accordance with the Statement of Conditions tabled in Parliament in November 1980. The amendments to the Defence Service Homes Act are designed to remove any doubt that the cover specified in the Statement may extend to domestic improvements of a structural nature and to the property owners' liability. Because it would not be feasible for the Corporation to refuse to meet claims legitimately made under its Statement of Conditions or to attempt to recover moneys paid out in settlement of past claims, the Bill proposes the validation of any such payments. Other Budget decisions affecting veterans will be provided for by amendment to the Regulations. These include increases in the recreation transport allowance and the clothing allowance and the indexation of pensions payable to Papua New Guinea veterans.

The provisions of this Bill will cost the Government $0.920m in 1983-84; $2. 225m in 1984-85; and $3.340m in 1985-86. Additional costs will be incurred by the increased benefits to be effected by amendments to the Regulations. Some savings will be generated by the removal of the exemption from income of payments by trade unions and friendly societies, but they cannot be estimated as it is not known how many service pensioners receive such payments. Removal of the exemption is justifiable on the ground of equity. The biggest single cost is the indexation of fringe benefits levels: $0.565m in 1983-84; $1.488m in 1984-85 ; and $2.578m in 1985-86. This provision, as I have already stated, is designed to help those most in need of assistance.

The fact that the Government has been able to make increases at all in what is a large Veterans' Affairs budget, at a time when it is attempting to keep costs down, is evidence of its commitment to those veterans who are seriously incapacitated and to those totally or substantially dependent on government assistance. These Budget initiatives are partial realisation of the Government's commitment as detailed in the Australian Labor Party platform to improve the benefits to veterans and their dependants to ensure that their sacrifices for their country are not forgotten. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 1.43 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. The Attorney- General will recall yesterday discussing at Question Time the inadequate and inconclusive report from Commissioner Abbott to the New South Wales Government which touched on allegations of corruption in that State's prison system and investigations into international drug trafficking. I ask the Attorney-General: In light of the grave concern expressed by the Costigan and Redlich reports tabled here yesterday by him, will he assure the Senate that the national crimes authority proposal currently before the Labor Caucus will provide a mechanism for the fullest inquiry into all aspects of the matters which are the subject of such serious public disquiet in New South Wales and that it is an adequate mechanism to ensure that action will be taken?

—It is not my intention, nor would it be proper, to indicate an answer to this question. The details of the proposal are now being debated within the Government. All I can say is that the proposal does involve the creation of an effective crime monitoring and crime investigating national organisation which will involve the utilisation of the Commonwealth's powers, to the extent that they are constitutionally available, and will also provide a mechanism for co-operation by the States in the areas of the investigation and monitoring of crime where the Commonwealth's constitutional powers do not reach. I believe that an organisation of this kind, constructed in this way, will be an appropriate mechanism to deal at least with matters generally of this kind. Beyond that, I do not think it is possible for me to comment. In the particular circumstances of this case, as I have already indicated, the Commonwealth has investigated this matter to the full extent of its constitutional competence. It has handed over the matter to the States to investigate within the limits of their constitutional and other competence. It would appear that there the matter has been obliged now to rest.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note the use by the Attorney-General of words like 'monitoring', 'investigating' and 'co- operation'. I take it from that that the proposal he has before the Caucus is not a proposal which will take action, that it is something which would produce more information about crime and in fact do nothing about it.
—Mr President, that is less a supplementary question than a tendentious assertion. I reject the imputations behind it.
—Is it true or false?
—It is absolutely false. In short, yes.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Minister read a recent article in the National Farmer which is headlined 'How farmers will lead our economic recovery' ? In view of the negative and ill-informed attacks by the Queensland National Party on the Government's policies on promoting the rural economy, can the Minister describe the role that the Commonwealth Government sees for the rural sector in the economic recovery that will take place under Labor's policies? Furthermore, will the Minister also ensure that Queensland National Party senators receive copies of this enlightened article in the National Farmer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have had drawn to my attention that article in the National Farmer. It broadly confirms, of course, what the Government has been saying for some time, that is, that the growth in the farm sector alone is expected to add 2 per cent to total gross domestic product growth in this financial year. The non-farm real GDP growth anticipated is 5 per cent. The farm GDP growth is 2 per cent, making a total of 7 per cent in all. We cannot expect similar increases of that magnitude in the GDP arising from the farm sector to continue in future years. A total increase of 2 per cent in real GDP from the farm sector is, of course, an enormous contribution from the farm sector, given that its total contribution to GDP is usually somewhere between 8 and 10 per cent. Net farm incomes, of course, will rise more than proportionately to the increase in farm products.

ANSWER.PARA: The macroeconomic policies of the Government in general, which are directed at limiting income and wages growth, prices, getting down interest rates and, consequently, getting down inflation are, however, of ongoing importance to the agricultural sector. Although we no longer live in the pre-1971 period of fixed exchange rates, currency rates are not immediately adjusted or adjusted on a one to one ratio to reflect different inflation rates in different countries. In all that macroeconomic area the policies being pursued by this Government will be to the advantage of the agricultural sector. In the last part of Senator Reynold's question she asked me whether I would ensure that National Party senators from Queensland get a copy of this article. I will think about that. If one does a quick cost benefit analysis of that proposition, I think it would probably come out negatively in that I suspect that they are ineducable and, therefore, there would be no point in circulating to them a copy of that article.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask: Has the Attorney noted the recommendation of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Robert Redlich, in his report tabled yesterday that 'a robust independent national authority' should be established to meet what he assessed as the 'national crisis' of organised crime? Has the Attorney-General brought this recommendation to the attention of the Government and, more particularly, to the members of the Labor Caucus? Will he assure the Senate that this assessment of Mr Redlich's combined with Commissioner Costigan's well-known views on the subject, will prevent a further watering down of the powers of this much delayed authority?

—I have, of course, noted Mr Redlich's conclusion and recommendation to that effect. I am sure that that has been noted by other members of the Government and the Caucus. I endorse the sentiments of Mr Redlich in this respect as I have made clear on numerous previous occasions. The particular model of a crime authority that I have in mind in fact bears a much closer resemblance to that given Mr Redlich's approval than the rather more draconian model for which Mr Costigan has expressed public enthusiasm. I have no doubt that in the debate that still continues within and outside the Government, all the matters adverted to both by Mr Redlich and Mr Costigan in their respective reports will be given full and appropriate consideration by the Government and appropriate action will follow.

—I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Until December 1982, handicapped students in northern Tasmania had been able to attend St Andrew's College at Launceston. I understand this building, which was funded by the Federal Government, is now standing empty. What will be the future use of this building? Is that use subject to the Minister's approval?

—As Senator Hearn said, St Andrew's residential college was used for handicapped children in the north of Tasmania until December last year when the organisation which controlled it closed it down. It was built with Federal assistance. At the moment discussions between officers of my Department in Tasmania and the relevant organisation are proceeding. It seems a pity-I am sure Senator Hearn agrees-that such a facility should be there and not be used when there is the potential for use. I hope that arrangements can be made not only with the organisation itself but also with other organisations which are seeking accommodation in Launceston so that a satisfactory use can be made of the property. As the property was partly purchased with and supported by Commonwealth funds, the Commonwealth is involved. It is for that reason that I and my departmental officers are involved.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence a question about an installation not in Queensland but at Watsonia in Victoria. Is it a fact that a 60 foot diameter dish located at the Watsonia Barracks in Melbourne is the ground terminal for the United States Defense Satellite Communications System? Is it true that this facility, part of Project Sparrow, is involved in the transmission of signals intelligence to the United States of America, which enables it to pinpoint Soviet nuclear submarines in the Indian and Pacific Oceans? Is it the Government's assessment that this facility gives the United States the technological capacity to launch a first strike against Soviet submarines and thus contribute to American nuclear war fighting capability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that there is a satellite communications facility at Watsonia in Victoria which enables Australia to communicate with the United States of America on intelligence matters. I am told the facility accesses the United States Defense Satellite Communications System. This Government, as with previous governments, will neither confirm or deny details relating to intelligence matters. The problems for governments in dealing with claims about intelligence matters is that if they are accurate, and the government concerned confirms their accuracy, potential enemies will be provided with valuable military information. Conversely, if the claims are inaccurate in part or in whole, denial of claims that are inaccurate will, over time, also allow potentially unfriendly governments to build up a picture of what intelligence capabilities are or are not possessed. I am sure that Senator Chipp will appreciate that situation.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the last part of his question which concerns the general question of the United States' first strike capabilities, I believe I can do no more than refer the honourable senator to the 1984 United States Defense Report recently presented to Congress by Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger which includes the following unequivocal statement:
First, our strategy is defensive. It excludes the possibility that the United States would initiate a war or launch a pre-emptive strike against the forces or territories of other nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question-I believe it is a true supplementary question. I asked the Attorney whether this facility was located at Watsonia and whether it sends intelligence signals to pinpoint Soviet nuclear submarines in the Indian and Pacific oceans? I also asked whether it is the Government's assessment that this facility gives the United States the technological capacity to launch a first rate pre-emptive strike against Soviet submarines. The Attorney did not answer that question for the proper reasons that he gave. He simply said: 'They are there for intelligence matters'. Am I to understand from this-I just want to get it clear as a citizen of Melbourne-that this suburb eight or nine miles out of downtown Melbourne has a facility which could be a prime nuclear target? Are the people of Melbourne to be kept in ignorance of the possible fact that Watsonia, eight miles out of Melbourne, could or would be a prime nuclear target of the Soviets in the case of a pre- emptive strike?

—I do not believe it is the case that any writer on Australia's defence installations, including even Desmond Ball, has specifically identified the Watsonia facility as a nuclear target in the terms in which Senator Chipp describes it. I am not sure that it is possible for me to add anything further to my response. However, I will seek a further reply from the Minister for Defence, or the Minister for Foreign Affairs for that matter, if either of them feels able to add further and better particulars along the lines of the answers I have already given to a number of other questions on the nuclear targeting aspects of Australia's defence policy.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation whether it is the case that Air Queensland has suffered losses in providing air services to locations in western Queensland and whether these losses, if they continue, may jeopardise the future of those services. Will the Government take action to help maintain the viability of those services for western Queenslanders?

—I have been advised that the services of Air Queensland from Brisbane to the western Queensland towns of Alpha, Barcaldine and Longreach do indeed run at a loss and this is a matter about which the Government has expressed some concern. It may be that there will be a very sharp deterioration in services if these losses continue. In fact, the services could be put in jeopardy. The Federal Government recognises its obligation to help in the provision of better communications to citizens and has made available $50,000 on the basis of a dollar for dollar contribution by the Queensland Government to subsidise the services at least until 31 December 1983. At that stage the Government is prepared to consider further subsidisation. It will be prepared to review the temporary arrangements which are intended to identify appropriate longer term measures to meet the air transport needs of isolated Queensland communities. As you well know, Mr President, Queensland suffers greatly from the fact that many towns are a long way from the capital city of Brisbane. Therefore , there is an obligation upon the Commonwealth to assist if at all possible.

—Will the Attorney-General explain why he is now so much less definite about when the Government's national crimes authority will be revealed in all its modified splendour? Does he recall last week chiding Senator Durack for his impatience and assuring the Senate that all would be well? I think his words were: 'I hope in another week or two'. But yesterday he admitted to Senator Hill that he was now not in a position to make a final judgment on its timing. Does this retreat simply reflect yet another Caucus defeat for the Attorney-General or does it reveal the Hawke Government's fear that the early establishment of an effective national crime fighting organisation would seriously embarass the Wran Government in New South Wales which once again is unable to throw off the air of corruption pervading its administration of justice.

—As much as I would like to be able to satisfy the blood lust of Senator Walters, I am afraid that I am not yet in a position to give her the further details she requires. It may be necessary, accordingly, for me to go on chiding Senator Durack and others, as I have been doing now for some time, for their impatience and, indeed, their general behaviour in matters of public policy.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I have received a number of submissions regarding the proposed new categorisation of nurses by the public Service in the trades and related staff at the operational level, following the abolition of the divisional structure of the Publc Service. There is considerable concern at such classification and I understand other groups have raised objections about their categorisations. Can the Minister say what stage Public Service Board categorisations have reached? Further, can the Minister say whether there have been many protests and what steps will be taken to deal with those protests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably it comes as no surprise to the Senate that I am not exactly au fait with the relationship between the Public Service Board and the nursing organisations in Canberra. Senator Crowley was courteous enough to give me some notice of this question. The amendment to the Public Service Act in 1982 provided for the abolition of the four-tier divisional structure of the Public Service. I think this has been generally regarded as a desirable reform. As a consequence, the Public Service Board set about making plans to organise the Service into occupational groupings. Notice of this intention was given on 7 June 1983 by means of a draft memorandum attempting to classify occupational groups into categories. One of those groups was nurses, who were professionally placed into a trades and related operational sub-category.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the specific point of the question, yes, the Public Service Board has received numerous complaints and representations about this classification of nurses. As a result of the wide range of complaints, the proposal has been completely reviewed. In a memo issued on 23 September the Public Service Board announced that it was dropping its initial proposal entirely. I should add that further attempts will be made by the Public Service Board to organise the Service in the way desired, but on this occasion the very vehement wishes of nurses will be taken into greater account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General taken steps to identify and discipline the lawyer from the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in charge of a joint prosecuting task force who, in the Special Prosecutor's presence, argued against releasing any information to another task force? Will the Attorney-General make it quite clear to officers of his Department that co-operation between law enforcement bodies is essential in combating organised crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The incident to which Senator Lajovic referred is one of some other examples of this kind adverted to by Mr Redlich in his report. The report is critical of what Mr Redlich perceives to be a lack of co-operation and co-ordination between a number of Commonwealth authorities, departments and agencies in the area of offences against Commonwealth law. I do not think it is appropriate that that particular matter should be the case for any witchhunt- type investigation of the kind that Senator Lajovic would egg me on to. Rather it is a demonstration of what I think has been a structural and organisational problem within the Attorney-General's Department, and more partciularly within the whole Commonwealth, so far as its capacity to deal with and effectively prosecute a crime is concerned. That of course is very much the subject matter of, among other things, the departmental review which I announced yesterday. It will be more specifically addressed in the context of the legislation and subsequent administrative action to establish a directorate of public prosecutions, which legislation will be introduced into the Parliament, I hope, very shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: Beyond that it is a matter of developing better arrangements for co-ordination and the removal of some of the traditional feudal mentality that has undoubtedly existed between the respective statutory authority fiefdoms in the Commonwealth administration, both in this and in a number of other respects. I am not sure that can be accomplished overnight. We are certainly aware of the problem. We are taking very active steps to solve it, both right now and in the context of the activities of the special prosecutors, which range over both civil and associated criminal matters. More partciularly, we will be addressing the problem, as I said, in the context of the extablishment of a directorate of public prosecutions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to a report which appeared in the Australian newspaper of 6 October in which it was claimed:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal Government may introduce a levy on uranium exports to fund research into the disposal of nuclear waste.
The Northern Territory Chamber of Mines responded favourably to the levy proposal.
Is such a levy under consideration by the Government? Has such a proposal been discussed with the uranium mining industry? If so, what has been the industry's response?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a report in the Australian-I think it was of the same date-regarding this question. I have also received a telex from the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy, which I do not seem to have with me. However, the facts are that the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Reeves, raised with me, when I was in Darwin a couple of weeks ago, the suggestion that an export levy be applied to uranium for the specific purpose of funding research into waste disposal. Of course, such a practice is not without precedent. A levy is applied for the purpose of defraying the cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Mr Reeves proposed another levy for an additional purpose on the ground that increased funds for research into waste disposal were more likely to increase the chances of overcoming the problem and the problem having been overcome, a great deal of the soundly based concerns about the nuclear power industry would, therefore, be removed. I raised that matter with the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines. Its response was, in my judgment, non- committal.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the matter was reported in the Press in somewhat different and stronger terms than a suggestion coming from Mr Reeves which I said I believed was worthy of consideration. I still do. In one report-I think it was the report in the Australian to which Senator Giles referred-a figure of 5 per cent was mentioned as being the levy that the Government was contemplating. There is no substance to such a figure. It is not correct, as has been reported-I think in the Australian-that a spokesman from my office indicated that the Government was committed to such a policy. There is no such commitment. My position is the same now as it has been all along, that is, that Mr Reeves's suggestion in my view, is worthy of serious consideration. I take this opportunity to assure the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines that neither I nor my office was responsible for what one might call the beat up versions of what I said which have appeared in some newspapers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to an interview on the AM program in which he suggested a degree of dissatisfaction with the way in which Commissioner Costigan conducts his investigations. Has the Government taken, or does it plan to take, any steps to change the direction of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? Does the Attorney-General's apparent dissatisfaction with what he described today as Mr Costigan's 'adventurous investigation technique' have a purely professional motivation or is it an attempt by the Government to subtly muzzle the Commissioner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said nothing on AM this morning that I have not said on innumerable other public occasions over the last few months while this issue as to the proper role and scope of a crimes commission or a crimes authority has been debated. I certainly do not in any way express dissatisfaction with what I described as the adventurous investigative techniques embarked upon by Mr Costigan. Indeed, I was laudatory of what those techniques had produced by way of very significant information about the nature and extent of organised crime in this country. I would certainly wish that kind of investigation to continue, whether by Mr Costigan or some other differently structured organisation. I expressed the view, as I have on other public occasions, that I believe it is appropriate that investigations be particularly focused on the need to elicit admissible evidence which can substantiate subsequent prosecutions. To the extent that there has been less of a focus on that and more of a focus on pursuing investigative trails without stopping to gather hard admissible evidence, then I have been suggesting that a change of focus and approach may, to that extent, be desirable. I have certainly communicated that view to Mr Costigan. He is well aware of it. I am sure he has been taking that into account in the course of his investigations, certainly over the last few months.

ANSWER.PARA: I might also say-I did not get an opportunity to say this on the radio program this morning-that it is not only by actual prosecutions that the success of an enterprise such as Mr Costigan's should be measured. Much can be done along the way. I know Mr Costigan and Mr Meagher emphasised this in explaining what they were about to alert other instrumentalities and agencies to problems in their own procedures, organisational legislation, which allows money to be lost by means of fraudulent schemes of one kind or another. It is true that the alerting of other law enforcement agencies to the possible commission of offences and to the possible identity of offenders can be a very great utility indeed to those law enforcement agencies as they go about their tasks. Yet that may never emerge as part of the final reporting of the Commission itself in relation to its own mainstream investigations. It is very important that that spin-off or consequential benefit of the kind of enterprise that Mr Costigan's Commission has been conducting should be fully appreciated. I do not wish to be understood in any way as being critical of the overall performance and achievements of that Royal Commission. The only point I make-I have repeated it endlessly in public forums and in this Parliament-is that if we are to establish any form of ongoing organisation to monitor and investigate organised and sophisticated crime in this country, it does need to be rather better defined both as to the powers to be exercised and the safeguards on those powers than is now the case as a matter of law so far as royal commissions are concerned. I believe that is a view that would be shared by all honourable senators in this place on both sides of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Following the recent decision by General Motors-Holden's Ltd to close down the Acacia Ridge plant and following the question asked yesterday by Senator Foreman I am concerned about the possible misuse of the export credit facilitation scheme for car manufacturers that was introduced by the Fraser Government. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the intended purposes of this scheme? What have been the effects on the work force employed in the vehicle building industry as a result of it? Is there any evidence that Australia's car manufacturers have abused the scheme by importing large quantities of manufactured components produced with a high labour content while, at the same time, curtailing their Australian operations? Further, is the Government considering reviewing the export credit facilitation scheme or considering tightening its provisions to prevent possible misuse?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of questions are contained in that one smorgasbord which has been thrown at me. I will try to deal with them one by one as they came up. First of all, I was asked about the purpose of the export facilitation scheme and the possible misuse of that scheme. The essential purpose of the export facilitation scheme, as I understand it, is to expose the manufacturers of component parts of cars to more import competition over a number of years. The purpose of that was to try to ensure greater efficiencies and rationalisation within the component part manufacturing industry. It is very difficult to say, at this stage, whether the purposes of that scheme have, in any way, been achieved. It is also very difficult to say what the effects of the implementation of the scheme on employment are. I must say that that depends very much on a wide variety of factors about which, if I might offer the opinion , quite outrageous assumptions are made in certain circles varying from massive effects on employment to no effects on employment. All I am prepared to say is that the situation is somewhere in the middle between those two wild estimates.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked also whether there is evidence of misuse of the export facilitation scheme in that car manufacturers import into Australia component parts which are either inferior or made at very low cost because of low-cost labour in the countries of origin and so on. I think it may be correct to say that there are certainly a large number of allegations to the effect that there have been some examples of transfer pricing operating in respect of particular component parts of particular vehicles by some manufacturers. That matter is currently the subject of investigation by officers of my Department. I would like to add that the general issues raised in Senator Richardson's question are now the subject of discussion by the Car Industry Council which was formed last week and which had its first meeting on Wednesday of this week. That Council has established a number of working parties some of which are directed towards the specific topic about which Senator Richardson is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In addition to the enormous risk of the Iran-Iraq conflict spreading to involve the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is the Minister aware of the dangers to Western oil supplies that could result from the French Government's decision to supply Iraq with Super-Etandard war planes capable of firing the French made Exocet missiles ? Since Western Europe and the United States have urged the French Government not to proceed with this sale, has the Australian Government expressed an opinion to the French Government as to the wisdom or morality of its supplying Iraq with those planes?

—The Australian Government is well aware of the dangers of escalation of the conflict between Iran and Iraq. Obviously, we do not wish to see it extend to other countries in the region. Any disruption of the movement of oil supplies through the Strait of Hormuz would be an additional reason for concern. It would be incorrect to portray the arrangements apparently under way for France to supply Super-Etandard aircraft to Iraq as a significant alteration to the military balance in the region. For instance, it is the Government's understanding that Iraq has had Exocet missiles for quite some time, deliverable by other aircraft. The acquisition of Super-Etandard aircraft does, however, clearly add a new psychological factor in what has become, to a large extent, a stalemate. It would be a matter of real concern if an escalation of the conflict were to result. I am advised that Australia has expressed to French officials our general concern about the dangers of expansion of the conflict and the risks this would pose to oil supplies. I have no advice or information as to the response that was received to that. If I can obtain further particulars I will advise the honourable senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In view of the Australian Labor Party's stated policy to repeal the sections of the Trade Practices Act which imposed penalties on trade unions and union oficials for legitimate forms of industrial action and taking into account the increasing urgency for repealing section 45D of the Trade Practices Act because of the likelihood of further national industrial action in the oil industry, on the waterfront and in other areas as indicated by the Transport Workers Union for one, I ask: Will the Minister inform the Senate when the relevant amending legislation will be introduced into the Parliament?

—I cannot give the honourable senator the answer to that question because I am not sure. The matter is subject to current review by the Government and an announcement will be made at the appropriate time.

—Is the Leader of the Government aware that, according to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force figures released today, Queensland has gone against the national trend of increased unemployment, with the rate dropping by 0.4 per cent, while in New South Wales it has increased by 0.3 per cent, in Victoria by 0.8 per cent, in South Australia by 0. 1 per cent, and in Western Australia by 0.5 per cent? Furthermore, is the Minister aware that Commonwealth statistical information illustrates that Queensland has outperformed every other State in the implementation of its wages pause programs?

—I really am delighted in the words of Senator Bjelke-Petersen to have confirmation that Queensland has gone against the national trend. What is new about that I do not know. Queensland has been going against the national trend for a number of years now under the leadership of the Bjelke-Petersen Government. I simply make the point that if Senator Bjelke-Petersen is concerned about statistics and indices of welfare and economic stability and recovery in Queensland, they are not too good and they are against the national trend. I have not studied the figures. If Queensland's unemployment has dropped by 0.4 per cent on the latest monthly figures that is very welcome, because it will be the first month in which it has happened for some time. We welcome that as a Government, and we would welcome any other improvement in the situation of the people of Queensland. We believe that that will be brought about on 22 October when there is a change of government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION OF AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General received expressions of concern about the charging under the Crimes Act of ten members of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia not only with contempt but also with conspiracy arising out of their refusal to testify before the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? Can the Attorney-General indicate who is conducting the prosecutions and whether it is intended that they should proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matters to which Senator Georges has referred arose from a ruling given by the Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan, on 27 July, which he drew to my attention in subsequent correspondence, in relation to the failure of certain witnesses from the Painters and Dockers Union to answer questions. The ruling involved his conclusion that an offence appeared to have been committed under section 6 of the Royal Commissions Act by the witnesses in question. Arising out of that, and before I had had a chance to do anything by way of evaluating the possibility of the commission of an offence, arrest warrants were issued and executed against 10 painters and dockers on 18 August. Ten of them were charged with conspiracy to effect an unlawful purpose against the laws of the Commonwealth, namely, to refuse to answer questions before the Costigan Royal Commission. Eight of them were charged with the actual offence which can be described in shorthand as contempt, that is, under section 6 of the Act, which involves the refusal of a witness to answer questions put to him by a royal commission and relevant to its inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Redlich, who as special prosecutor was carrying on these prosecutions in effect arising out of the Costigan Commission's recommendations, has now advised me in a letter I received yesterday that the conspiracy charges should be withdrawn and that the prosecution should proceed only in relation to the substantive charges under section 6 of the Royal Commissions Act. The reasons advanced by Mr Redlich for this conclusion, and I believe they are important, are, firstly, the delay in referring to the Crown for prosecution the first refusal by a defendant to give evidence. That was as long ago as 9 February 1982 . Secondly, doubt whether evidence of the refusal by a defendant before the Commission to answer questions would be admissible against him in a conspiracy charge having regard to the restrictions imposed on the use of evidence given before a Royal Commission by section 6DD of the Royal Commissions Act. Thirdly, the strong disapproval recorded by the High Court in Queen v. Hoar (1981) 34 ALR 357 as to instituting conspiracy charges when substantive charges are available on the same facts.

Mr Redlich points out in effect that, if the charges are confined to substantive offences, all of the circumstances surrounding the commission of the offences will be placed before the court so that, if the defendants are found guilty, the court will be able to punish the defendants with full knowledge of the circumstances leading to the refusal by each defendant to answer questions put to him by the Royal Commission.

I agree completely with Mr Redlich's conclusion. In my view, the conspiracy charges are and always were manifestly inappropriate in the circumstances of this case. Mr Redlich's advice has of course been accepted by the police informant. The conspiracy charges will accordingly be withdrawn but the charges under section 6 of the Royal Commissions Act against the eight defendants who refused to answer the Royal Commission's questions will be continued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I ask the Minister whether she is aware of the decision of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly in relation to Radford College:

QUESTION.PARA: That this Assembly reiterates its support for, and calls upon the Government to confirm its commitment to the unequivocal statement of the Prime Minister Mr Hawke, as reported on 3.3.83 that 'we will ensure that the school is built'; and , 2. That the extraneous matters referred to in the Anderson Committee of Review into the impact of Radford College that do not specifically relate to the building of Radford College as planned, be rejected by the Government.
Can this community be confident that the Government will accept the advice of the House of Assembly and honour the commitment of the Prime Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather surprised that Senator Reid has chosen to use this forum to bring to my attention the views that are expressed in another democratically elected forum.
—Why? Can't you answer it?

—It is usually the practice of the House of Assembly to send to me any resolutions it moves in areas for which I am responsible. I am sure that it will do the same in the case of the motions to which Senator Reid's question referred. When it does, I will respond to it.

—Can the Minister for Resources and Energy say whether any progress has been made in finalising a tender for the construction of the Burdekin Dam? If a decision has been made, can the Minister provide information on the name of the successful tenderer, the number of tenders received, the value of the tender or the estimated cost of construction? However, if the tender has not been finalised, can the Minister give any further information to the Senate about the present position of the tender for construction works?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eleven firms have been invited to tender for the construction of the dam and tenders closed on 20 September.
