The Queensland Government, apparently following the proper procedures for once, examined the tenders and announced on the tenth of this month that it favours the lowest tender, which has not always been the practice in Queensland either, I understand. The lowest bid was for tender of $45.6m received from Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd which, like most of the other low tenderers, is a reputable and experienced contractor. The tenders must be submitted to the Commonwealth Government, and specifically to me, for final approval and are therefore subject to Commonwealth veto if the Commonwealth chooses to exercise such a veto. Since in this case the Queensland Government appears to have applied the proper procedures, unusual though that may be, I see no reason to veto the tender which I expect to be recommended by Queensland. The fact that the Commonwealth does have that power of veto may account for proper procedures having been followed by the Queensland Government on this occasion, as distinct from a number of other occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Govenrment is conscious of the tight timetable for constructing the dam wall and will do nothing to impede progress. We will, however, closely examine the tenders to make sure that the taxpayers of Australia are getting value for their money. Also, I will make an announcement of the final decision as soon as possible. I should add that this Government has accepted, in a legally binding form, the responsibility for funding the construction of the Burdekin Dam. It has exceeded the commitments given in the Labor Party's north Queensland policy which was released in, I think, November last year and provided for funding for the construction of the dam on a two-for-one basis. This Government has exceeded the undertaking it gave in its north Queensland policy. It has agreed to fund the construction of the dam in total and to put that into a legally binding form , in a way that the Fraser Government had not done. The final proof of the fact that the Fraser Government, although it spent some money last year, had not put that agreement in legally binding form came from the former Treasurer who, in an interview published in the Age about six weeks ago, is reported to have said that, of course, if the Fraser Government had been returned, the Burdekin project would have been one of those considered for the axe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the discredited former Treasurer?

—Yes, the discredited former Treasurer, but in that case I believe he was being absolutely frank and honest in admitting that had the Fraser Government been returned the Burdekin project would have been one considered for the axe-he did not say that it would have got the axe. That establishes more clearly than anything else possibly can that there was not a firm commitment in principle, let alone a legally binding commitment, by the previous Government to continue funding the Burdekin Dam. If Senator Sir John Carrick wants to dispute that I suggest he take it up with his deputy leader, who said and was reported in the Press about six weeks ago as saying that if the Fraser Government had been returned the Burdekin project would have been of of those considered for the axe.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE SQUADRON, MALAYSIA, AND AID TO VIETNAM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, refers to a report on AM of Tuesday, 11 October in which it was stated that: 'While the good offices of Mr Hayden endeavour to hold the ALP Caucus at bay, they could well decide to remove the remaining RAAF squadron from Malaysia and as well demand that aid be renewed to Vietnam'. I ask : Is that report accurate and, in view of the present coolness in relations between the Australian Government and the Association of South East Asian Nations, is there any move for the remaining squadron to be returned from Malaysia to the Australian mainland? Also, in regard to that part of the statement concerning the demand that aid be renewed to Vietnam, will the Minister advise the Senate on the matter?

—There is no present cause for alarm, on Senator Kilgariff's behalf or anyone else's behalf, concerning either of the matters to which he has referred. Both are under review, as one would expect, with a Government responsibly trying to work out its relationships with its regional neighbours. When the time comes for an announcement on either or both of the matters to which Senator Kilgariff has referred, it will be made by the relevant Ministers. If there is any further specific information that I am able to give him after consultation with the relevant Ministers-being unable to scurry through my brief , given the unaccustomed brevity of Senator Kilgariff's question-I will do so in due course.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, whether he has seen the report in the Weekend Australian of 8 October entitled 'Macphee throws down the gauntlet on wages', in which it is revealed that there is a battle within the Federal Opposition over wages policy. Does the Minister agree with the comments made by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, at the weekend, that the decentralised wage fixing system, as advocated by Mr Howard, would mean open slather for the strong unions? What would be the consequences for the economy generally of the Howard free-for-all approach to wage fixation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not see the report in the Weekend Australian under the title 'Macphee throws down the gauntlet on wages'. However, I have had the opportunity of reading a transcript of Mr Macphee's speech to the industrial relations seminar on which the report in the Weekend Australian was based. I must say that it was a most articulate and well argued speech in presenting Mr Macphee's case in relation to centralised wage fixation and other matters. Yes, surprisingly enough, I do agree with the Prime Minister on this issue: A decentralised wage fixation system would mean open slather for the stronger unions. That is precisely the sort of point that Mr Macphee makes in the paper he gave to the seminar last week.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked also what would be the consequences for the economy generally of the Howard free-for-all approach to wage fixation, as I think Senator Foreman put it . Let me say that while I could not speak with any great authority on that matter, there are two or three very obvious consequences of the approach adopted by Mr Howard to wage fixation. The most obvious result of all would be that there would be a very considerable misallocation of resources, both labour and social, and many problems associated with that misallocation. It is important to remember that the sorts of considerations to which Mr Macphee addresed his mind, in relation to wage fixation, are those that are essentially conservative in the true sense; namely, that he sees the importance of the traditional development of wage policy in Australia and the importance of the centralised wage fixation system as it has obtained for a very long period, and on the basis of those factors analyses the economic dislocation which would arise, as Senator Foreman' s question suggests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, refers to the answer given by Senator Walsh to Senator Cook in the Senate yesterday, in the course of which Senator Walsh produced what purported to be copies of two cheques and two cheque butts and referred to the name 'N. Crichton-Browne' as appearing on one of the cheque butts. I draw the attention of Senator Walsh to Senator Crichton-Browne's firm statement that he had no business dealings with Mr Christo Moll, directly or indirectly, and now ask the Minister whether, in accordance with normal ministerial and Senate practice, he can authenticate the documents that he produced and from which he read.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The photocopies in question were supplied to me from a source which I am not prepared to disclose. All politicians get information from sources which they are not prepared to disclose.
—Do you even know?
—Order! The Minister is answering a very serious question.

—I know what the ultimate source is but I received it on a confidential basis and therefore will not disclose it. As for Senator Crichton- Browne's denial, he has denied before things of which he was not accused. I reported the facts concerning what was written on those cheque butts. I might add that Senator Crichton-Browne's definition in the past of what is a direct or indirect interest has been shown to be different from that which most people would adopt as defining a direct or indirect interest. For example, he held the position of mining registrar at Marble Bar at the same time as he held, I think, 5,000 shares in Burrill Investments, which was a company set up--
—More lies.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. The honourable senator will withdraw that remark.
—I apologise, Mr President. One cannot help but be tempted to object as long as that man states untruths. But I withdraw in accordance with your request.
—The honourable senator has withdrawn. I call the Minister.

—I was drawing attention to the fact that Senator Crichton-Browne' s conception of what is a direct or indirect interest has been shown in the past to be substantially at variance with what most people would conceive to be a direct or indirect interest. He held, I think, 5,000 shares in Burrill Investments, a company which was set up for trading in shares and which, as the Senate committee chaired by Senator Peter Rae showed, was very heavily involved in trading in Poseidon shares at the time the market was being rigged, and that principals of that company were indeed actively involved. I think that a fair description of the findings of Senator Rae's committee is that principals of the company were actively involved in the rigging of that market. The importance of that is that at that time--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I find it very difficult to relate this answer to the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition. It was a simple question asking whether the Minister could or could not vouch for the authenticity of the document presented yesterday. I cannot see that delving into other matters has any relevance to this particular question. I ask you to draw the Minister's attention to that.
—I ask the Minister not to debate the matter, but to relate his remarks to the question that has been asked.

—The question asked included a reference to the statement made by Senator Crichton-Browne following Question Time yesterday. It is with that aspect of the question that I am dealing, since the words 'direct or indirect interest' were used by Senator Crichton-Browne. At the time he was a shareholder in Burrill Investments, under circumstances which I have described, he was also the mining registrar in Marble Bar. Section 8 of the Mining Act of Western Australia, from memory, states that no person who holds the position of registrar or warden is permitted to hold a direct or indirect interest in any company associated with mining.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne was ultimately charged under this Act and acquitted. I do not have time to go into a critique of the way in which the Crown presented its case, but I would be happy to do so at some other time. Senator Crichton- Browne obviously saw no problem in being the mining registrar at Marble Bar and being a substantial shareholder in a company which was dealing in Poseidon shares in a rigged market which that company had helped to rig. He saw no conflict between simultaneously being a major shareholder in that company and holding the position of mining registrar at Marble Bar in spite of the strictures of section 8 of the Western Australian Mining Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. How long are you going to put up with this diatribe from the honourable gentleman, who is not relating his remarks at all to the question that was asked? Are you going to go down as the President who lets Ministers get away with things like this?
—Order! The Chair will not be subjected to threats like that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sir John Carrick

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 418 and specifically to the words:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

I put to you, Mr President, that you have been listening to imputations against a member of this Senate and that they ought to be ruled out of order. The Minister ought to be called to order because he is in defiance of standing order 418.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the Minister that he relate his remarks very much to the question that has been asked by Senator Chaney. I really feel that the Minister is tending to debate the issue now, and he should very much relate any future remarks to the question.

—I was about to finish my remarks, Mr President. I have one thing to add and that is that what is direct or indirect interest is obviously for some people a matter for subjective judgment. I am not sure what Senator Crichton-Browne had in mind when he stated yesterday that he had no direct or indirect interest.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the Minister is not prepared to answer the question, I ask him again whether he has seen the originals of the documents that he produced the photocopies of. Can he vouch for the copies being true copies of the originals? Can he tell the Senate when the documents were written and by whom they were written? Is he in any position to say whether what was written is correct or incorrect?

—I can answer most of the questions that Senator Chaney has asked but I do not believe it would be possible to do so without disclosing a source which I regard as confidential. I noticed that one of the colleagues of the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Repesentatives yesterday quoted what was said in an anonymous telephone call made to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I have taken considerable steps to follow through the authenticity of the cheques. I have no reason to believe that the photocopies tabled yesterday are not photocopies of original cheques.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON STATUTORY AUTHORITY FINANCING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Statutory Authority Financing, volume 2, together with the transcript of evidence presented to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is volume 2 of the report of the Select Committee on Statutory Authority Financing. The report itself is very brief, but included is an econometric study prepared by a consultant to the Committee, Dr C. R. Weston, entitled 'Estimating the Impact of Statutory Authorities on the Australian Economy'. Also attached is the transcript of evidence of hearings held by the former Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations about the operation of the Australian Loan Council, and the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and their impact in relation to capital markets and statutory authority borrowings. The copy of the report that will be circulated today does not have the transcript of evidence attached, as a bound copy of the report is in course of preparation by the Government Printer. Until the bound copy is available copies of the transcript are available on request from the Secretary to the Committee. This is the Select Committee's final report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (SIMULTANEOUS ELECTIONS) BILL 1983CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ADVISORY JURISDICTION OF HIGH COURT) BILL 1983
CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (REMOVAL OF OUTMODED AND EXPENDED PROVISIONS) BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to this cognate debate on five Government and four private members' measures for the alteration of the Constitution. I believe that the second reading debate we have just now completed has been an important and interesting one, not only for those of us who are interested in this sort of thing, but also for the Australian community generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The five Government measures, which I am pleased to say have secured very general, if not unanimous, support in this chamber, deal respectively with simultaneous elections, four-year terms, the inter-change of powers, advisory opinions from the High Court and the removal of obsolete and expended provisions . It is proper that they should have been generally supported because they are all measures which have received either unanimous or very strong cross-party support at successive sessions of the Australian Constitutional Convention. Equally, it is proper that they should have been supported, because all of them do a great deal to improve the machinery of government, the quality of democratic government in this country.

It is not sufficient, of course, for Senator Withers to appreciate the merits of the Bills in these terms. He has described the measures before us as, if put to the people, generating a trivia-led recovery. I simply say that the only recovery that Senator Withers could ever lead would be a cynicism-led recovery, because he showed that quality in ample abundance today, and regrettably, that was the only positive quality that he was able to bring to this debate.

The measures that have been advanced by the Government, despite the occasional fire and brimstone that has been directed at them from various parts opposite, have survived this debate with flying colours. As to the first two matters, simulated elections and four-year terms, each of these Bills deals with some of the reasons for the ludicrously frequent elections in Australia. Simultaneous elections will deal with the problem of dislocation of election dates. Whilst it may be theoretically possible to keep election dates in phase without the passage of this measure, the vagaries of political life in this country are such that to do so over a lengthy period is simply not practical, and that has been amply demonstrated in the election pattern of the last 20 years.

The four-year terms proposal deals with the assocated problem that the present three-year terms of Parliament, which have themselves been in practice much less than that-an average of two years and five months over the whole period since the last war-are simply too short to provide the proper conditions for good government and for long term planning. The reality is, as I think Senator Durack rather nicely and succinctly put it, that we have had too many elections in this country and too many opportunities for the Houses to get out of phase; and I might add-I am sure that he would accept this-that we have had too many short term governments trying to cope with the complexities of government over the recent decades.

It is true that two other reasons for early elections, the Prime Minister's right to call an early election and the Senate's powers to force an early election, are not addressed by these Bills in the way in which they were by the fixed term measure now withdrawn for want of bipartisan support. But it does not follow that either of these Bills creates problems, as I think Senator Macklin, for one, was wont to say. What they do is partially, but very significantly, solve the problem of too frequent elections and all the problems of governing well that flow from that.

There is no doubt that there have been too many elections in this country for rational government. I do not think that any better demonstration of that was given during the course of this debate than the passage in Senator Richardson's speech when he described the experience of a New South Wales elector over the last two decades. Taking into account both Federal and State elections, there has been an election in that State almost every year since 1961. I repeat Senator Richardson's litany for the record because it graphically makes the point: In 1961, a Federal election; in 1962, a State election; in 1963, another Federal election; in 1964, a half Senate election; in 1965, a State election; in 1966, a Federal election; in 1967, a half Senate election; in 1968, a State election; in 1969, a Federal election; in 1970, a half Senate election; in 1971, a State election; in 1972, a Federal election; in 1973, a State election; in 1974 and 1975, double dissolutions at the Federal level; in 1976, another State election; in 1977, an early Federal election; in 1978, a State election; in 1979 , no elections; in 1980, another Federal election; in 1981, a State election; in 1982, another vintage year, as Senator Richardson describes it; but then back to the polls again in March 1983. Even the most dedicated democrat would, I think, regard that as a surfeit of the democratic process and manifestly absurd in a country of any size or of any governing structure.

Senator Crichton-Browne was inclined to make the debating point that the simultaneous elections Bill will not guarantee fewer elections. He says-and this is a point made by other speakers in the debate-that the simultaneous elections proposal will not prevent a Prime Minister from calling an election whenever he feels so inclined. That point can be made as a debating point. But it needs to be well and truly appreciated that there are political sanctions now very evident against a Prime Minister calling too many early elections. No one is better aware of the force of those political sanctions than the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. He made his discovery-as Mr Corcoran in South Australia had done before him a couple of years earlier-on 5 March this year. This Bill will reduce the number of elections by removing the necessity to have either separate half Senate and House of Representatives elections or early House of Representatives elections.

The other major form of opposition that was expressed, such as it was, to the simultaneous elections Bill came from a number of sources. I think that Senator Hill was the most articulate expresser of them. He talked in terms of prejudicing the position of the Senate, pressing the point of view that the simultaneous elections proposal would somehow reflect on the status and more particularly the powers of the Senate. But as with the breaking the nexus proposal-which I note, incidentally, that Senator Hill supports-simultaneous elections would not reduce in any way the powers of the Senate. The influence of senators depends on their quality, not upon their numbers; nor does it depend on the time at which they are elected. It is nonsense to say that this chamber goes about its political business quite independently, isolated in some kind of bubble from the events in the other place across Kings Hall. The very interdependence of the respective chambers in our system was again amply demonstrated by the March election this year when the Senate, minding its own business at the time, was dragged untimely to the polls by virtue of the double dissolution called by Mr Fraser as a result of a much earlier deadlock. That is a matter to which we shall come later. I note that Senator Hamer beams whenever that particular subject arises.

Simultaneous elections would, of course-and this is the last word on this subject for the moment; there will be many more in the months ahead-produce a more representative chamber in that the composition of the Senate would reflect the will of the people at least as it stood at the time that the House of Representatives was elected. The absurd situation to which Senator Tate referred , of newly elected senators being in limbo for seven months and retiring possibly defeated senators continuing to serve for seven months after their defeat, would also clearly be avoided. That is another incidental benefit of this measure.

The interchange of powers proposal has not attracted as much excitement as the first two Government Bills, on simultaneous elections and four-year terms, but nonetheless there was a degree of dissent, or perhaps neurosis is a better expression, expressed by one or two senators about it. Senator Durack and, I think, Senator Hamer were a bit inclined to say that this is an inconsequential matter, a mere tinkering with the Constitution. Whilst I agree that it may not quite have the crowd pleasing appeal of some of the other matters that we will be debating, it is, nonetheless, a very important machinery measure and it has very great potential for improving the quality and the rationality of government arrangements in this country.

Certainly it is not the view of the States that this is in any way an inconsequential or minor or trivial matter. They have consistently provided very strong support for the proposal at successive Constitutional Conventions, going right back to the first in 1973. At the Adelaide Convention in April this year, Mr Cain, for example, said:

Interchange of powers would enable these problems of the Constitution to be dealt with efficiently in a way that could be tailored to meet the immediate need. It would not be necessary for powers to be referred all the time. If a deficiency of a power were a short term problem, as might be the case in some economic matters, it could be referred for a limited time. If a power, once referred, did not operate as intended, perhaps because of changed circumstances or an unexpected judicial interpretation, the reference could be amended. It could then be open to the referring parliament to monitor the use of the power.
The key point is that as the needs of the components of the Federation change, so must the capacity to meet these needs.

The great utility of this particular proposal is that the locking in of the distribution of powers that was bequeathed to us by those founding fathers-who people like Senator Walters would, on selective occasions, elevate to the status of saints when it comes to enshrining their words and intepretations for all time-has led to some of that power distribution being manifestly inappropriate in the circumstances in which we find ourselves in the latter part of the twentieth century. By means of the interchange of powers proposal it is possible , with a co-operative approach to these matters between the governments in our federation, to resolve the problems that arise in a far less dramatic or far reaching way than is involved in having to go to the people for approval at a referendum. It is a thoroughly useful means-not an end in itself because it is only a preliminary to further negotiations of power distribution-of establishing machinery for a rational solution of these problems.

The other kind of objection, apart from the inconsequentiality point, was made during the debate, I think in particular by Senator Jessop, who expressed his profound suspicion at the interchange of powers proposal because he said a Labor federal government could centralise power by getting Labor State governments to refer their powers in a wholesale manner. Would that he only knew the difficulties that are involved in any exercise of this kind, even with the rather easier machinery that is now proposed. Of course there is already provision, in section 51 (xxxvii) of the Constitution, for State references to be made, albeit hedged about with uncertainties which have made it difficult for that clause to be relied upon by anyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you getting on with the reference of power in family law ?

—That is a very pertinent observation and I have to acknowledge the force of it. The reality is that State governments of any political colour are always reluctant to refer powers, however rational a case may be made for so doing. So far as State references are concerned, the proposal will simply clear up some of the uncertainties and worries which have been expressed by States in the past as to whether references can be revoked and so on. For the first time we have a reciprocal flavour coming into this matter of references of power being able to go the other way, from the Commonwealth to the States. That makes a much greater set of attractions for those sitting down to the bargaining table.

SPEECH.PARA: Advisory opinions came in for some flack, notably from Senator Lewis. His views were wrong-headed, for the most part, as we have come to expect from the honourable senator. Of course the advisory opinions proposal, expressed in a nutshell, is designed to create a jurisdiction in the High Court which will allow the Commonwealth and the States respectively to test the constitutional validity of their own major initiatives and also some heads of existing legislation which have remained for practical purposes untestable under the present situation of requiring a plaintiff with the standing and the willingness to run the case appearing in the latter category. I mention in particular those notoriously ambiguous provisions concerning the qualifications of members of parliament to serve in this place, contained in sections 44 and 45 of the Constitution.

It has long been thought highly desirable that there be a series of clarifying decisions made by the High Court as to what exactly these provisions do and do not require and whether for example, it is strictly necessary for people who are in Public Service employment to stand down from that employment for long, weary months, in the case of Senate candidates in particular, as is the case under the present arrangements, because they have technically been elected but are not yet able to take their places. The situation is that in this kind of matter no potential plaintiff has ever been willing to take the risk of an adverse finding and as a result genuine injustices have been caused to many individuals over many decades because of the absence of a simply advisory jurisdiction vested in the High Court to enable it to resolve, without risk to litigants of this kind, particular matters.

But none of these considerations was good enough for opponents of the measure, such as they were, like Senator Lewis. He peppered his contribution to the debate with a series of quite inaccurate readings or understandings of the present situation. In particular, he said that the advisory opinions jurisdiction had fallen into disuse in Canada; it had not been used at all in the last few decades. That is simply not true. It was used in 1976 in relation to important economic legislation, the Anti-Inflation Act of 1976 and in 1981 in relation to the issue of the patriation of the Canadian Constitution. Of the 282 leading constitutional cases in Canadian law, which had reached either the Privy Council, prior to 1947, or the Supreme Court up to 1981, 77 were referenes under the advisory jurisdiction power. It has been used-though not with the kind of floodgates frequency that has been predicted by opponents with another point of view about this legislation-as an appropriate way of getting particular matters or particular occasions before the highest authority and to get decisions out of that authority in appropriate circumstances.

It was said also in relation to the advisory opinions Bill that it would take away from the power of the Parliament and put the Court midway between a judicial body and an executive body. Of course the Parliament's views as to the validity of its laws should be given weight by the Court. No doubt they are given weight but they can never be conclusive, and the absence of an expression of that view in the context of a proposed enactment or Bill will not seriously inhibit either the Court's capacity to adjudicate or Parliament's capacity to influence the course of that adjudication. The exercise of advisory jurisdiction is a function that is entirely appropriate to a judical body. The Privy Council has always had an advisory jurisdiction and expressed surprise as long ago as 1912 that the appropriateness of its exercising that jurisdiction should ever be questioned. Other particular objections were made to the advisory opinions matter and, if they are raised again in the Committee stage, perhaps it will be more appropriate for me to deal with them in detail there.

Finally, as to the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill, given grudging support I noticed in some instances and rather more wholehearted support in others, I simply make this point: Nobody suggests that this particular measure is in any way necessary. Clearly these provisions that are about to be removed-we hope-are not doing any particular damage by remaining there, cluttering up the Constitution, but their removal would be desirable if we want to get to a situation where the Constitution is perceived not as a dusty, musky, unreadable collection of lawyers' language from yesteryear but rather a living, breathing document that does have some relevance and some utility to the people of this country. It is only by gaining an appreciation of what the document is all about and what it provides for that we will ever develop any real momentum towards changing what needs to be changed in our present constitutional arrangements. It is an exercise, if you like, in conscienceness raising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get the Parliamentary Counsel to be more concise if you want a short, clear Constitution?

—That is a labour of Hercules but precision is the name of the game when it comes to the drafting of these particular matters and, faced with a choice between prolixity and precision, unfortunately precision tends to win every time at the expense of often excessive prolixity. Maybe it is not excessive. It is an age old problem, no less in constitutional matters than elsewhere. In fact, it is a greater problem in constitutional matters because we only get one bite at the cherry. It is not easy to come along and spend $15m to $20m of taxpayers' money to resolve a drafting problem.

SPEECH.PARA: So much for the Government's Bills. I believe they will be supported and I am indebted, as I said, to the majority of the honourable senators for the support they have given them. More quickly, may I indicate the Government's attitude to the private members' Bills that have been introduced, perhaps beginning with Senator Rae's Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill. I think the only remotely respectable aspect of this proposal so far as the Government is concerned is that it would require the Senate to go to the polls to face an election in the event that it exercised its Supply-blocking power. However, as to its basic substance, its picking up of the so-called Sir Charles Court resolution at the earlier Australian Constitutional Convention makes it completely unacceptable to the Labor Government. That will not be news to any honourable senator. What it does is simply institutionalise the outrage of 1975. So far from discouraging the Senate from exercising the manifestly excessive powers it has to determine not just the content of legislation but the life or death of properly elected governments, those manifestly excessive powers will not only not be curbed in any way by this particular measure but also their exercise will positively be encouraged. There is no question under any circumstances of this measure achieving any support whatsoever from this side of the House. I have no doubt at all that Senator Rae appreciates the fate in store for him, if not here today, then certainly in the other place.

Senator Hamer's double dissolution anti-stockpiling measure is a rather different kettle of fish. I acknowledge that it is a much more difficult matter with which to come to grips in terms of doing the right thing. Senator Hamer's measure proposes that the right to set in train a double dissolution lapses if it is not exercised within three months, the objective being to confine the double dissolution procedure to situations related to the particular measure which is the subject of the double dissolution, and to ensure that the original purpose of section 57 of the Constitution has a better chance of being observed, that is, the double dissolution existing not as a convenient device for an early election but rather as a way of dissolving a genuine deadlock. Of course, there is no guarantee that Senator Hamer's measure would ensure that the double dissolution procedure is used only in relation to genuine as distinct from artificial or contrived deadlocks. I do not take Senator Hamer to be suggesting otherwise. All he claims is that there will be a better chance of the genuine ones being sifted out.

Another aspect of Senator Hamer's measure which he does not trumpet but which does make it attractive to honourable senators on this side of the chamber is, of course, that it would tend to make rather more difficult a recurrence of the circumstances of 1974 and 1975, when a money Bill was rejected in this place in circumstances where the allowing of a full three months to elapse would not have been a realistic option but where the existence of stockpiled double-rejected Bills from earlier controversies made it possible for the double dissolution option to be a genuine one to be waved over the head of the government of the day. Senator Hamer's proposal would make it very much more difficult for that kind of situation to arise and, as such, it has its attractions.

The difficulties about it from the Government's point of view which lead us ultimately to vote against it are these: First of all, and less significantly, there are some practical but significant drafting difficulties with the measure as it comes forward. There is a real uncertainty still, even after the Petroleum and Minerals Authority case in the High Court of Australia, as to the meaning of the expression 'fails to pass' and as to the question, accordingly, as to when time begins to run from a deadlock, when a deadlock exists and when it concludes for the purposes of the operation of this legislation. The Bill simply does not resolve any uncertainty of this kind. We are left with genuine doubts as to how it would apply in many different practical circumstances. Rather more significantly than that technical defect, which might be able to be fixed up by appropriate drafting at the Committee stage, is the point that it is simply not practical, from the point of view of a democratically elected government of the day trying to get on with the business of implementing the job it was mandated to do by the electors, to be without any really effective remedy so far as a recalcitrant Senate is concerned. It ought to be possible for the government of the day to be able to store up its grievances, as it were, in situations where what I described earlier in the debate as the death of a thousand cuts is inflicted upon it by a hostile upper House.

One of the difficulties that were experienced, for example, by the Whitlam Government in 1972 was that almost from its first day the hostile majority confronting it in the Senate did not use its power in respect of money Bills but emasculated or refused to pass or otherwise tore apart other pieces of legislation that the Whitlam Government put up. That happened over and over again. It was simply not practical politics, nor would it be for any government in like circumstances, immediately to take one such measure to a double dissolution election. In the event, that occurred in 1974 in slightly different circumstances. Under those circumstances a government ought to be able to store up the measures that are dealt with in this way. If its patience is finally tested to the point that it has to take one such measure, or all of them, as a basis for a double dissolution and if the electorate endorses that course of action and returns it with a resounding majority and a renewed mandate, then the existing procedures will, of course, allow a joint sitting to be held. Not just one particular measure but all of the measures that have been the subject of such hostile treatment from the Senate could then be disposed of simultaneously. That ultimately, I think, becomes the reason why this Government, although weighing very seriously the merits of Senator Hamer's proposal, because they are evident, comes down on the side of resistance to the blandishments in question.

The third measure concerns the nexus and was introduced by Senator Macklin. The Government's attitude to this, I think, can be described in the language of St Augustine: 'God give me chastity, but not yet.' In other words, we approve of this particular measure. We will support its passage through this chamber. We believe it ultimately ought to be put to the Australian people but we do not believe that the right time to do so is next February, with the other referendum proposals. Accordingly, we will hold it in store, as it were, in the House of Representatives and give very serious consideration to moving it and putting it before the people at some more appropriate later time.

The reasons why we take this attitude, approving as we do of the basic principles of the measure, are these: We believe it would impossibly complicate the other referendums if this particular proposal, with all the passion- irrational as it may be, but passion nonetheless-that it arouses were to be put to the people. The highest number of proposals ever carried at a single referendum was the carriage of three out of the four proposals that were put in 1977. The only other occasion on which six proposals were put was in 1913, when all of them failed. One reason which has been constantly put forward by commentators for the poor success rate of referendums has been this practice of putting a large number of proposals at the same time. We think we can do that, at least to the extent of five measures, on this occasion because of the interrelated machinery of government and largely uncontroversial character of them. But to add a sixth proposal and to add one which will be controversial will not help in getting any of them up. We believe accordingly, given the possibilities of irrational States rights passions, plus some other practical technical considerations involved in getting the legislation to do with the redistribution in place early next year, that it is simply not practical politics, as much as it is attractive in principle, to contemplate the nexus referendum going forward.

Finally, of course, there is the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1982 introduced by the Australian Democrats. A number of rude things have been said about this measure by a number of honourable senators in this place. I simply add that it would clearly constitute, were it enacted, a paradise for single-issue loonies in this country. We do believe in representative and responsible government as the appropriate way of going about the nation's business. We are worried about the way in which crude appeals to prejudice and self-interest would be encouraged by this. We are worried about the ease with which even this target of 250,000 votes could be satisfied and the ease, accordingly, with which the Treasury would be subjected to regular bills of $15m to $20m for putting to referendum proposals which manifestly ought to be better dealt with by the people's representatives in this Parliament. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. I urge them to vote in the way I have suggested.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 12 May 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) the point to which I referred at the second reading stage of the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill. I can understand the argument that is advanced in favour of a clarification of the powers of the Commonwealth to interchange certain powers with the States. Nevertheless, I raise the converse situation-that is, the interchange of powers from the States to the Commonwealth. Say one State cedes power to the Commonwealth on a matter for which the States have powers. How does the Attorney-General see that affecting the other States, given the fact that, should this occur, the Commonwealth Government, through legislation, could provide for more favourable treatment to that State in respect of the areas of that power? Is it the intention of this legislation that the power be ceded by all of the States or by none of the States?

—The short answer, as I understand the situation, is that existing section 51 (xxxvii.) of the Constitution, which is not being altered in this respect, makes it absolutely clear that the power of the Commonwealth extends only to that State from which the reference has originally come. Under those circumstances the Commonwealth achieves no power in relation to States other than the State from which the reference has originally arisen.

—I understand that. The point I made concerned the intention of the Government. For example, the State of Victoria could cede certain powers in respect of registration fees for motor vehicles. The Commonwealth Parliament could make a law in respect of that matter which could be seen by the people of Australia as being most favourable for the motorists of one particular State and thus, by such financial inducement, could encourage other States to cede powers in respect of the same matter. Of course, to preclude that we would have to amend the Constitution. Presumably, if powers are to be ceded they ought to be ceded by all the States rather than one. Am I right in stating that to achieve that would require a different amendment to the Constitution?

—Yes, Senator Harradine is right in stating that. The consequence does, I suppose, follow that the Commonwealth could legislate in a manner favourable or perceived to be favourable for a particular State if it is only that State that has given the Commonwealth the wherewithal to do so and that that may attract a twinge of jealousy from other States-
—That is available to them now.

—That is available to them now under 51 (xxxvii.) of the Constitution. We would have to amend existing section 51 (xxxvii.) to counter that rather than anything to that effect being achieved by the new sections 108A and 108B proposed in this Bill.

—I ask the Attorney-General: If, for instance, all States except one were to agree to certain powers going to the Commonwealth, would the provisions of this Bill impose any pressures which could in any way force or coerce that one State into joining the other States?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no such provision, but how could that State be so coerced? For the last 83 years we have been living with this provision which has made it possible for just that state of affairs to occur. It is a practical political matter which simply has not arisen, nor could one see how in practice it might arise. I confess that I am unable to appreciate the point the honourable senator is making.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
