DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ADVISORY JURISDICTION OF HIGH COURT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 May 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subject to an arranged agreement between the Government and the Opposition, because of an undertaking that has been made, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement I have in respect of this matter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted provided it is understood that its standing there in splendid isolation in the Hansard does not mean that everthing in it is not rejected out of hand by the Government.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr President, I notice that inasmuch as the debate so far on the nine Constitutional Alteration Bills has been a cognate debate, little comment has been made upon the Constitutional Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill.

The Bill proposes as we are told in the explanatory memorandum to enable the Commonwealth and State Governments and a Territory Government to obtain advisory opinions from the High Court on specific types of questions. The Bill is so framed as to confine the jurisdiction to cases of enactments actually passed or already before a Commonwealth or State Parliament, or a Territory Legislature, and to certain other constitutional or treaty questions that have actually arisen or are reasonably likely to arise, the Commonwealth, State or Territory Government concerned may only seek an advisory opinion on the validity of an enactment or proposed enactment passed by or before its own parliament or legislature.

The Bill intends by its wording that the Federal Government or more correctly the executive will be able not only to refer enactments or legislation which has been passed by both Houses of the parliament but also proposed enactments or laws.

In other words the Government of the day will be able to simply introduce legislation into the House of Representatives and then send it off to the High Court for a compulsory advisory opinion by not less than five Justices and then presumably that decision will result in precedent and stature with any other High Court decision.
Mr President, while I have grave concern for the full implications and ramifications of the Bill I see particular dangers in including proposed legislation.

The effect of that is that the High Court will become legal advisors to parliamentary draftsmen to the Government of the day. Further, not only may the determination have the effect of pressurising either or both Houses of the Parliament, but it will presume to bypass the Parliamentary system.

It seems to me not only improper but quite impertinent for an executive government to bypass the two Houses of Parliament and go straight to the High Court for a legal judgment on a piece of legislation which has not had a political judgment cast upon it.
The High Court should be dealing with matters of law, not proposals or suggestions of legislation that the government of the day is toying around with.

It is for the Parliament to determine in which form the legislation will be when it arrives at the High Court for a legal opinion. It is for the Parliament to make decisions about the validity of its laws and to take the responsibility which has been vested in it as an elected body by the voters of Australia.
A vital part of the function of the Federal Parliament I would have thought was to make good and proper laws for the good Government of Australia.

As was said by Felix Frankfurter, Professor and later Justice of the Supreme Court of the USA, when commenting upon such matters ''another commonplace, indispensable to the effective working of our constitutional system, is rigorous regard in practice for the avowed theory that legislation is for the legislature , that the court does not sit in judgment upon the wisdom or fairness or utility of legislation.''

If a proposed law is referred to the High Court for a legal opinion and either House subsequently amends it, do I take it that the Bill being referred by the Senate back to the House of Representatives for further consideration will then be again sent off to the High Court for a further determination as the whether or not those amendments are constitutional and if not constitutional is the High Court then asked to spell out which amendments are acceptable and which are not.
It would be an intolerable way to try to legislate. The debate would not be about the merit and virtue of the content of the proposed law but rather whether it was constitutional in part or in full.

In essence the daily role and function of the two chambers would be gutted. The Parliament would come by nature to rely more and more upon the High Court for an interpretation of its proposed laws and amendments. Debate would in many cases become stifled and academic.

Debates of the virile and robust nature such as we saw in the south west Tasmanian dams case would no longer be a part of our daily lives. There would be little point arguing the social, political or economic virtues of such issues if the fate of the proposed legislation is to be predetermined by the High Court after an undebated first reading in either house of the parliament.

The great and real issues of the nature of the Tasmanian dams legislation are not whether it is constitutional but rather whether or not the function ought properly, as distinct from legally, to rest with the Commonwealth or the states and I might add had those debates not taken place both within and without the parliament many of the political, social and economic issues would never have been ventilated and public awareness would not have been stimulated.

Advisory opinion may well cause parliaments and people to fall into the habit of assuming that whatever they can do constitutionally they may do. As if the merits, honesty and fair dealing of legislation were not relevant to their inquiries.

It is my view that State Commonwealth relations should be worked out and accommodated more by the play of political forces rather than the forced and imposed sterility of a High Court advisory opinion.
Clearly one of the purposes of including the proposed law provisions is to ensure that the bill intended by the government is in no way defective.
Surely that assumes that the High Court is the only competent body of legal opinion in Australia capable of making such a judgment.

I would have thought that the Attorney-General's Department which is presumably there for that purpose would have men who can justify their enormous salaries by giving good legal advice to the government.

If the government is not satisfied with those whom it expressly employs for the purpose there is nothing to stop it doing what it has in the past and seeking legal opinions from the best legal brains in private practice.
Of course there is unlimited talent that the government can call upon but that opinion is not final, absolute or authoritative.

What the government is seeking through this constitutional amendment is to get an irrefutable and in many respects irreversible decision. The High Court will be reluctant to go back on its earlier decision.
It is not looking for a legal opinion, it is seeking to bind others, whether they be individuals, corporations or sovereign states with a legal judgment even before the bill becomes law.

If as I said earlier there are some aspects of the proposed legislation which are defective the government is capable of continuing to resubmit new and differently drafted legislation until it gets it right.
It wants not only a legal judgment of what it intends, but advice on how to achieve it-hardly the role of the High Court.
This may apply to both a proposed law or an enactment but we may well find a complex piece of legislation which contains two or three hundred separate provisions.
The legislation is referred to the High Court in an abstract way as distinct from fact-and I will come to that later.

The Court, to determine the validity of the bill or act, will not only have to go through it clause by clause but if it is to be of any benefit to the government offer advice as to what will remedy the defects.
If the High Court is to give bland or very guarded advisory opinions on most occasions they will be of very little help.

Mr President if legislation presented to the High Court for an advisory opinion has not been enacted then it is quite irrelevant, and if in the event it is enacted then of course the advisory opinion becomes unnecessary because appropriate action can be taken by any interested party on the basis of real facts and a proper tangible case.

Notwithstanding the fact that the Attorney-General claims in his second reading speech that provision is made for facts to be specified in some detail for the purpose of a reference and where necessary, for references to be amended, one of the fundamental problems of advisory opinions is that they are not based on concrete facts but abstract considerations lacking under this legislation an effected litigant.

To quote Lord Sarkey of the Canadian Privy Council: 'We sympathise with the view as to the difficulty which the court must experience in endeavouring to answer questions put in this way. It is true that the advisability of propounding for the consideration of the court abstract questions involving considerations of debatable fact is to say the least, doubtful'.

Dixon, C. J. said in Commonwealth Freighters v. Sneddon. 'Highly inconvenient as it may be, it is true of some legislative powers by definition . . . that the validity of the exercise of the power must sometimes depend on facts, facts which somehow must be ascertained by the court responsible for deciding the validity of the law.'
There are numerous Canadian examples of abstract advisory opinions being given which have had a serious effect upon the development of both the Canadian constitution and individuals.

In the 1916 Insurance Act reference the Canadian Supreme Court was asked for an opinion as to the validity of certain sections of the Federal Insurance Act. Here was a reference involving the bare question ''are sections 40 and 70 of the Insurance Act 1916 or any and what part or parts of the said sections ultra vires of the Parliament of Canada?''

Following decisions litigated on fact demonstrated that the result of the 1916 Insurance Reference, being an abstract decision which had far reaching and unfortunate consequences would have been quite different if it too had been litigated on concrete fact.
There have been a number of other cases in Canada which have had the same effect.

The 1916 Insurance Reference was influential in a number of later cases where Parliament was denied the power to cope with nation-wide commercial problems because this was characterised as regulation of a particular trade within each province.

To quote one prominent Professor of Law B. L. Strayer from the University of Toronto. Referring to this case ''reference decisions have tended to be abstract . It also demonstrates the great and largely unfortunate effect which such decisions have had on Canadian constitutional development. Indeed one can argue that reference decisions are more likely to have a widespread effect because of the circumstances in which the reference technique is frequently used. Governments are most likely to refer to the courts legislation which is not only constitutionally questionable but also controversial because of its economic, political or social importance. Thus references are particularly dangerous because the opinion subsequently rendered by the court will naturally have far reaching implications.

As Felix Frankfurter, a leading American Jurist, further observed ''the whole milieu of advisory opinions on proposed Bills is inevitably different from that of litigation contesting legislation. However much provision may be made on paper for adequate arguments advisory opinions are bound to move in a unreal atmosphere. The impact of actuality and the intensities of immediacy are wanting . In the attitude of court and council, in the vigour of adequate representation of the facts behind legislation there is thus a wide gulf of difference, partly rooted in psychological factors, between opinions in advance of legislation and decisions in litigation after such proposals are embodied into law. Advisory opinions are rendered upon sterilized and mutilated issues.''

Frankfurter goes on to recite a number of cases in which advisory opinions were handed down by the Massachusetts Court only to be eventually overturned by the Supreme Court of the United States when they were litigated upon fact. In the meantime there had been a misstatement of the law and a great deal of damage done.
To quote Frankfurter again because I believe he puts the position so precisely and lucidly:

''Not the least of constitutional controversies resolve themselves into the pressure of new facts against the resistance of inadequate or exploded facts persisting as legal assumptions. The reports furnish too abundant illustrations of what Huxley called the tragedy of a fact killing a theory.''

''The advisory opinion deprives constitutional interpretation of the judgment of the legislature upon facts, of the effectual defence of legislation as an application of settled legal principles to new situations and of the means of securing new facts through the process of legislation within the allowable limits of trial and error.''

What has been clearly demonstrated over very many years is that to fully understand and appreciate the effect and ramifications of legislation it must be enacted and implemented. The reality of the real world is that very often legislation has effects which were never intended or contemplated by the lawmakers of the day.
It is quite impossible to test most laws until they are implemented and take effect.

As the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia who has publicly condemned this proposed constitutional amendment said: ''Under the proposal made by the constituional convention'' which of course is now the form of this legislation, ''the court would be required to consider questions in the abstract, and possibly before the practical implications of the legislation have come to be fully understood. Experience suggests that when a statute is sought to be applied in a situation which was not within the comtemplation of the draftsman, questions of interpretation and validity arise which would have passed unobserved if the effect of the statute had been considered in the abstract.''
The proposal can do nothing other than provide and ultimately guarantee greater power in the hands of the Central Federal Government and dilute and erode even further the power of the States.

No doubt the questions which will most often be put by the Federal Government to the High Court for an advisory opinion will be those related to treaties and the constitutional power of the Federal Government vis a vis the States.

This Government will seek to explore further and further the limits of its jurisdiction under the constitution with a view to gathering unto the Central Government more and more power at the expense of the individual States.

We have already seen what can only be described as obscene abuse of the external affairs powers and no doubt areas such as the implied national power, the corporations power and . . . will be tested to their very limits.

Already we have seen the external affairs powers used in the Tasmanian dams case and the Sexual Discrimination Bill and clearly the intention of including clause 2 (1)D which reads inter alia ''any question of law arising under or with respect to any treaty, including any question of law relating to the implementation of any treaty, being a question that, by reason of circumstances existing at the time of the reference, the Governor-General in Council is of opinion has arisen or is reasonably likely to arise'' is to test the ultimate extent to which the external affairs powers can be used to impose federal laws upon the States and to take from the States that power and jurisdiction which they have exercised since Federation. The brief history of this Government has demonstrated an unbridled ambition to intrude by whatever means available into the traditional responsibilities of the States and this constitutional amendment can only greatly speed up and expedite that process.

It ought to be noted that in the case of treaties it need not even be a matter that is before the Parliament. This is really a question of the Cabinet going straight to the High Court without any contemplation or consideration by either House of Parliament.

The proposed Constitutional Alteration Bill before us specifically excludes individual citizens from seeking an advisory opinion from the High Court on any of the matters referred to in the Bill and yet a great many of the matters it is proposed to submit to the High Court for such an opinion do and will touch upon the lives of every individual Australian.

It is of course argued that theoretically the opinions are merely advisory though of course opinions rendered are bound to embarrass the administration of justice when the subject of an earlier opinion is brought before the courts on a later occasion by genuine litigants.

It ought also to be remembered that on a reference under this Bill the court shall be constituted by not less than 5 Justices and under those circumstances they would not be human if they were not tempted to maintain their earlier position. To do otherwise continuously can only bring the court into disrepute.
In 1898, the Canadian Privy Council, in an important constitutional reference, made its position known. Delivering the opinion of the Board, Lord Herschell declared:

''Their Lordships must decline to answer the last question submitted as to the rights of riperian proprietors. These proprietors are not parties to this legislation or represented before their Lordships, and accordingly their Lordships do not think it proper when determining the respective rights and jurisdiction of the dominion and provincial legislatures to express an opinion upon the extent of the rights possesed by riperian proprietors.''
In the references, Idington J. considered the question from its second aspect: Embarrassment of the administration of justice.

''What would be the thought of a judge, he asked, who had expressed to a private litigant an opinion more or less deliberate upon questions the answers to which determine the litigants rights, and who afterwards sat in that litigants case and judged it. Was there not involved in the very essence of what was attempted the taking away of men's rights and liberties without due process of law?''

What more graphic example of the private rights question can be found than in the Canadian marriage laws reference? In that case the Supreme Court refused to answer one of the questions on the grounds that it was a question which affected private rights and private interests which were not represented before the court . The question was whether the law of Quebec rendered null and void unless contracted before a Roman Catholic Priest, marriages between persons of certain religious faiths.

In the view of council for Quebec a question could hardly be submitted which involved a declaration which would not only cause disturbance, but would put the ban of absolute nullity upon scores of marriages of persons who were not represented before the court.

While one may argue that the opinion rendered would only be advisory, yet if the opinion favoured nullity, it would affect the name and fame and standing of every person married under the conditions set forth in the question as well as the children.

The court upheld the argument and Idington J. said in part ''I admit this case involves . . . what I had conceived to be the vicious principle of interrogating judge, it imperils private rights in a way that seems to deprive those concerned of trial by the process of law.''
In the recent case of Attorney-General of Canada V. CPR and CNR Rand J. delivering the judgment had this to say:

''. . . we would be expressing an opinion that might seriously affect private rights in the absence of those claiming them, a step which would be contrary to the fundamental conception of due process, the application of which to opinions of this nature, has long been recognised.''

Mr President, I make these comments because under this bill now before us the High Court is not at liberty to decline to give an opinion, in fact it is compelled to do so and at the same time the bill expressly prohibits individuals appearing before the court.
Mr President, in my view this proposed constitutional amendment rather than be described as granting an advisory power to the High Court ought rather to be described as a delegating power.

There has been a growing trend particularly in recent years for governments to politicise the judiciary and the success of this constitutional amendment can only accelerate that process. It has the effect of course of reducing the power of the parliament while at the same time increasing the control over parliament of the executive.
To reflect for a moment on past events I quote first from Chief Justice W. H. Irvine who in 1923 in writing to the Victorian Government on behalf of the Supreme Court of Victoria had this to say:

The duty of His Majesty's Judges is to hear and determine issues of Fact and of Law arising between the King and a subject, or between a subject and a subject presented in a form enabling judgment to be passed upon them, and when passed to be enforced by a process of law, there begins and ends the function of the judiciary. It is mainly due to the fact that in modern times at least, the judges in all British communities have, except in rare cases confined themselves to this function, that they have attained, and still retain, the confidence of the people. Parliament supported by wise public opinion has jealously guarded the bench from the danger of being drawn into the region of political controversy.''

Regretably governments have more and more in recent years used members of the judiciary to their own perceived advantage, particularly when seeking to deal with complex and controversial social and political issues.

Now while of course to be able to tap the very fine talents and minds of members of the judiciary has in some respects been of very considerable benefit to the community, in my view on balance I think it is wrong and potentially harmful. Not only to the judiciary but to good government and to the Australian parliamentary institution.
The politicizing of the judiciary has not been limited to using judges for public inquiries but has been extended to appointing judges to fill executive positions such as:
Committee of Reference on Defence Force Pay
Ambassador at Large for the Australian Government
Just to list a few, in fact in 1979 Professor Gordon Reid was able to cite something like 20 or more.

Now we are appointing judges of the High Court of Australia to tell not the Parliament but the executive wing of government how to draft its legislation, what the effect of that drafting will be and what will be the status of the legislation if and I repeat if it passes both Houses of Parliament in the form that the High Court determines-as section 2 (2) B says: ''the manner and form required for the passing of a proposed enactment of that Parliament.''

Given that the executive of the day appoints the High Court judges, almost invariably mindful and conscious of their attitude and approach to the interpretation of the Constitution given that as I say they will under this bill be called upon to consider legislation proposed by the Executive, as to its validity and/or faults and finally to provide the Executive with redrafted legislation which will reflect the political intentions of the government of the day one can't help but be drawn to the conclusion that the historic separation of functions and powers of government and the judiciary have been bridged.

We have certainly come a long way since 1793 when the Supreme Court of the United States of America declined a request through Secretary of State Jefferson by President Washington for an advisory opinion relating to certain treaties, laws of nature and nations and the laws of the land which appeared to be impinged upon by the war in Europe.

The Supreme Court declined, emphasising the principle of separation of powers which gives rise to considerations which afford strong arguments against the propriety of extra-judicially deciding the questions alluded to by the courts.
Naturally the government of the day then turned to the Attorney-General of the United States for the advice. The United States of America Supreme Court still does not give advisory opinions.
There are a limited number of State Courts of America that do provide advisory opinions but none by its constitution since 1890 and the last successful attempt by statute was in 1923.

Those courts that do so will not answer questions requiring the determination of a question of fact, nor will they answer questions bearing upon wisdom and expediency as distinguished from power and authority.

They have refused to give opinions on matters that are likely to come before the court for decision. They have consistently refused to answer questions which involved private rights and they have held that it is for the court to determine whether the question comes within the constitutional or statutory language, such as ''solemn occasion'' or ''important question of law''.
Eight of the states that once practised advisory opinions no longer employ it.

In the ten states of the USA where the judges have refused to give advisory opinions the underlying reason was, and is, their belief that since the giving of such opinions is not the exercise of a judicial function, the practice is, in the absence of specific constitutional authorisation, a violation of the doctrine of separation of powers.
Now while the success of this referendum would in Australia provide the constitutional authorisation, it is worth noting the additional comments added by the judges of those ten states.
''generally failure has met attempts by legislation or litigation to employ the courts for legal advice rather than for decision of justifiable controversies between adverse parties.

the impropriety of an unauthorised expression of opinion by a judge or court, especially one of last resort, upon a matter which may subsequently come before the court for adjudication, will immediately suggest itself, the Attorney- General is the officer to advise the civil officers and when questions come before the Supreme Court, that court is then untrammeled.

it would be an attempt to settle questions of law involving the rights of persons without parties before it, or a case to be decided in due course of law, thus violating that provision of the bill of rights which declares that every person shall have a remedy for an injury done him by due course of law''.

Mr President, it was once said unkindly a referendum is the intelligent appealing to the unintelligent, an advisory opinion might well lead the same cynic to observe that such a course is the unintelligent appealing to the intelligent.

Without breaking party room confidentiality, during a party room debate on increases in salaries and pension conditions for members of the high court while at the same time the Prime Minister was calling for Parliamentarians to take a salary cut and the argument being put forward in support of the judges case was that we needed to attract excellent people, I was moved to observe that clearly the logic of the argument was that we needed clever men to interpret the intention of fools.
That in my view ought not be the case, the place for making laws and the responsibility for them should rest with an elected Parliament, not an appointed High Court.

I can find no merit, need or justification for advisory opinions and I think it almost inconceivable that the Labor Government could be serious about including proposed enactments. However if it is felt by some that the present circumstances and rules upon which the Australian High Court provides declaratory judgments are to restrictive and for that reason there ought to be a capacity for advisory opinions, I refer those people to the fact that in American jurisprudence, courts have exerted a certain amount of judgment or discretion in determining whether or not a plaintiff or defendant has a legally defined interest in contesting the validity of a statute, such an interest has been more readily perceived when larger public interests are at stake.

On the ground of large public interest in the decision the courts have on occasions regarded as an actual controversy what might have appeared as an insufficiently hostile or concrete controversy, normally two essential elements necessary before the courts will entertain a declaratory judgment, and have actually decided on what would normally appear to have been a moot case or request for an advisory opinion. It may or may not involve a legitimate controversy and both parties may have possibly wanted the same judgment.
If the court wishes to render judgment it will close its eyes to the realities and perceive only the ostensible conflict of interest.

I understand the Australian High Court has been liberal in its interpretation of the rules normally applying to an application for a declaratory judgment and should that be not adequate to accommodate a more liberal approach along the lines of the American States jurisprudence then it seems there would be little difficulty in amending the rules of the High Court or whatever other appropriate modest measures are necessary to provide an even more generous approach by the High Court to declaratory judgments.
I conclude with a quote from James Bradley Thayer in his ''Life of Marshall''.

''Courts, as has often been said, are not to think of the legislators, but of the legislature-the great continuous body itself, abstracted from all the transitory individuals who may happen to hold its power. It is this majestic representative of the people whose action is in question, a co-ordinate department of the Government, charged with the greatest functions, and invested in contemplation of law, with whatever wisdom, virtue and knowledge the exercise of such functions requires.''

''To set aside the act of such a body, representing in its own field, which is the very highest of all, the ultimate sovereign, should be a solemn, unusual and painful act. Something is wrong when it can ever be other than that, and if it be true that the holders of the legislative power are careless or evil, yet the constitutional duty of the court remains untouched: It cannot rightly attempt to protect the people, by undertaking a function not its own. On the other hand, by adhering rigidly to its own duty, the court can help, as nothing can, to fix the spot where responsibility lies, and to bring down on that precise locality the thunderbolt of popular condemnation. The judiciary, today, in dealing with the Acts of their co-ordinate legislators, owe to the country no greater or clearer duty than that of keeping their hands off these Acts wherever it is possible to do it, for that course-the true course of judicial duty always-will powerfully help to bring the people and the representatives to a sense of their own responsibility.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move together amendments Nos (1) to (9) which have been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, line 11, after ''validity of'', insert ''a provision or provisions of''.
(2) Page 1, clause 2, line 12, after ''validity if enacted, of'', insert ''a provision or provisions of''.
(3) Page 2, clause 2, line 13, after ''Administrator of a'', insert ''self- governing''.
(4) Page 2, clause 2, line 16, after ''validity of'', insert ''a provision or provisions of''.
(5) Page 2, clause 2, line 17, after ''validity, if enacted, of'', insert ''a provision or provisions of''.
(6) Page 2, clause 2, line 29, after ''Administrator of a'' insert ''self- governing''.
(7) Page 2, clause 2, line 43, after ''in relation to a'', insert ''self- governing''.
(8) Page 3, clause 2, line 3, leave out ''in relation to a Territory, means the authority'', substitute ''in relation to a self-governing Territory, means the body''.
(9) Page 3, clause 2, line 8, leave out the definition of ''Territory'', substitute the following definition:

''self-governing Territory' means a territory referred to in section 122 of the Constitution, where, apart from the powers of the Parliament under that section, the power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the territory is exclusively vested in a body the members of which are directly chosen by the people of the territory;''.

I will briefly explain what these amendments are about. Amendments Nos (1), (2), (4) and (5) on the list propose the insertion of the words 'a provision or provisions of' before the words 'enactment' and 'proposed enactment' so as to make clearer the intention that references may be made on particular provisions of Acts or Bills and not only on entire Acts or Bills. This is designed to meet, among other things, the kind of objection which I anticipate might be made by some honourable senators to the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill as it now stands. Amendments Nos (3), (6) and (7) would limit the powers of the Administrator of a Territory to make reference to those territories which are self-governing, and at the moment that includes only the Northern Territory. It would not be possible under this amendment, for example, for Norfolk Island to seek an advisory opinion from the High Court of Australia.

Amendment No. (8) is a technical one substituting the word 'body' for ' authority' in relation to legislative powers so as to make the reference more accurate. Amendment No. (9) is connected with the earlier ones to define the expression 'self-governing Territory' in the way that I have indicated. I commend to honourable senators the amendments which are essentially technical but which do have substantive significance particularly so far as the provision or provisions clause is concerned.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated an amendment in my name to proposed new clause 77A(4) which deals with standing or the right to appear before the High Court when the argument is heard in relation to a request for an advisory opinion. At the present time the clause specifically states only that the Court will hear argument on the question from various Attorneys-General -Commonwealth, State or Territory as the case may be or indeed all of them if the case justifies it. I propose to add to that the words in the amendment circulated in my name. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 2, after proposed sub-paragraph 77A(4) (a) (ii), insert the following sub-paragraph:
'(iiA) any person who, in the opinion of the Court, has sufficient interest in the determination of the question;'.

I am moving that just to make it perfectly clear. Certainly the Court would have the power to enable any person to appear if it was at the discretion of the Court. A lot of concern has been expressed to me in regard to this matter. I think it would be much more satisfactory if this Bill, and ultimately the Constitution if it is amended, should make that perfectly clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can appreciate the desirability of clarification of the kind that Senator Durack is proposing, and indicate that the amendment is acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 2, proposed sub-section 77A(7), definition of '' 'proposed enactment' '', lines 6 and 7, leave out the definition, insert the following definition:
'' 'proposed enactment' means-

(a) in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth or of a State-a proposed enactment in the form in which it has been passed by both Houses of the Parliament concerned, or the House of the Parliament concerned, as the case may be, but which has not received the Queen's assent at the time of the reference;

(b) in relation to a self-governing Territory-a proposed enactment which has been passed by the body the members of which are directly chosen by the people of the Territory, but which has not received the assent of the Administrator or the Governor-General, as the case may be, at the time of the reference''.

I am sorry that I have not had an opportunity to discuss my amendment with the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) but it is simple and I hope that he might be persuaded to accept it in the course of this Committee of the Whole debate. The amendment deals with the very real concern that I have, which I expressed in the second reading debate, and that is in relation to that part of the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill that will allow Bills per se to be referred to the High Court for opinion. As the Bill stands at the moment it would potentially be possible for a government-I am not necessarily suggesting this Government-simply to bring down all its Bills at the commencement of a session and move them off to the High Court for opinion. Not surprisingly, when honourable members and honourable senators are returned to the Parliament with advice as to their constitutionality it is obviously going to be extremely difficult for them to be able to look to amendment and receive the answer: 'But your amendment is now going to question the validity of what we have already received judgment upon'.

I think that this is a most unsatisfactory development in the process of an operation of the Parliament. I remind the Senate that the 1928 Royal Commission on this subject in fact did not go as far as including this power to refer Bills as opposed to enactments to the Court. I also remind the Senate that the 1977 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs also did not go as far as to include this power. I remind the Senate also of the disquiet generally expressed by the Chief Justice of the High Court on the subject of opinions generally and the fact that he said he felt his brother judges were of the same opinion. But the concerns expressed by the Chief Justice of course are particularly accentuated with regard to this particular aspect of the Bill. That is obviously because his principal argument which he put to the law conference in Brisbane earlier this year was that the Court had sufficient power with regard to declaratory judgments. Now obviously that does not apply with regard to this proposal, this extension, which goes far beyond any power to give declaratory judgments that the High Court has ever had or ever attempted to exercise.

Mr Chairman, I move this amendment because I fear that the Bill as it now stands is attempting to usurp the role of the Parliament. It is forcing the Court to become intimately involved in the legislative process. The Court's attitude is quite clear, as I have expressed it, and that is that it is undesirable. Not surprisingly the Court itself does not want to take the place of parliamentary council, which is the type of emphasis that will come about if the Bill is passed in its present form. The Court obviously and reasonably does not want to have to answer abstract questions which can similarly arise if the Bill is passed in this form. It is not the place of the Court to be giving legal advice before enactment. I therefore share the view that has been expressed by a number of commentators on the subject of advisory opinions that to extend the process this far to Bills that have not actually passed the Parliament is an undesirable precedent. I trust that the Government will agree and that the referendum that is eventually put to the community will not have this undesirable complication included therein.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a little on this matter because there is some background information which I think should be known by the Committee. I must admit that I am a little troubled too, having heard the argument Senator Hill advanced this morning. Having got out my notes of the discussions that took place on this matter earlier I now think it is important that the Committee should know something of the background. It will be realised that I am a strong supporter of the advisory opinions proposal, and I will certainly vote for it. This matter arose from two different sources. It arose partially from the recommendations of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs of October 1977 on advisory opinions by the High Court. There also came down, almost at the same time, a report based upon Committee D's recommendations at the Constitutional Convention . There were differences between the two reports. Both recommended an advisory jurisdiction for the High Court but they differed as to the people who could approach the Court and as to the type of matter that would be dealt with by the Court in giving such an opinion. The Constitutional Convention adopted its report. Following that, a sub-committee was set up consisting of members of Committee D and of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, represented by myself, by Senator Gareth Evans and by Senator Tate. We discussed the differences and reached agreement, amalgamating as it were the recommendations of the two committees. It should be mentioned, and I think it has been by Senator Hill, that the Senate Committee's recommendation was that matters dealt with in advisory opinions should be on questions of law affecting the contitutionality of any law of the Commonwealth or of a State or any Bill passed by the parliaments of the Commonwealth or of State but which had not received royal assent at the time the request is made. It went on to deal with other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the discussions and negotiations, the Senate Committee gave way on that, and the provision is that which is now in the Bill relating to proposed enactments, which would make it possible for advisory opinions to be sought at various stages. They could be sought immediately after a Bill had been introduced in the Parliament, or at various other stages. I do not believe that in practical terms, de facto, this would happen and I would be surprised if any government would go backwards and forwards to the High Court seeking opinions, as it were endeavouring to improve its drafting of Bills and trying things out on the Court from time to time. That would be pretty reprehensible and would not be done; nor do I think it has been done elsewhere. From that point of view I do not think that this is a terribly serious problem. Having read the notes and from my memory of the discussions I do not think that the sub-committee had really given a great deal of attention to this problem. When I read the minutes of our sub-committee meeting of 26 May 1980 I find that in discussing the differences between the two reports we said only this:
The following decisions were made:
(a) Scope of jurisdiction. The sub-committee could see no difficulty in accepting the proposed terms of jurisdiction as expressed by the Judicature Committee.

We then went on to deal with sections 57 and 128. I believe this matter was not adverted to at great length in the discussions, but memory may well fail me at this stage. There may have been more discussion than I thought, but I do not believe this problem was adverted to greatly. Therefore, I feel sympathy for the proposal that has been made. It is the original recommendation of the Senate Committee and, of course, a Bill which has gone through the two Houses and is awaiting royal assent would be in a very determined and finalised form, whereas a Bill could be in a much more have-it-to-go form, be sent off to the High Court , and then be altered--

TALK.START.PARA: —Flying it on the flagpole.
—That is a way of putting it. I might say in regard to the proposed amendment that it contains a degree of obscurity that, before it could be passed, would have to be remedied. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: in relation to the Parliament of the Commonwealth or of a State-a proposed enactment in the form in which it has been passed by both Houses of the Parliament concerned, or the House of the Parliament concerned, as the case may be, but which has not received the Queen's assent at the time of the reference;

So it picks up the type of period for consideration of a proposed enactment which the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee had before it, but there is some obscurity as to what is meant by 'passed by both Houses of the Parliament concerned, or the House of the parliament concerned'. That presumably is designed to cover the situation, as in Queensland, where there is only one House , but it could be said that if it passes one of the Houses of the Federal Parliament it reaches that situation. So I think there is an in-built obscurity in the clause that no doubt could be fixed up.

Because of the agreement reached and because the Constitutional Convention subsequently adopted the compromise proposals which were made by the sub- committee, I would feel bound to support that proposal, hoping that the problems raised would not occur in actual operation. The most important thing is that the advisory opinion jurisdiction be given to the High Court, but I feel some qualm about this amendment and hope that the Government will consider it further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can well understand the genuineness of Senator Hill's concern about this and I hope that in what I say I can put his mind at rest. The Government, for reasons that I hope will be seen to be compelling, does not accept the amendment. The first point I make concerns the history of the matter, which Senator Missen has touched upon. It is the case that the Senate Committee, in its original report on this, did not include a recommendation that proposed enactments be able to be the subject of advisory opinions, but rather that these be confined to completed pieces of legislation. However, the Constitutional Convention itself, and the Judicature Committee reporting to it, took a different view. At the time the two competing streams of thought on this were meshed the matter was-I have tested my recollection since Senator Missen raised this with me an hour or so ago-squarely discussed and debated on the merits, and the approach of the Constitutional Convention was accepted. So this is not coming as some product of the draftsman or the Government's last minute thoughts on the subject. It is the product, really, of a quite long and extended process of debate about its policy implications.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that I am not sure that it is completely clear from what Senator Hill said, though it certainly is from the terms of the Bill before us, that when we are talking about a proposed enactment we are not talking about something which is merely a draftsman's doodling, prepared over the parliamentary recess in order to get a fix on what might appropriately be put subsequently in legislative form. The definition of 'proposed enactment' in the Bill now before us is:
'proposed enactment' means a proposed enactment in the form in which it is before the Parliament concerned at the time of the reference;
So it would need to have been actually introduced as a Bill in the Parliament before it could--

TALK.START.PARA: —It need not have been debated.

—That is perfectly true but, equally, it is not just an advance draft. It has to be something that has at least been shaped up and introduced as a Bill. The Government has to be prepared to be politically committed to it and to have visibly done so by the process of bringing it into the chamber. I think that ought to be appreciated in a way that I am not sure it was fully--
—The sex discrimination legislation came in, was here for ages and then had 52 or 53 amendments made to it. What are you going to do to that?

—I think that the next point I want to make is the practical justification for the proposal being put in these terms. The Sex Discrimination Bill does not squarely raise questions of constitutional validity .
—It is an example of what could happen.

—But many equally complicated measures which have been presented to the Parliament do raise threshold questions as to constitutional validity. One classic example was the Marriage Act, which changed in very significant ways questions of status. It was a controversial measure and was the subject of a declaratory proceeding before the High Court, after it had been passed by both Houses but before it had received royal assent. Threshold questions were involved there. Clearly, constitutional questions were involved in the Family Law Act, particularly in the form in which it was originally passed and, arguably, in the form in which we have just passed it here. Constitutional questions of a threshold kind would be clearly involved were the Commonwealth, as we foreshadowed we might in due course, to introduce unilateral national companies and securities legislation purportedly based on the corporations power and other available heads of constitutional power. The point I make is that all these sorts of measures are very complicated. They have many different policy dimensions to them other than the particular constitutional one . The constitutional one is really a threshold one which needs to be debated along with many other policy implications of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The utility of an advisory opinions procedure which enables one or more specific identified provisions of a Bill to be taken to the High Court is that the vexed threshold question can be resolved without necessarily having to go through the extraordinarily protracted process of debate that may well be involved in the other policy aspects of measures of this kind. Just imagine having to go through the 1975 Family Law Bill type debate and at the end of that extraordinarily protracted process, full of controversy and excitement and all the rest of it, have the High Court dispose of it completely as being outside Commonwealth power rather than, as it did, only one small part of it. Imagine having to go through the business of debating in this chamber and in the other a new piece of Commonwealth companies legislation, only one small part of the argument about which would be the constitutional argument. The rest of the argument, which would no doubt occupy most of the time, would involve other policy implications of the content of the legislation. But I think really what is being proposed here--

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been the practice, has it not?

—That has been the practice and an enormous amount of parliamentary time has been devoted to things which, luckily, have not as yet in our history resulted in a complete decimation of the measure. But it is only in relatively recent years that governments have been adventurous with constitutional powers on major policy matters of this kind. For most of this century governments have not sought to exercise legislative power. Of course, it would be the view of many people in this place that they ought not do so and anything which dissuades them from doing so ought to be applauded. I expect the neanderthal vote to oppose this, as it has opposed everything else that we have debated today. But those amongst us-I include Senator Hill in this category-who are progressive in their approach to public policy issues and who do want legislation to sensibly reflect and respond to prevailing social and economic problems would wish public resources to be efficiently devoted to the resolution of the sorts of problems that arise.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one further point as to the practicalities of these things. It could be said that one simple way of dealing with large complex legislation such as family law, company law and matters of this kind would be to introduce a very small Bill which raised the constitutional issues and pass that through both Houses fairly readily, provided one has the numbers, and then test that. That might be the sort of answer that Senator Hill would put to the points I have been making. The difficulty about that is that even though one would presumably be giving a reference to the High Court only in relation to a couple of specific provisions which clearly raise constitutional issues, those provisions could hardly be adjudicated on by the High Court in the abstract. They would have to derive their shape and substance from the context in which they appear. One could not do otherwise than introduce the test provisions in the same context as the rest of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an argument against it, is it not?
—No, it is not. I am saying that what one does is-
—You are getting too arcane for your own good.

—I am trying to meet what might possibly be a more sophisticated argument, which has not yet emerged from the other side. My argument about complexity and practicality can be quickly dismissed by drafting a Bill which is much narrower in compass and only dealing with the constitutional issue and referring that to the High Court. What I am saying is that that is not really the way the world works. One could only present the High Court with a problem in which the constitutional issue is raised in a total context. What one would do, of course, is refer to the High Court for actual adjudication only one or two clauses of the Bill. One would not ask it to pass upon every last one of the potential constitutional minefields that might lurk in the rest of the Bill. To do so would place unreasonable demands upon the High Court. I can only put it that way. Part of the justification for having advisory opinions is to enable one to test in a formal way legislation of this kind.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make quickly is the practical one again, that I think Senator Missen has made. The Canadian Supreme Court, as I understand it, has had a capacity to adjudicate on proposed enactments as well as Bills that have formally got through the parliamentary process for a very long time now. Although it has not fallen into disuse, as I made clear earlier, although it is a procedure that has been used from time to time every few years, it is not a procedure which has been abused, nor is it reasonable to expect it to be abused in the Australian context. The amendment which we have just passed, which makes it clear that it is only a portion of the Bill that should properly be referred to the High Court, gives added practical incentive to what, I think, would in any case be the practical political dynamics of the situation. I think Senator Missen has made that point very effectively and I cannot add on that score anything to what he has said. I do not think either that there is occasion to worry that the basic principles of the place and the legislative process are being somehow put at risk by this measure. I do not think there is any real reason to express any alarm that in practice this particular capacity would be abused. I urge the chamber accordingly to vote for the Bill in the form in which it was originally proposed and as it originally emerged from a very long and protracted negotiation process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been trying desperately to get some references because I understand that the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, in the course of his summing up, alleged that some of the statements that I had made about the disuse of this power were not correct. I have had some difficulty in getting the references because I thought Senator Evans would talk long enough for me to get them, but unfortunately he managed to sit down. I refer the chamber to a report in the Washington Law Review and State Bar Journal. Admittedly, this is not a Canadian, but a United States report. I refer the Committee to an article in the Spring 1959 issue by one George Neff Stevens, the Dean of the School of Law at the University of Washington. The article is entitled 'Advisory Opinions-Present Status and an Evaluation'.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Senator Robert Ray and Senator Gareth Evans are not interested in what the constitutional lawyers of the United States have to say on these matters, but I intend to tell those honourable senators who are interested what these people have to say on the subject. This fellow only happens to be the Dean of the School of Law at the University of Washington. I know that does not stand up to Senator Evans's academic qualifications, but the opinion is worth reading. Dean Stevens said in his conclusions:
The advisory opinion practice does place in the judges a degree of control over legislative and executive conduct, duties, and obligations above and beyond the judicial function . . .
When I suggested that, apparently it was frowned upon. The dean went on-I am just trying to extract the minimum of what he said-to say:
Its disadvantages far outweigh its actual and potential advantages.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is opinion, not fact.
—Yes. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Procedural reform, looking to a speedier determination of litigated cases, and a wider use of the prerogative writs and the declaratory judgment procedure will accomplish far more, in a sound manner, than could be obtained under any extension of the advisory opinion practice.
That is just one fellow's opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 1959.
—What does it matter whether it was written in 1959 or 1859? Of course, in questions of law the opinion of these people is all important. I will tell honourable senators what happened in Germany:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Constitutional Court of West Germany was given advisory jurisdiction when it was established in 1951. But after unfortunate experience with it in the European Defense Community controversy when both major political parties in the Bundestag endeavoured to embroil the Court in an ugly political conflict, the jurisdiction was abolished in 1956 at the Court's request.

That is the sort of opinion that is available for anyone who wants to look. There are plenty of references criticising the granting and the use of this power. I support what Senator Hill has proposed because it would at least limit it in order to retain some powers in this Parliament. What bothers me is that the Government will produce a piece of legislation, will not give the Parliament an opportunity to debate it, will send it straight across to the High Court and come back with the opinion of the High Court and present it as a fait accompli to this Parliament. The Government will say: 'What is the good of you arguing about it? The High Court has approved it'. The Parliament will once again be seen to have lost some of its power. I am totally in favour of what Senator Hill is putting forward. Ultimately, however, I will oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I may suggest that Senator Lewis is debating the general issue rather than anything specifically identified and relevant in Senator Hill's amendment, but to the extent that he has challenged the validity of what I was saying in my second reading speech, perhaps I may say that the direct challenge that I, in turn, was then putting to Senator Lewis was as to the accuracy in particular of his Canadian references. In making those he said two things-which are both manifestly false-namely, that the advisory opinions jurisdiction has fallen into disuse in Canada and has not been used at all in the last few decades; and, secondly-this was also false-that Canadian experience is that advisory opinions have been subsequently ignored and overturned by the Supreme Court when concrete issues subsequently arose. That is just as false as his statement of fact, for reasons that I can spell out, perhaps, by reference to another learned judicial authority, Strayer on judicial review of legislation. I will give Senator Lewis the page reference afterwards, if he is keen on it.

SPEECH.PARA: Everything else is really just a matter of opinion and takes us into the realm of the second reading-type debate which we have had and concluded as to the general merits of this meassure. As to the specific merits of Senator Hill's proposal, I do not believe that anything that Senator Lewis has said adds to or detracts from the argument that we have already had on that subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gareth Evans very much for his contribution. He has made the matter so adequately clear to me now that my choice is quite clear. I shall now certainly oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Hill. I support the notion of advisory justification for the High Court of Australia. As to the suggestions that have been put forward-and I listened carefully to the reply of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) on them-it seems to me that, in reliance upon the political activities, Senator Evans did not address himself to an interjection, and that was the discussion about the Sex Discrimination Bill. That is not a Bill which would fall into this category- although it might-but it is a Bill to which the Government, with a very high profile, committed itself politically. It brought a Bill into this place and we now have a new Bill coming in. It is a severely amended Bill. But the suggestion was that having committed oneself to a Bill, that is it. I do not see any problem that has arisen for the Government in relation to that Bill. Politically it was able to amend its own Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a regular occurrence in this place, as it is in the other place. So the mere introduction of a Bill does not commit the Government in any way politically. Yet that was one of the basic arguments being used as to why we might use it at that stage for advisory opinion rather than having gone through the debate in this place and in the other place. We may then, before it receives the royal assent, send it to the High Court for an opinion. I believe that that parliamentary debate would be the political element. The suggestion was that it was not worthwhile to proceed with the entire parliamentary debate if at the end of that we discovered that the entire episode was unconstitutional.

Let us turn that argument on its head and suggest that having found that something is constitutional, if it is not politically acceptable why waste the time of the High Court looking at it? One can take one or the other. It seems to me that the political judgment on a particular Bill ought to be made first, and we should then seek-I certainly think that it should be done before the royal assent-an advisory opinion on the legality of the Bill. Senator Hill's proposal, which has been brought forward before, as Senator Missen has outlined, is probably a more appropriate way of operating with the advisory opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief because I have already had the indulgence of the Senate to incorporate a statement in Hansard. As I was leaving my office I noticed that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) referred to Strayer in supporting his argument in respect of advisory opinions. I refer Senator Evans to the 1916 insurance case. In the 1916 insurance reference the Supreme Court was asked a number of questions and specifically to wit:

SPEECH.PARA: Are sections 40 and 70 of the Insurance Act 1916 or any and what part or parts of the said section ultra vires the Parliament of Canada?

I should have thought that that was a pretty definitive request for an opinion. But Strayer goes on to make the observation, after analysing the opinion that was given, that the results might easily have been different in a concrete case when the facts before the Court may have been seen by contrasting the decision with that of the Quebec Court of Queen's Bench Appeals cited in the Reader's Digest case. He goes on to say that the 1916 insurance reference was considered at the time to be inapplicable, but he says:

Nevertheless, one might well suspect that the Courts in the 1916 insurance reference, if they had had before them the kind of facts of the insurance business corresponding to those of the publishing business considered in the Reader's Digest case, the result of the 1916 decision might well have been quite the opposite. The 1916 insurance reference was an abstract decision. It was one of the many such reference decisions which have had far-reaching and unfortunate consequences upon the laws and the Constitution of Canada.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not entirely sure what Senator Crichton-Browne has just contributed to the debate with that sally. There are, of course, differences of opinion as to the merits of particular decided opinions, whether on the basis of an advisory jurisdiction or an ordinary jurisdiction.
—You were quoting Strayer.

—Yes, but as to the facts as to what has happened in Canada as to the number of cases which have been run there and what the implications of them have been in terms of their subsequent overturning. That was all. I am not saying that Strayer was terrific in everything else that he wrote or in his analysis of his judgment. So the honourable senator is welcome to that debating point, but it does not meet the one that I was raising.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, Senator Macklin is welcome to his debating point about the Sex Discrimination Bill. Of course it is the case that a Bill might be substantially amended after it has been introduced. I was not seeking to suggest that there was anything about the mere fact of introduction which represented that that would then be the be-all and end-all of the Government's views about how the legislation ought to be introduced. I was simply saying that an element of formality and public commitment to at least the basic principles of a measure is necessarily involved before it can be sent off to the High Court, and as such it is not just a draftsman's sketch which would be wasting the time, possibly, of the High Court of Australia. It must have at least that degree of political momentum behind it.

As to the more substantial point as to whether or not there is any justification for seeking an advisory opinion at the stage at which it has just been introduced and before it has been fully debated, I do not think that it has been fully appreciated that the High Court already has a declaratory jurisdiction in relation to Bills which have passed both Houses and which have not yet received the royal assent. It exercised that in the Marriage Act case, for example, in 1961, and there have been other instances of that. To the extent that one already has that jurisdiction, one does not need any additional jurisdiction vested in the High Court by virtue of this amendment.

One of the numerous advantages of this proposal that has been accepted by the Constitutional Convention, for this among other reasons, is that it enables, at an earlier stage, threshold constitutional questions to be resolved, particularly in the context of vastly complex legislation which might otherwise involve a very substantial allocation of parliamentary time and resources which would then be wasted because of the way in which the constitutional foundations are struck from beneath it by the High Court. That is one of the very objectives of advisory opinions legislation-to enable this, in an appropriate case-and there would be all sorts of political checks and balances at work to ensure that the thing was not abused. We cannot make the High Court give a decision. There is no question of a mandamus lying against the High Court to make it produce a reasoned opinion on something on which it simply does not want to or to which it does not feel it can respond. But there is a case for creating the capacity in the High Court to give such an opinion if it is requested in an appropriate case . Perhaps I may suggest that the very careful attention that has been given to this matter by the Judicature Committee of the Constitutional Convention and the way in which this proposal has evolved over a long period, with this among other objectives in mind, ought to be given appropriate credence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment moved by Senator Hill comes as a matter of surprise to the Opposition. We have not therefore had the usual chance to consider all the ramifications of what he is putting forward. On the face of it, it has some attraction, and the Opposition and, indeed, some individual senators have indicated a very strong interest in supporting it. At the same time, there are-
—It has got some difficulties in it.

—I am getting help from all sides here. There are also potentially some problems in it. That being so, the Opposition would really prefer not to have to take a decision on this amendment on the run. I raise the matter now because I understand that there are time problems, and the Opposition has been endeavouring to fit in with the Government's time requirements. In turn , it has had from the Government concessions on time-last week, for example. So I am raising the matter really in a spirit of inquiry at this stage. The preference that I have on behalf of the Opposition is to stand this Bill over until Tuesday and to deal with it on that day. Thus we would have a chance to consider over the weekend the amendment proposed by Senator Hill and to discuss the matter in our Party room. If it is possible, that is the course we would prefer to follow and I would appreciate it if the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) could give consideration to it. I am sure the whole Senate would agree to dealing with the Bill first thing on Tuesday and then disposing of it. There is no wish to interfere with the timetable that the Government has set but there is a wish to have the chance to give mature and sober consideration to what is for most of us a new amendment which may contain some bugs even although it is, on the surface, an attractive proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the circumstances, I think it would be appropriate to accede to the request just made. The difficulty we have as to timing is simply this: These Bills must be introduced into the House of Representatives next week. If we can introduce them by Wednesday or Thursday, then this proposed course is possible. It cannot go any longer than that and I must understand that what the Leader of the Opposition ( Senator Chaney) has said amounts to an undertaking that there will be no further delay of this matter on Tuesday. I think it is appropriate in the case of a constitutional proposal of this kind that we not be fighting about things in public which we are capable of resolving amongst ourselves before they get into the public domain.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 October 1983, on motion by Senator Macklin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 3, proposed sub-section 24 (3), leave out 'eighty-five thousand' , insert 'one hundred thousand'.

The issue concerning this amendment was raised by you, Mr Chairman, during the second reading debate on these Bills and I think that the point you raised was well taken. People should be careful when they read the Constitution Alteration (Parliament) Bill. It only sets a ceiling. We are not talking about absolute numbers; we are talking about a ceiling. For the first time there will be a ceiling on the number of parliamentarians that can be elected to this parliament . So in that sense the Bill proposes to limit for the first time the absolute number of members. Senator Hamer, in his contribution to the second reading debate, pointed out that if the figure of 85,000 were left, as in the original Bill, the numbers really would be quite high. If the figure of 100,000 were introduced, the ceiling as of this year would be 154 members in the House of Representatives. Of course there is no constraint on the Parliament going up to that number, and the number could be even lower, as it is now. For the information of honourable senators, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics projections available, which go as far as the year 2021, the absolute number under the amended proposal would be 219 when the total population of Australia would be 21,000,000 people. So I have taken the arguments that Senator Hamer raised and have moved accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is prepared to support this amendment. As Senator Macklin has pointed out, the figure is in the Bill merely to establish a ceiling on the number of House of Representatives seats which can be created. That restriction has not been present in the past. The idea that there should be some lower ceiling than is proposed by the Government is one which I think is fairly attractive to the Opposition parties and the limit of 154 members would seem to cater for any real requirement that the Australian people might have. The Opposition has the view that the Australian people in general are not very keen on having any more politicians anyway and I think the lowering of the ceiling would be generally acceptable to the community that this Constitution is supposed to service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government is prepared to accept the amendment, though not necessarily for entirely the same reasons as those just advised by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). Even when passed by the Senate, as no doubt it will be today, it has to be said that there will still remain a fair amount of time for further consideration of this measure before it is put to the people, so I do not think we need sweat too much about the detail of it. I see the point behind Senator Macklin's proposal and accede to his suggestion. After all, it is his Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I will support the third reading I do not regard this as a particularly practical proposition. I certainly support its going before the people but whether or not it ought to be supported in the ultimate, at the referendum, is another matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: The PRESIDENT-I declare that the motion for the third reading of the Bill has been carried by an absolute majority of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (REMOVAL OF OUTMODED AND EXPENDED PROVISIONS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 12 May 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —(5.08)-by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, clause 2, lines 6 to 9, leave out the clause.
(2) Page 1, after clause 2, insert the following new clause:
Summoning Parliament ''2A. Section 5 of the Constituion is altered by omitting the last paragraph.''.
(3) Page 2, after clause 8, insert the following new clause:
Ministers of State ''8A. Section 64 of the Constitution is altered by omitting from the last paragraph 'After the first general election, no' and substituting 'No'.''.

I will explain for the record the substance of these amendments. The first amendment, strictly speaking, is simply a negativing of clause 2 of the Bill as it now stands. That is because it is no longer necessary, now that this referendum is to be held next year. Its original purpose was to delay the repeal of section 59 of the Constitution so as to preserve the trustee status of remaining stock issued under the United Kingdom Colonial Stock Act of 1900. The last of that stock matures on 1 December 1983, which the Senate will be delighted to hear. It is no longer necessary to delay the implementation of this accordingly. Our independence is almost complete in this respect.

The second and third amendments are to delete respectively the provision in section 5 of the Constitution which relates to the summoning of the first Parliament in the Federation. The third amendment, the second substantive amendment, is to omit the words 'After the first general election' in section 64 of the Constitution. The provision requires a Minister to take a seat in the Parliament no longer than three months after his appointment. The words 'After the first general election' are removed to again clarify that the first election of the Federation has now rather long since passed. These particular minor amendments were in fact contained in the Bill dealing with the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Parliaments) Bill as part of the tidying up of clauses 5 and 64 that was there attempted. With the demise of that Bill it, accordingly, becomes necessary to put this particular bit of archival enterprise into the Bill we are now debating.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: That the Bill be now read a third time. Those of that opinion say aye, against so no. I think the ayes have it. As no division has been called for, I draw attention to the constitutional requirement that this Bill must be passed by an absolute majority. Before the counting of the Senate proceeds I direct the bells to be rung.

—A division has not been called for, but it is desirable that the names of those honourable senators present and agreeing to the third reading of the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill 1983 be recorded. I think it would meet the convenience of the Senate if I ruled that honourable senators remain in their places in order to be counted. I appoint Senator Robertson and Senator Kilgariff as tellers to record the names of those honourable senators present and agreeing to the third reading of the Bill. I ask any honourable senator not agreeing to the Bill to so indicate, so that he or she will not be counted with the honourable senators agreeing to the Bill.
—Even if it means that I am slightly outmoded and outnumbered, I am against the third reading of this Bill.
