PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September 1980, on motion by Senator Mason:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the previous arrangement between the Whips, rather than spend any more time on this matter I seek leave to have my speech on the second reading of this Bill incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
We are debating the Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill.

Senator Mason's Bill besides being in my view highly impractical strikes not only at the heart of responsible government but at the foundation of the constitution and the paramount role of a federal system for which it was designed and which is enshrined in it.

The two fundamental purposes of the legislation are to firstly bypass the system of elected governments and have government by referendum, and secondly to destroy the influence which the smaller States have in the Federal Parliament by their equal representation in the Senate and their representation in the House of Representatives.

The Bill as it presently stands proposes to confer upon qualified electors, power to make laws on any matter with respect to which the Parliament has power to legislate, and further to confer upon qualified electors in a way presently prohibited by the Constitution, the power to amend the Constitution.

The intended new section 130 proposes in party that on a petition to Parliament by 250,000 qualified electors any legislation which as I say, is within the Commonwealth's jurisdiction shall be put to the people of Australia by way of a referendum.

I repeat only 250,000 people are required to petition the Parliament to cause the holding of a national referendum. A percentage of 2.67 per cent of the Australian voters can cause and force the holding of a referendum.

Given the recent polarisation of the community and the vocal minorities who with the willing help of the Australian media are more and more seeking to influence both community and government attitudes with one issue policies, we can I suspect really expect that there will be a continuous stream of referendums not only dislocating the legitimate government of the country but causing enormous expenditure to the taxpayers. The cost of the referenda to which the Federal Labor Government is about to subject the Australian people in February is expected alone to cost somewhere in the range of $21 million.
With this proposal which requires such a small number of petitions there will be countless referendums held every year.
In the event that a single issue minority group fail in their first attempt, they are at liberty to try and try again.

The very system of government will be severly disrupted. New proposed section 132 intends that should there be an inconsistency between legislation made by the Parliament and legislation resulting from elector initiative, the new section 132 is designed to ensure that the latter shall prevail.

With the ease with which referendums can be instigated but with the time required to put them to the people, governments will tend simply to defer legislation which is likely to be the subject of a referendum. In the meantime of course there will be a hiatus.
Mr President, of far greater significance are the qualifications which the Australian Democrats propose to give effect to their referendums.

The new section 130 tells us that for laws other than those seeking to amend the constitution or seeking to effect the representation of a State in the Parliament or the boundaries of a State a simple majority would be sufficient.
An amendment of the Constitution could be effected by a majority of electors overall and a majority in a majority of States, or by a two-thirds majority overall.

In respect of a law effecting State representation or State boundaries, a majority of electors in the affected State together with an overall majority will be required unless there is a two-thirds majority overall.
I take the first proposition as it stands, which is to have the effect of creating federal laws by a vote of a simple majority of the qualified voters of Australia.

In other words, it matters not whether all the voters of Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia, South Australia, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory oppose the referendum proposed. It will become law if 81.35 per cent of the voters of New South Wales and Victoria support it.

I would just remind the Senate that New South Wales and Victoria between them have 61.5 per cent of all voters in Australia, that of course means that every time a referendum is put which has particular appeal to the people of those states, the views and wishes of all other States and Territories are quite irrelevant and will be ignored.

One can immediately understand that this first proposal seeks not only to make the Senate totally irrelevant and the equal representation of each State which the Senate expressly provides, of absolutely no effect but it also destroys each State's representation in the House of Representatives.

For the very purpose of providing a bulwark against the domination of the Federal Parliament by the two most populous States our founding fathers and the architects of the Constitution very deliberately provided for equal representation from all States in the Senate.

So as to ensure that there could be no subsequent tampering with this cornerstone of our Federation and without which there would have been no Federation, the Constitution was so drafted that this provision could not be amended without the express approval of the majority of votes in the states so affected. Clearly no State would vote for a dilution of its representation so the provision of equal Senate representation for all States will remain a permanent fixture of our Constitution so long and only so long as the present provision for amending the Constitution remains.
This Bill now seeks to destroy that fundamental tenet of our Constitution.

Equal representation is held as an intrinsic and vital part of the Constitution by the smaller States because of the very considerable powers vested in the Senate and yet now here we have the Democrats seeking to totally destroy the fundamental premise of the Senate's existence. The States House of equal representation and equal powers will under this Bill become an irrelevance.
Representation in the House of Representatives by the smaller States will also become immaterial.

In fact in many respects, by the powers contained in this legislation the Parliament as a whole become irrelevant because not only does the Bill allow for laws without Parliament but laws created by it override the laws of the Parliament.

To move to the Bill's second proposition under proposed section 130 relating to constitutional amendments it is proposed that constitutional amendments will be declared carried by a two-thirds majority overall. It will no doubt be recalled that the Territories are now proposed to be included in the aggregate overall total.

This provision is to replace that part of section 128 of Chapter VIII of the Constitution which presently requires not only a total majority vote within the Commonwealth but a majority of votes in the majority of States.
The Bill again takes absolutely no cognizance of the collective views of the States or the fact that Australia is governed under a federal system.
The Democrats in seeking constitutional amendments without the consent of the majority of the States appear to be advancing into practice their proposition that the States ought to be abolished.

One is compelled towards the conclusion that their proposals are based on the premise that Australia does have a unity system of government that the Constitution has no relevance to or effect upon the six States which make up our Federation and that the Australian Constitution is not one in which both national and State elements co-exist.
The variation of the Constitution without the approval of both the people and the States is not only thoroughly unjust but is an attack upon the whole system of our government.

The Democrats seem to have lost touch with reality. Being a new party seems no excuse to being new to the history of the Constitution. The Australian Constitution is an instrument of the careful and considered deliberations by the delegates of what are the six sovereign States of Australia. It is a creature of the States conceived and created by men who were invariably members of State legislatures.
One sometimes wonders whether it is not the view of some that the Federal Parliament created the States.
That the States are to be considered as inconsequential, irrelevant irritating mendicants.

I just remind those of that view that the very first section of the constitution says that 'the legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament which shall consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives'. 'The Senate shall be composed of senators for each State, directly chosen by the people of the State, voting, until the Parliament otherwise provides, as one electorate'.

Section 24 referring to the House of Representatives says, 'the number of members chosen in the several States shall be in proportion to the respective numbers of their people etc. That section concludes with the sentence, 'but notwithstanding anything in this section, five members at least shall be chosen in each original State'.

The very essence of the composition of the Federal Parliament designed for the purpose of creating Federal laws is the protection of and participation by all States. All serious contributors to the drawing up of the Federal Constitution were of one mind on one issue. The Federal Parliament was to be a parliament of all States, reflecting the views, wishes, aspirations and characters of all the States of Australia.
In a simple stroke this legislation seeks to destroy that premise and dismantle the principle of Federation in Australia. By ignorance or design I have no idea.

Pursuing the logical conclusion to which this legislation inexhorably draws us it must follow that the Democrats are calling for the abolition of the Senate and the creation of a unicameral system of government or at best a totally unstructured system of election to the Senate.

In as much as each State has ten senators in the Senate and given the significant difference in the various States naturally the quotas for senators in each State are different. Under the principles outlined in this legislation the quota for all senators should be the same. If that were to be the case New South Wales would be entitled to 21 senators, Victoria 16, Queensland 10, South Australia 6, Western Australia 5 and Tasmania 2.

To refer for a moment to that part of the new section 132 of the Constitution contained in the Bill before us, it is as I have outlined, proposed that alterations diminishing the proportionate representation of any State in either House of the Parliament, or the minimum number of representatives of a State is the House of Representatives, or increasing, diminishing or otherwise altering the limits of the State, or in any manner affecting the provisions of the Constitution in relation thereto, shall become law if a two-thirds majority of all eligible voters so decide.

In other words now, theoretically New South Wales and 48 per cent of the voters in Australia or New South Wales and Victoria plus 13.5 per cent of every other State could at such a referendum under such a proposal abolish the Senate completely, amalgamate the smaller States into one and abolish representation of those States so amalgamated.

Is that really what this constitutional amendment is intended to achieve. Under Senator Mason's proposal it would only require 4.26 per cent of New South Wales and Victorian voters to cause that proposal to be put by way of referendum.

As far as Tasmania is affected such a referendum could of course very easily amend that provision of section 24 of the Constitution which provides that five members at least shall be chosen in each original State.
It is not a question of what will be done but rather what can be done.
If Tasmanian House of Representative boundaries were drawn under the standard provisions of section 24 which applies to every other State, their representation in that chamber would be reduced to 3.

The Constitution provides that the number of members chosen in the several States shall be in proportion to the respective numbers of their people, and shall until the Parliament otherwise provides be determined in the following manner:
(i) A quota shall be ascertained by dividing the number of the people of the Commonwealth as shown by the latest statistics of the Commonwealth by twice the number of the Senators.

(ii) The number of members to be chosen in each State shall be determined by dividing the number of the people of the State, as shown by the latest statistics of the Commonwealth, by the quota, and if on such division there is a remainder greater than one-half of the quota, one more member shall be chosen in the State.
As I say on that basis Tasmania would be entitled to three members, but for the fact that section 24 is qualified to the extent that no original State shall have less than five members.

That qualification to the determining calculation for representation from each State in the House of Representatives is to ensure that the less populous States such as Tasmania are not swamped by the more populous States and to ensure that they have some voice in the House of Representatives.

It is an extension of the underlying philosophy which has been woven through the Constitution. Concern to ensure that all States are adequately numerically represented in the Federal Parliament both in the Senate and the House of Representatives.
The Democrats are now seeking to break the golden thread and submerge such considerations.
To argue in favour of their proposals is to argue against a voice in the affairs of our nation by the smaller States and is to argue against a voice for all Australians.
This Bill now before us is potentially the most divisive legislation to come before the Senate in a great many years.
It could and would, if ultimately caused by a referendum, lead to enormous difficulties for the system of Federation.

It would lead inevitably to discrimination between the stronger and weaker States on a whole range of issues which the Constitution in its present form prohibits, and I refer to taxation, trade and commerce just to name a few.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 October 1983, on motion by Senator Hamer:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Very briefly I exercise my right of reply in a last ditch attempt to try to induce the Government to see reason on this issue. Only one objection has been raised by the Government to my Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill which provides that the Government's power to have a double dissolution lapses after three months if it has not exercised that power. It is intended to bring the workings of the Constitution back to its proper and intended purpose. The objection raised by Senator Tate and the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) can be expressed, I think, in this way: What about the death of a thousand cuts? What if the Senate, instead of rejecting a major piece of legislation which could properly be the grounds for a double dissolution under the Bill, rejected a succession of minor pieces of legislation cumulatively frustrating the Government in the process? As far as being grounds for a double dissolution is concerned, this does not matter because a single ground, no matter how trivial, is adequate and the straw that breaks the camel's back can properly be the grounds for a double dissolution.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is true that the other rejected Bills may be out of time, the rejection having occurred more than three months before, and the Government would not have the right to have them considered at a post-election joint sitting if it so desired. The answer to this is very simple. If the Government were becoming increasingly frustrated by Senate obstruction and decides to go for a double dissolution, it could, if it desired, re-present all the Bills which had previously been rejected. This would focus the Senate's mind wonderfully if the Government's intention to go for a double dissolution were obvious. If the Senate were not prepared to face a double dissolution on the grounds of obstruction, it would have to pass the Bills. That is one solution. On the other hand, if it were prepared to face a double dissolution it would reject them again and they would be available to the Government for consideration at a post-election joint sitting, provided, of course, the Government won the election. This seems an adequate and appropriate way of dealing with the problem that Senator Tate and the Attorney-General raised and is, politically, entirely proper and workable. Since the only objection raised by the Government to the Bill has now been disposed of, I look forward to the Government's support.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: The PRESIDENT-The votes being 26 all, the question is resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: In error, Senator Lewis, although present and voting aye, was omitted from the record of the division.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have been informed that certain people counted 27 on the ayes side during that last division. I am not for a moment disputing what you have said, Mr President, but it seems to me that there is some doubt about the count. I do not know what provision we have for recommitting a vote of that kind, but perhaps it should be done.

—I speak to the point of order, Mr President. I was going to raise that point of order myself. We are talking about an extremely significant vote. If you look at the naked figures there are 28 Liberal Party and National Party of Australia senators in this place plus five Australian Democrats. I assume all members of those parties present voted for the ayes, which means that the ayes must have won unless there was a Liberal Party or a National Party member absent . Surely the matter can be cleared up if either the Liberal Party Whip or the National Party Whip declares that one of their members missed the division or abstained. It would be as simple as that. I think it is such a serious matter that it should not be allowed to go by default.

—I was just waiting while my Whip checked with the Government Whip. There may be some possibility that there has been some confusion with the pairing arrangements. My informal counting of that division led me to believe that we had successfully carried it. I suggest that it is an appropriate case for recommittal.

—Order! The division lists have been recovered and I would suggest that they be perused by the Clerks and the Whips. In the meantime we will proceed with the business of the day. If in the event it is found that a mistake has occurred we can determine whether the Bill should be recommitted.

—Mr President, I refer you to page 236 of Odgers Australian Senate Practice which covers the subject of an incorrect counting or irregularity in the vote. If anything is to be done, perhaps the Standing Orders and Australian Senate Practice need to be gone through first.
—Surely the Senate can decide if it wants to recommit a vote.

—On that point of order, it has been a rule in this chamber ever since I have been here, and no doubt since you have been here, Mr President, that neither side tries to win in this place by misadventure.
—What about in 1975?

—No, that is true. Many a time a vote has been taken when somebody has been locked in a lavatory or something. The vote has been put again . Occasionally we on our side have lost and occasionally the other side has lost following a recommittal. But there has been a general arrangement around the chamber that neither side wins by misadventure. One does not want to worry about the Standing Orders or Odgers' publication. It is a matter of decency in the chamber.

—I do not in any way wish to delay this most edifying debate but I am quite happy that in a quarter of an hour or so we should come back to this issue. Everybody is speaking in total ignorance, with respect. If there could be some discussion between the Whips and the Clerks, in a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes, by agreement, we could come back and consider this matter again. I would be quite happy. I do not see any point in continuing the present discussion.
—That is the course of action I suggested in the first instance. It has been the normal practice in the case of misadventure in regard to counts.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 October 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the second reading of the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill or giving the Bill a second reading, but the Opposition will move an amendment identical to that moved by our spokesman, the Hon. Michael Hodgman, in another place. We will draw the attention of the Senate to some aspects of the legislation. The amendment which we will move has been circulated and proposes that the following words be added:

SPEECH.PARA: 'but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) the increased charges will cause personal hardship by preventing a large number of private overseas students from obtaining the benefits of secondary and tertiary education in Australia; and

(b) the substantially reduced overseas student intake for 1984 is not in the interests of Australia and its relations with our Asian and Pacific neighbours in that it is elitist, isolationist, selfish and mean'.

The legislation seeks to increase the maximum rate of charge per prescribed course for overseas students attending secondary and tertiary institutions in Australia. The extent of the increase in the maximum charge will be from $2,500 to $2,900.

As with other changes affecting tertiary students, what the Labor Government is doing is making it more difficult for private overseas students to be able to afford or get access to, secondary or tertiary education in Australia. At the same time as it is increasing the charges, the Government is cutting the intake of overseas students quite significantly and the Opposition is concerned about this action. The increasing of charges by the Government is an affirmation that education is a good and that there are costs associated with the provision of that good. It is an affirmation by a Labor Government in Australia that circumstances do exist in which the charging of fees for access to higher education in this country is something that Labor supports. That is quite an admission because the charge itself was, of course, introduced by the previous Government and what we are debating now is really the fact that the charge has been increased.

It is worth noting that in 1979, when the charge was introduced, the Australian Labor Party was unanimous in its opposition to it. It was unanimous in its opposition to the Overseas Students Charge legislation. The Australian Labor Party at that time, when it did not have the numbers and was in opposition, said that it was disgraceful that we should seek to charge overseas students for the privilege of being educated in Australia. Now that it is in government and has the capacity to redress what it saw as wrong in 1979, there is no move to do that. Let me be clear about our position. We believed it appropriate to introduce this charge. It was the Australian Labor Party that condemned it when in opposition. Now it is in government it has declined to take the first opportunity open to it to redress what it saw as wrong when it was convenient to take that view. In fact, Labor supporters ran around the campuses of Australia indicating that if elected they would get rid of the legislation. Of course, we find that now they are in government they are not going to do that.

One of the obligations which we really must assume, and have assumed, as a highly developed country, a country with special capacities in our region, is to provide educational opportunities for our neighbours in South East Asia and the western Pacific. Some of the things which have been occurring, particularly the limitation on the numbers of private overseas students to be allowed access to Australia, are not in accord with assuming those obligations. It is worth observing that the Australian Union of Students has expressed its opposition to this move by the Government. Although I am frequently in conflict with the Australian Union of Students, on this occasion it is appropriate, as a contribution to the debate, to mention what Miss Gayle Sansakda had to say as Education Vice-president of Australia:
It was disappointing to see the Minister being pressed into taking this position which was based on the situation at only one campus, the University of NSW.

I might come back to that and say that at the University of New South Wales some of the courses had large numbers of overseas students participating. There was in the Sydney Press earlier this year a not entirely savoury debate which drew upon some of those less admirable tendencies in Australian society which lie just below the surface and suggested that somehow overseas students were displacing, inappropriately, Australian born students. I can understand the difficulties which the very enlightened Vice-Chancellor of the University of New South Wales faced in dealing with this circumstance. I would say that at all times his position was careful, proper and reasonable, but I do not think that some of the Press comment that occurred in my own city during this time was either good or helpful. The fact is that some of the students, on merit, earned their way into courses and it was a matter for some public comment that in some courses overseas students did represent some 90 per cent of students. On many other campuses space and capacity was available for overseas students to enrol. Many campuses have the capacity to take extra students, and to extrapolate from the position at the University of New South Wales and on that basis make it not possible for students, above a very small quota, to come to Australia, is something which has concerned the Australian Union of Students as well as a number of other people in the community.

The AUS also drew attention to the lack of consultation which had occurred on the issue. We understand that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan) and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) had considerable difficulty in coming to an agreement on a number of matters relating to this issue. I understand that it was even difficult to settle upon a Press release. So, considering the difficulties that they had, I am not surprised that there was minimal consultation with outside groups, but that is a pity, because this is just the kind of issue where extensive consultation with the institutions and with the AUS would have been helpful in obtaining acceptance and perhaps some modification of what the Government has proposed. The AUS opposed also the level of increase in fees and had this to say:
There is a presumption that all overseas students come from wealthy families, but this is not true. Most overseas students find it very difficult to pay their annual visa charge--

At that stage it ranged from $1,850 to $2,500. I must say that the Liberal Party and the National party do not oppose the concept of a fee for private, non- sponsored, overseas students. We acknowledge clearly that we introduced the fee and resisted the fierce opposition of the Australian Labor Party when we did so, but the same Party, now that it is in government, has failed to redeem the promises that it made when in opposition. Not only has the Hawke Government not got rid of the overseas students charge, as it said it would but also it has increased the charge substantially and has narrowed the access of those students from our region who may want access to education in Australia. That is a pity, especially in view of the other ways in which students in this country have been disadvantaged. I would just refer to the promises made to students about the level of the tertiary education assistance scheme, and so on, which have not been honoured.

The other concern, in addition to the increased charge, is the reduction in overseas student intake. There is real concern as to the extent to which adequate levels of intake will be maintained over the next few years, and the extent to which the Government will make adequate access as part of its good neighbour policy in the western Pacific and South East Asian region. We believe that the Government has responded in a knee-jerk fashion to a problem that is present predominantly on one campus in one State. There has been some difficulty on this and perhaps a couple of other campuses, but in view of the capacity that exists across Australia to take students, and in view of the Government's promise to increase access to higher education, the Government could have been less restrictive in regard to the numbers that it would allow in. Indeed, if the Government's promise of increased access and participation in higher education is to be met at the expense of overseas students, if what it is saying is 'We will keep them out to allow more home grown people in' it is a very short- sighted and unneighbourly policy in a region in which we have so much to offer and in which, traditionally, we have offered so much. Therefore, the Opposition will not seek to prevent the Bill from passing. I shall formally move the amendment which has been circulated and I indicate that no Committee stage amendments will be moved by the Opposition. I therefore move:

At end of motion, add '', but the Senate is of the opinion that- (a) the increased charges will cause personal hardship by preventing a large number of private overseas students from obtaining the benefits of secondary and tertiary education in Australia; and

(b) the substantially reduced overseas student intake for 1984 is not in the interests of Australia and its relations with our Asian and Pacific neighbours in that it is elitist, isolationist, selfish and mean''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out that the Opposition's amendment is in terms different from those originally read out by Senator Baume. I seek clarification as to which of those we are speaking to.
—The Opposition's amendment is that which has been circulated.

—The Australian Democrats believe that the decision indiscriminately to levy fees on overseas students is ill-conceived, counter- productive, and inconsistent with other policy objectives for Australia, particularly in the area of foreign policy. As an economically developed country in the Asian-Pacific region, the Australian Democrats believe that Australia has an obligation to assist in the development of struggling nations in our area. Many quite small nations have urgent problems in providing the bare essential needs of their population such as food, fresh water, primary schools, and basic health services. Thus, they cannot divert many resources towards the provision of extensive tertiary facilities. If they are to solve these problems in the long term they require doctors, medical researchers, technicians, agricultural scientists and technicians, biologists, teachers, sanitation and civil engineers , economists, agronomists, accountants and social scientists. In other words, their needs are great and their desire and thirst for knowledge is commensurate with their problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to levy fees, which amount to an insignificant proportion of Australia's total education budget, makes a mockery of the many statements of support that Australia has given to the issues of Third World development and the North-South dialogue. The very essence of the North-South dialogue is the transfer of technology from the developed to the underdeveloped countries. If we are to prove that our statements are not mere rhetoric and that we are seriously committed to helping those nations solve their pressing problems, one of the most obvious and immediately effective ways that we can do this is to make our tertiary institutions accessible to nationals of underdeveloped countries in an ordered way.

Another aspect of this issue is that this Bill, in levying higher fees on overseas students from underdeveloped countries, is that the percentage of students from very rich families will increase sharply while middle class families will find it much more difficult, if not impossible, to continue to finance their children's further education. I refer here, of course, to the private students and not to those students who are currently financed by the Australian Government. This, in turn, leads to greater inequalities within the countries themselves and is not an appropriate policy to be advanced by the Australian Government and certainly not, I would have thought, by an Australian Labor Party Government.

In this area the Australian Democrats believe that students should be assisted to study here by arrangements being made between ourselves and various nations in our region as an integral part of our entire foreign policy arrangements, this not only for students who are here on Australian-assisted study but also for private students. I emphasise that I am referring to both categories. The only proviso the Australian Democrats would wish to make on this would be that it should not be open to the governments of these countries to exploit such a policy to further any racial ends. For example, it ought not to be acceptable to Australia for Malaysia to send only Malay students while excluding Chinese students; nor should it be possible for the Philippines to exclude the Moslem minority from taking advantage of Australia's policy in this area.

In addition, the Democrats advocate the establishment of a system of variable fees for overseas students. This would involve an analysis on a country by country basis differentiating between living standards and rates of exchange. The fees charged would be paid in the country of origin and based on capacity to pay. The conditions under which Australian nationals can undertake further studies in these countries would also be taken into consideration. Such a scheme could be easily administered through our embassy network. It would involve a person applying to our embassy for assessment. We do not believe there would be any need for a policing of these applications as this would be too cumbersome and expensive, but we would support a provision that if a student was apprehended making a false declaration that student's tertiary course would be immediately terminated and no further study could be undertaken by that person in Australia.

Quite apart from the aid Australia can provide to other nations by making access to our tertiary institutions more easily attainable, Australia would reap many benefits from such a policy. The most important benefit for our country would arise from having people educated here who understand our outlook and way of life. In effect, they would become ambassadors of good will for Australia when they returned to their own nations. The major problem that the world is facing, the Democrats believe, is in the area of disarmament. Surely in a positive direction Australia can contribute towards this goal by creating a climate of good will between ourselves and those nations surrounding us, a contribution, I add, in excess of the amount we now make. At a tertiary level that contribution really boils down to a very small one indeed. Also, our students would get to know other cultures. I believe that this would be invaluable to Australia in developing a less xenophobic attitude to the world. We have difficulties in that regard because of our isolation and our monolingual structure. I believe that any efforts we can make in this regard are beneficial to our own citizens as well as to the citizens of other countries. The Democrats believe that in the long term such a policy will contribute far more than anything else towards understanding between nations, because it is understanding at the most fundamental and important level, an understanding between peoples. If one wanted to take a less idealistic view and wished merely to approach this on a materialistic and economic level, one might look at the cost that is involved to Australia and put against that the enormous amount of foreign exchange which comes into this country from overseas students.

I draw the attention of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) to the various statements that have been made, even within the last week, by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) and the importance that the Government, as a policy matter, now attaches to attracting tourists to Australia.

One of the arguments that Mr Brown has advanced in relation to that is the ability of people to come here and bring foreign exchange into Australia. Indeed , when one looks at figures one sees that the staggering amount of foreign exchange brought in by overseas students who live here on a year to year basis easily outweighs any current costs to the Australian Government. If one looks at the recent report of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau of the Department of Foreign Affairs-I refer to the 1981-82 report which came before the Senate in the last couple of weeks-one sees on pages 10 and 11 under the heading 'Education and Training' a discussion of the current efforts the Government is undertaking in this regard. The report states:
During 1981-82 over 4,000 students and trainees, ranging from undergraduate students to senior managers, were sponsored by the Australian Government to study in Australia . . .

The unfortunate part about that report is that the various lengths of stay of those people in Australia are not itemised. One has to read between the lines to work them out. I have been involved in some of these matters myself. The lengths of stay vary from as little as a week to up to a full two-semester or three-term operation at a tertiary institution. In effect, the number that we are looking at is not 4,000. In resource terms we are looking at 1,500, because we are looking at the tertiary institutions and at that level. The resource implications at other levels are minimal. Indeed, much of the resources allocated in other areas are picked up as an incidental cost only by tertiary institutions, Government departments and private industry. The Government should be very careful when it throws around figures which suggest that we are looking at 4,000. The figures to which we ought to address ourselves are figures for areas in which there is a substantive input, and in this regard it is those who attend tertiary institutions of whatever kind. I am referring not only to universities but also to colleges of advanced education and to technical colleges, because they are at the level from which the various underdeveloped countries within our region require technicians to help them to develop in the areas that I have already outlined in which they have such desperate need.

It is extremely disappointing that after the various statements that the Australian Labor Party has made-in fact, statements that we made together while the Labor Party was in opposition-it has not followed them through when in government. An enlightened policy in this area ought to be moving to cater not for the small vocal minority groups in the community, which are basing their arguments on pure racism and nothing else, but to a realisation that what comes to Australia from this area is to our benefit and is probably more to our benefit than it is to the benefit of the countries that we are helping. It is a disgrace and an extreme disappointment after the various things which the Labor Party said when in opposition, and which we said together, that it has not now, in government, followed through on its rhetoric. It is certainly extremely disappointing to the overseas students who are studying in Australia, as I am sure it is to many of the countries in our region.

Now that Senator Peter Baume's amendment has been clarified, the Australian Democrats can certainly support it. We could not support it previously because we are opposing the Bill, a Bill which we believe ought not to have been introduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition strongly supports the private overseas student program and the ability of overseas students, especially those from South East Asia and the Pacific, to come particularly to our tertiary institutions and to participate with Australian students and gain skills that they can then apply in their own countries. I remember participating in the debate when the Act that we are seeking to amend tonight was introduced in 1979. At that time all of us in the debate, on both sides of the chamber-the Australian Democrats did not participate in that debate-supported the overseas student program, saw it as worthwhile and wished to continue the by then well- established tradition in Australia of welcoming overseas students amongst us. However, in the debate in the House of Representatives in particular, it is evident this time, by the judgment of the Government, and by the Government's attack particularly upon Malaysian students coming to Australia, and by the terms of the review that was instituted to look at the private overseas student program in Australia, that perhaps there is a wavering on the Government's part from the full support that we have always given, on all sides of the chamber, in the past. I hope that that is not the case. I urge the Government, in response to the review that will come down eventually from Professor Goldring and the members of his committee, to come to a firm statement of support for the overseas student program in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Macklin has just said echoes my own view that the overseas student program is important to Australia. It has already created, particularly in the period after the Second World War, 30 years of good will between Australia and those countries in our immediate region with which we have special relationships . So many of the leaders of these countries were trained in Australia and they look with friendship and appreciation and with a knowledge that they have experienced in Australia a mutual friendship which is enduring. Australia should continue to contribute through both the sponsored overseas student program and the private overseas student program. I cannot say anything that would detract from what anyone has ever said in this Parliament about the importance of the overseas student program. I urge the Government to clarify any wobbling statement that has appeared in this debate already to the effect that there might be less than the full support that was indicated in earlier debates.

As Senator Peter Baume has said, the Opposition will support the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, which will amend the Act established under the Fraser Government. At that time, in 1979, we in government sought to achieve a balance between, on the one hand, access and assistance for overseas students to come and study in Australia, and, on the other hand, a reassurance to the Australian taxpayer that the contribution being made was appropriate, that in the judgment of the Parliament it was an appropriate amount to be contributed, and that there was not an open-ended drain upon government revenue in that direction. The cost of the private overseas student program is $70m, and some $ 25m is proposed to be recouped by the overseas student charge as amended by this Bill.

I draw back a little from Senator Macklin's full-bodied idealism which did not also state the obligation that we in this Parliament have to the taxpayers of Australia. As I said earlier, I share his idealism and his sense of vision about Australia contributing to the countries about us, but we need to have this balance. I do not resile at all from the measure introduced by the Fraser Government which proposed a balance in this matter.

The terms of this Bill are that what has been a range of charge of from $1,850 to a maximum of $2,500 will rise by about 15 per cent to a range of $2,150 to $2 ,900 as a maximum. About three-quarters of the private overseas students will pay at the lower end of that spectrum. It is estimated that about 35 to 40 per cent of the real cost of providing courses of tuition in our colleges and universities is thereby paid by the participating private students. It should also be recognised that not all private students are required to pay this charge . Secondary students are exempt from it, so it affects only those students who enrol in universities and colleges of advanced education. Also, all private students coming from Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific countries are exempt -or, rather, the Australian Government through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau or other overseas aid appropriated moneys pays the overseas student charges for those students. There are also private tertiary students from other parts of the world in some categories who, if they meet certain requirements as originally set out in the Overseas Students Charge Act, are exempt from paying this charge. There are now 8,000 overseas students in our universities and colleges. It is expected that about 5,000 of them would be paying this charge, and three quarters of those would be paying at the lower end of the charge spectrum.

I refer again to this sense of balance. The Parliament has an obligation to express its vision of Australia being of assistance and co-operating with students from the region about us, and indeed from all parts of the world, but that must be balanced with our obligation to the taxpayers of Australia. I am trying now to emphasise the hyprocrisy of members of the Australian Labor Party. Not only are they increasing the overseas student charge by introducing this Bill but also, quietly, in their hyprocrisy they are bringing in quotas. They are renewing quotas that will restrict the number of overseas students that will come into Australia. They are doing this despite the fact that four years ago in this chamber and in the other place they condemned the proposal that the former Government had introduced. They gave the impression that not only would they remove this overseas student charge when they came to office but also that they were against any restriction that would not allow the benefits that had been extended to overseas students, from Colombo Plan days especially, to continue to be available to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is their chance, isn't it?

—This is their great chance now, being in government, to follow up the conscientious statements that were made four years ago. In that debate the Labor Party spokesman on immigration and ethnic affairs, Moss Cass-who has now retired from the Parliament-made certain statements. The Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, who is in the chamber tonight led the debate in the Senate tonight. He made certain statements, as did Senator Colston and Senator Tate. All of them condemned this measure and all of them said that it was ill advised. I do not want in any way to so remind them of their statements then as to lead them to retract those statements. I am only asking them to recognise that back in 1979 we, in government, tried to argue that they were short sighted , that they were not seeking a balance, that they were just opposing for opposing's sake, being reactionary. I am not seeking to oppose this measure.
—What did you do for years?

—I have reread my speech of 25 October in the Senate and I still stand by all the words of that statement. I do not want to be hyprocritical like the Labor Party was at that time. I will not bore honourable senators with long quotations, but Dr Moss Cass said:

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the Government has taken the cheapest, nastiest and most superficial and irresponsible approach to the problem by imposing charges without honestly or fully assessing how the program is working . . .
Senator Grimes, who has just left the chamber, said:

It is in this scenario that Government Ministers searched around for the least odious way to bolster the Government's coffers. Who do they seize upon but the group, amongst many others, which is unable to defend itself and which is completely disenfranchised in this country . . .

Is the Government of today still imposing an increased charge and a restrictive quota on this same, as they put it, disenfranchised and weak group unable to defend itself? What has Senator Grimes to say about that? When in opposition, the statements made were reactionary. They were just opposing for opposing's sake. Now members of the Government are displaying their hyprocrisy. They are in fact not only endorsing our measure but also increasing the charge and whacking in a restrictive quota. At that time, Senator Colston stated:
. . . these overseas students charge Bills . . . introduce clear inconsistency into our educational policy. They revive, whether justly or not, suspicions that our immigration policies are racist.

I do not agree with that. I did not agree with it in 1979 and I do not agree with it now. I do not believe that this sense of balance between our obligations to the taxpayer and our vision towards overseas students is in any way racist; to the contrary. That is what was put up. Where is Senator Colston now? Is he claiming that his own Government's measure fits that description? He went on to say:

It also contradicts our foreign policy, in which Australia says that it will help people in overseas countries to obtain a better standard of living and to have more educated people. The whole thrust of our foreign policy is contradicted by these measures.
Indeed, Senator Tate said:
. . . this Bill . . . will have a disastrous impact on our international relations.

Where is Senator Tate now? Does he still believe that? I want to remind the Senate in this debate that in 1979 we came forward with a reasonable measure. It did not ruin our international relations. It was not seen as racist and it was not seen as a purely revenue raising measure, as was alleged; rather it was seen as a matter of balance. Honourable senators opposite, now they are in government , are stepping into our shoes fairly exactly but are imposing a higher charge. They have let down the overseas students in Australia, and indeed many other students in Australia who were concerned about this. The Labor Party claimed it was more concerned about this than we were and raised expectations that it would remove these charges. My last quotation from the debate in 1979 is from Senator Tate, who said:
For an investment of some $6m-
six million dollars was the amount expected to be raised in 1980, but now it is $25m-

we are gaining all that. I cannot think of any expenditure of a mere $6m which could devise such a system more calculated to create within the Pacific region and in south and south-eastern Asia a body of influential opinion inclined to understanding Australia. It must auger well for our political and commercial relations with that area.

At the time I agreed with Senator Tate's hope that we would build good relations with the students who would become graduates and leaders in their own countries, but I differed from Senator Tate by saying that it was appropriate that there be a contribution of that dimension to balance our obligations to the taxpayers of Australia. The hypocrisy and the failure of the Australian Labor Party to meet the expectations that it whipped up in its period in opposition are directly demonstrated in this Bill. I am glad that the Australian Labor Party Government has endorsed a particular measure which we introduced after the passing of the original Act, that is the measure to exempt the students from Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific. The overseas student charge which applies to the private overseas students from those areas is paid for through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, through the overseas aid vote of the Australian Parliament. I am glad that the Labor Government has seen fit to continue these arrangements.

I now turn to the question of quotas. In the period of the former Labor Government, in 1973, a quota of 10,000 students was introduced for the first time. The former Labor Government restricted the number of overseas students in 1973. In 1979, in parallel with the introduction of this original measure, we removed that quota. We said: 'In order to justify an open-ended number of overseas students we need to introduce a balance by imposing an overseas student charge.' But we expect, in these new circumstances, that the 1979 decision will lead to increased numbers of overseas students in Australia. The reactionary opposition of the day said: 'Numbers will not increase. They will be killed off. This charge will lead to a decline in numbers'. Do honourable senators opposite want me to quote all of the statements? What has happened? The numbers did increase. We said to the Senate in 1979 that, as a direct result of taking away the quota and of introducing a moderate charge-about 40 per cent of the average cost of tertiary education-we would expect to see an increase in the numbers. The number has increased. It has increased from 11,500 in those days to 13,500 now. In fact, it has increased so much and the pressure for further increases has so worried the Government that in a knee-jerk reaction it has whipped in a new quota for next year.

Labor governments bring down quotas on overseas students in Australia and Liberal governments remove the quotas. That should be understood. The quota is extraordinarily restrictive for 1984. It will allow only 1,500 new tertiary students to enter Australia. There are 4,000 students who will be able to enrol for the first time. It is estimated by the Government that 2,500 of those students are already enrolled in Australian secondary schools which allows for only 1,500 new tertiary students to enter Australia. That must be the lowest number in the last 25 years. This is an inappropriate, restrictive, slap in the face to the many overseas students who want to come to Australia. I do not support that quota. I now urge the Government to remove the quota and to await the result of its own review.

Professor Goldring and his committee have been given terms of reference for an inquiry into the private overseas students program. Why does not the Government await the results of that inquiry before prematurely bringing in this highly restrictive quota? It is not just a highly restrictive quota on newly arrived tertiary students but also it is especially restrictive on secondary students enrolling from Malaysia. The Labor Government has chosen on this matter to attack our near neighbour Malaysia.

Why has the Government picked on Malaysia? One argument may be that the student numbers in secondary schools from Malaysia have increased most dramatically. A substantial number of overseas students in Australia have always come from Malaysia. Strong ties have been established between Australians and Malaysians in every profession, especially in the fields of engineering, dentistry, medicine and the humanities. I think it is inappropriate and that it is contrary to the now reasonably bipartisan view that we seek to be closely aligned with our neighbours of the Association of South East Asian Nations. I know that we can be critical of a number of intiatives taken in the United Nations or with regard to Vietnam or with regard to consultation with ASEAN leaders. Those matters can be dealt with in foreign affairs debates. For the most part we have now established-both the Government and the Opposition-a goal of seeking close relationships with the ASEAN countries, Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific countries. But why muddy those waters with this particularly restrictive quota upon Malaysian students? Why introduce this quota before the review has been completed? I should like to quote just briefly the actual words used by the Opposition when dealing with our measure four years ago. Dr Cass moved this amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'consideration of the Bill be deferred until the Government presents a comprehensive proposal for a program of education aid for students from developing countries according to defined criteria including priority attention to academic ability, the needs of the developing nations and the needs of particular students.

In other words, he said, 'Defer the measure until you have reviewed the situation properly'. We maintained in that debate that this measure was an appropriate one to balance the abolition of the quota. But this Government has reimposed the quota and it has increased the charge without waiting for the results of the review. This is in direct contrast to the advice of the then Opposition spokesman four years ago. I ask the Government Ministers present, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), to take away these newly imposed quotas for 1984 and to await the review of the private overseas student program. If the Government does not wait for the results of that review I believe it will undermine the good will towards Australia amongst our near neighbours, particularly in ASEAN. This measure will be seen to be clumsy and bureaucratic and it will cause damage to Australia. In the light of what I have said about the 1979 debate, the hypocrisy of the Labor Party in this matter has been demonstrated. Why should we settle for a quick and unthinking reaction from the Government in this matter? Why should there not be a more considered and careful approach-an approach that is more consistent with our overall foreign policy and more consistent with the overseas student program of recent years which we have seen flourish in Australia?

I wish to refer briefly to two other matters. One is the notion of competition from overseas students with Australia's own students in universities, colleges, technical and further education colleges and schools. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) said this in his second reading speech on 20 September:

In the past few years, particularly in 1983, the numbers of overseas students admitted to Australia increased substantially over those of the previous year. The Government is concerned that as a result Australian students may not have been able to obtain places in the course of their choice at tertiary institutions.

I believe there is no evidence for that claim. The Minister did not refer to any university or any college where that was alleged to be the case. In which course are Australian students being denied enrolment because of overseas student competition? The Minister in his summing up in the House of Representatives debate referred to pressure of numbers-this is no surprise-in the traditional areas of enrolment of overseas students in Australia from ASEAN and South Pacific countries. This would include the faculties of medicine, dentistry, engineering and architecture. He referred to that but he did not give any concrete cases. He did not note any complaint from a student, an Australian family or from an educational institution.

I believe that this competition or pressure, this apparent squeezing out of Australian students, has not been established and is not factual. There is no evidence for it. By saying this in the Parliament the Minister is being derogatory of overseas students in Australia. He is pointing the finger at those students rather than underlining the welcome that we as Australians give to them . I think his attitude is unfortunate. I again urge the Government to retract such a statement, pending a careful examination by the review. In any event, how can 8,000 overseas students in our colleges and universities be much competition for more than 200,000 Australian students? Can 4 per cent squeeze out the 96 per cent? I do not think this argument is plausible. I believe that this action is a scare tactic. I harken back to the point I made at the beginning of my remarks when I asked the Labor Party to desist from this new departure which is compromising the overseas student program. Let there be a wholehearted statement from the Government that we value and want to see flourish an overseas students program in Australia. In any event, the institutions themselves are quite capable of introducing quotas, as they do, in a number of faculties to preserve a proper balance in those numbers. My time has expired. I can only urge that the Opposition's amendment be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have taken part in the debate, particularly Senator Baume and Senator Macklin who succeeded in making their points. Indeed, they made more points than Senator Teague did and in about half the time. First of all, in addressing Senator Teague's remarks, I wish to say this: There is no suggestion in any speech by any member of the Government in either House of the Parliament or outside of it that this Government, of all governments, intends to act to prevent private overseas students coming to this country in the way that he suggested. There is no suggestion that we intend to introduce any sort of program to prevent students from Asia, the Pacific or any country coming to Australia. Most of us on this side of the Senate who have been to universities in fact undertook our studies at a time when there were large numbers of Asian students in this country and we recognise the worth of that program. I think if anything is going to do damage to our relationships with other countries in this area it is people like Senator Teague coming into this place and saying: ' Because you are having a review of this program you might be a bit wobbly on it and you might be going to knock it off'. I think this is a cheap tactic which is not worthy of anyone in this House. It is a tactic which is destructive of our relationships with other countries. I think if the honourable senator cannot do any better than that he should not come in here and try to muddy the waters. With due respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, it is Senator Teague who is muddying the waters in this area and not anyone on this side of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact of the matter is that this legislaton and this program provides for an increase of 15 per cent in fees payable by overseas students which will in fact mean that there will be a recoupment of about 34 per cent of costs in this area. For people to come in here and complain that that increase is too high, when the recoupment factor was about 40 per cent in 1959 when the scheme was introduced, is a better example of hypocrisy than anything that Senator Teague has brought up today. In fact, the aim was to recoup 40 per cent when the program was first introduced. The level of fees has remained unchanged for three years and this measure will recoup 34 per cent of costs. At the same time the Government has instituted a review of private overseas student policy under Professor Goldring which we believe is important now as we believed it was important back in 1979.

I am the first to accept that some of the predictions that we thought might have taken place after the introduction of this program in 1979 did not take place. We were wrong. We did not have all the figures and as a result our predictions were wrong. We accept they were wrong. I have no worry at all about accepting that at that stage we were wrong. But we now have an entirely different situation which obviously requires review. Because of the budgetary considerations and because of the situation which now exists, we made two decisions. The first one was to upgrade fees by 15 per cent to a level which is still not comparable with the amount that was set in 1979. The second was that, because of advice from the Department of Education and Youth Affairs and the tertiary institutions and because of the burgeoning numbers of students who were coming to Australia, we introduced quotas. The quotas will mean that there will be 4,000 new private students from overseas who will attend our tertiary institutions. One must include the 2,500 who are already here. Of course, we have not changed the situation in regard to students from Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific as well as students who come to Australia under Australian Development Assistance Bureau schemes. They will in fact still be covered.

I accept Senator Macklin's point of view. I accept that if we are going to maintain good relations with the countries from which we take students, if we are going to assist underdeveloped countries develop, we should take students from overseas in increasing numbers to the extent that we can and we should strike a balance whereby we have a mixture of students who are aided and students who come under private schemes such as the ones we are talking about here tonight. But I believe that to take up Senator Macklin's suggestion that we in fact just have unrestricted entry and that we have no fees, particularly in the private student area, is in fact the most elitist thing we can do. I think that Senator Macklin should recognise that. Of course a system is elitist if the entry of private students is determined only by their capacity to pay. As both governments have tried to do in this area, we have to strike this balance. We have tried to make sure that we get a balance of students from different socio- economic groups and different countries. If we are going to introduce the sort of unrestricted system that Senator Macklin talks about we are going to have to increase enormously the number of our tertiary institutions. Maybe that is what we should be doing.

I and the Government accept the policy that we need to have overseas students. I have taken part in debate in this place with Senator Baume when we have both drawn the wrath of the racists in this country. We have deplored the sort of anti-foreign student nonsense which is going on all too often in some of our tertiary institutions, particularly at the University of New South Wales, but also at La Trobe University. In fact, at every university I have visited in recent times chancellors and vice-chancellors have expressed concern about this. In times of economic difficulty, in times when people are concerned about their future, there are those who will stir up this problem. There are those who will prey on the perception of some students that they are being restricted by the entry of overseas students. They will prey on this fear of students and cause the sorts of difficulties we are facing now. It is deplorable, and it is up to everyone in this place to get up and condemn that sort of behaviour.

In the present difficult situation a slowing down of the rate of increase may help the situation a little, but I would not like anyone to believe or to suggest that that has anything to do with the introduction of this policy and these increased fees. I repeat that all we have done is for the first time in three years, increased the fees by 15 per cent. All we have done is to bring the amount recouped to 34 per cent, where previously it was 40 per cent. All we have done is to act on the advice we have received from the various departments concerned that a quota should be introduced while we conduct this very important review of overseas students policy, a review that I believe should have been conducted a long time ago.

The amendment moved by the Opposition suggests that, firstly, bringing the fees to far less than the percentage recovered in 1979 will cut down the number of students and, secondly, that this is an elitist, isolationalist, selfish and mean policy. I do not believe that that can be sustained by the facts, and particularly by the facts in the example that Senator Teague used regarding Malaysian students. Malaysian students make up something like 50 per cent of all overseas students in Australia. The restrictions we have placed in this area have not been put in place without talking to and consulting with the Malaysian Minister for Education. When the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) was in Kuala Lumpur he urged the Malaysian Minister and the Malaysian Government to make a submission to the inquiry chaired by Professor Goldring. As a result of the Minister's talks with the Malyasian Government representatives, there is an understanding of what we face and what is going on.

I hope that in future the number of overseas tertiary students in this country will continue to increase and that the great contribution this country can make to the world, through our tertiary education system, will continue. I am sure that it will. It can only do so, I suggest, by increasing the facilities available in tertiary education in this country, because already we have a deplorable retention rate at the tertiary and upper secondary levels of our own students in this community.

I think the criticisms of this combined change, which introduces modest increases and at the same time provides for a proper and sensible review of our overseas students system, are unfair. I accept that for political and all sorts of reasons the amendment will succeed, as he obviously has the support of the Australian Democrats. I am only grateful that the Bill will pass despite the amendment and that we can look forward in the future to the more sensible and balanced policy that Senator Teague claims he wants. Under those circumstances I thank those who have contributed. I will not delay the Senate any further.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (APPROPRIATION BILLS) BILL 1983CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (DOUBLE DISSOLUTION) BILL 1983

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-A matter was raised by way of point of order in relation to the vote on the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill. At that time I suggested that we might seek some clarification of the issues. After a lengthy discussion I am able to report that there is not much clarification, but that we are agreed on a course of action. The dispute arose over a miscount, in one case, and also over the question of pairs. Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) would care to indicate his position, and then I can respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The matter affects two of the private senators' Bills which have been brought forward, that is, the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill. Firstly, we seek leave of the Senate to recommit the vote at the second reading of each of those Bills, the first of which showed a defeat for the Bill on the basis of a majority of votes being against it, and the second of which was defeated on a tied vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with respect to the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill is that there was some confusion about the question of pairs. In each case the Government and the Opposition had an official stance with respect to the Bill and, therefore, in the normal course of events the pairing arrangements would apply. The pairing arrangements between the Government and the Opposition at this stage on this day are that six pairs are outstanding. As I understand it , the count which was taken effectively reflected four pairs being shown. In any event, a number of Government senators and a larger number of Opposition senators were missing. In the event, because of that the motion was lost. The Opposition would simply ask for the recommittal of that vote so that the vote can be taken again and the number of pairs held at six.

With respect to the Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill, the same problem with respect to pairs arises but, in addition, Senator Lewis was present for that vote but was not picked up as being present. I do not think there is any dispute that he was present. I am sure that he is about to assert that very strongly. In any event, I think there is no disagreement that inadvertently he was not included on the list; he was not counted. For that reason the vote on the second reading was lost when it should have been carried. I understand Senator Lewis's preference would be to have the original division list corrected because he does not want it to be thought that he was absent from that vote. I do not know whether that is possible or not. In any event, I wish to put it on the record now that he certainly was present for that vote although he was not counted.

We are now seeking the recommittal of the second reading vote of the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill 1983. Subsequently that will go to a third reading which the Opposition understands will, in fact, be lost because the Bill cannot be carried with the required constitutional majority. The same will apply to the Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government is in broad agreement with the course outlined by Senator Chaney. I should say for the record that it was the Government's understanding that there were no pairs in respect of those two Bills. It was the Opposition Whip's understanding that there might have been. In all those circumstances it became a little difficult. We are quite happy that the course suggested by Senator Chaney take place, but we suggest it take place as rapidly as possible. I do not know how many minutes we have to ring the bells for.

—by leave-I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) whether he would give consideration to my seeking leave to have the Hansard record of the voting on the Constitution Alteration (Double Dissolution) Bill corrected to show that I was present for that vote. I do not think it will create any great difficulty if, by leave, that correction is made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not mind accepting people's word that Senator Lewis was here, but I do not want him to delay the Senate for a long time trying to get his name in Hansard. Senator Chaney has said Senator Lewis was here; I am happily persuaded that he was here. Of course the votes will still have to be recommitted whether he was all here, all there or not. Certainly, if the Government's leave is all that is required for that alteration to be made, I give it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the recommittal of the votes?

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill 1983 be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.
