QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the rules relating to who is entitled to travel on VIP aircraft been changed by the Hawke Government.
(2) Are Ministers and members of parliament required to obtain the specific permission of the Minister for Defence to use the VIP aircraft, as was the case for the Fraser Government.
(3) Who is permitted to use VIP aircraft.
(4) Did Mr Clyde Cameron travel aboard a VIP aircraft to Darwin with the Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, as was reported in the Weekend Australian 4-5 June 1983.
(5) Was Mr Cameron given permission to travel to Darwin aboard the VIP jet.
(6) On what grounds was permission to travel on a VIP aircraft granted to Mr Cameron.
(7) How many other former members of parliament and non-Ministers of parliament have been on VIP flights since 5 March 1983, and who are they.
(8) Will ALP officials and supporters be able to receive permission to travel aboard VIP aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Yes.

(3) A list of persons entitled to travel on SP aircraft is provided in the Rules Governing the Use of Special Purpose Aircraft which were tabled in Parliament in March 1973 by the then Minister for Defence, Mr Barnard.
(5) (Not applicable-see (4) above).
(6) (Not applicable-see (4) above).

(7) The honourable senator's attention is drawn to the schedule of special purpose flights conducted by the Royal Australian Air Force in the period 1 January to 30 June 1983 tabled in the Senate on 6 September 1983. This schedule contains all details of passengers carried.

(8) In accordance with guidelines which have been followed by successive governments, approval may be given for persons to accompany Ministers on special purpose aircraft in special circumstances. In the case of members of political party organisations, among others, fare recovery action is usually taken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will Australia lose the benefits of a sunrise medical technology industry, export income prospects of over $100m, and direct employment of 250 people by handing the beneficial ownership of the assets, goodwill, and business of Hospital Products Ltd, in New South Wales, to the United States Surgical Corporation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The ownership and control of the assets, goodwill, and business of Hospital Products Ltd in New South Wales has been the subject of extensive legal proceedings.

I understand that the decision of the New South Wales Court of Appeal was to the effect that, because of breaches of fiduciary duties, all the assets of Hospital Products Ltd should be regarded as held in trust for the United States Surgical Corporation.

An appeal has since been lodged with the High Court against the decision of the New South Wales Court of Appeal. There was a hearing of some interlocutory matters on 2 September 1983, where the parties gave undertakings not to divest themselves of property and generally maintain the status quo in respect of Hospital Products Ltd. The matter is expected to come on for a full hearing in the High Court sittings commencing in February 1984.

It would not be appropriate for me to comment on this case while this appeal is before the Court. Until the Court makes a ruling and the final intentions of the respective parties become known, the implications of this case for Australia's medical technology industry cannot be accurately assessed. The Commonwealth will continue to keep the matter under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department of Social Security accept a reverse charge telephone call after country hostels have been telephoned by STD or by way of a booked call in relation to information required by the Department and where the hostel personnel are obliged to return the call with the information required; if not, will the Department adopt this practice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department's normal practice when seeking information is to request the information in writing. If the information is required urgently it is the usual practice for officers to telephone back at a pre-arranged time to collect the information requested.

It is not normal for my Department to accept reverse charge calls, unless exceptional circumstances are evident. My Department has no plans to adopt this practice; rather it endeavours to keep telephone requests for information from organisations to a minimum.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will reductions in staffing levels within the Department of Defence affect the Defence Research Centre at Salisbury, South Australia; if so, to what extent will this centre be affected and in what manner will staffing levels be reduced.
(2) Will the Minister give an assurance that this centre will not be affected to a disproportionately large extent compared with his Department as a whole.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. As part of planned staff reductions within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO), the total strength of the Defence Research Centre, Salisbury (DRCS) will be reduced by about 60 during 1983-84. Some further reductions are contemplated within the DSTO over the following three years but the effect on individual laboratories has still to be determined. The reductions will be achieved by selective non-replacement of wastage; there will be no retrenchments.

(2) At present, reductions planned for the administrative elements at DRCS are larger than those proposed at other DSTO laboratories because the number of staff engaged there in administrative functions appears disproportionately high. A special review is to be made of this area before final decisions are taken on the level of cuts to be applied.
